column13: I am an artist and curator based in Toronto_COMMA_ Ontario. I was born in Moscow_COMMA_ Russia. My practice is organizational and curatorial : in Toronto I run a number of organizations that explore alternative approaches to image making_COMMA_ production_COMMA_ and consumption. I am interested in subverting traditional templates within the art system. I enjoy nature and physical challenge. Once I biked from Toronto to Montreal with a dog.
column14: In my practice_COMMA_ i often crowd source to fill in the gaps or as the focus of a project. I have had several projects involving large group of people that are activated by participation. In a way_COMMA_ part of my work as artist-curator involves the construction of an alternate reality occupied by the artists and art projects that i become involved with. my work in publications and performance is often extremely collaborative_COMMA_ and I am a member of a number of loose collectives.
column15: One example of a collaborative practice is my project Rearviews: a review is reviewed and that review is reviewed again by a string of people_COMMA_ like an exquisite corpse or a broken telephone. this eventually constitutes a publication. In the broken string of reviews are narrative that evolve between the reviewers_COMMA_ and which ultimately require collaborative support. In this project_COMMA_ people reveal themselves as tending to engage in a joined narrative that connects them as characters_COMMA_ not reviewers.
column16: I the summers of 2012 and 2011 I have spent a while in a local residency started by my friends and i called Don Blanche. In this residency_COMMA_ we would execute a number of art projects - some sculpture_COMMA_ some performance_COMMA_ some installation. we also built a sauna and a hot tub from scratch_COMMA_ and made a beach by ordering a lot of sand. everyone lived on cots in tents or in one big dorm and share space and meals. the residency would have between 18-40 people in it at any given time_COMMA_ it would last for 2 weeks.
column17: i am interested in improvised delivery of projects _COMMA_ which seems inevitable in the hike scenario. I like that it involves movement of both time and space_COMMA_ conceptually_COMMA_ this is interesting to me. I am also looking forward to becoming inspired by the mobility and physical activity involved - its refreshing to have a summit or a conference in a mobile format.
column18: something i would be interested in is the subject of score - through looking at a number of film/musical scores from hitchcock to john cage_COMMA_ I would be very interested in talking about the visual representation and importance of the score_COMMA_ as not only a document but a map. I would also be interested in having a micro reading group - where we discuss a short text impromptu_COMMA_ while walking_COMMA_ cooking or what have you_COMMA_
column20: what do you hope to take from this experience?_NEWLINE_I am hoping to meet people. that are different or like minded_COMMA_ to see new approaches to presentation/ workshoopping_COMMA_ to learn some new things and to teach somethings to others_COMMA_ and to maybe have some new ideas.

column13: My work often takes me down unexplored and surprising avenues. It is exciting for me when I end up with something completely unexpected. I rarely consider any part of my process as a mistake_COMMA_ because in the end_COMMA_ no matter where I go_COMMA_ I have learned and explored something new. Being fully immersed in a community that leaves room for progressive discovery has taught me that the only way to make work is to make work. Period. No matter how seemingly “chaotic” my process gets_COMMA_ my soul is so deeply rooted in a need to have my hands on materials that I cannot stop creating. _NEWLINE_I recently completed my final semester at Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design_COMMA_ and I am eager to break away from institutional ideals.
column14: In order to create art_COMMA_ I begin my process by entering into a meditative space_COMMA_ creating small places of order in my studio. Evaluating natural commonalities between these small places_COMMA_ I begin to develop an idea_COMMA_ and then move into the act of editing and clarifying the idea. Said created order can be built alone or collectively. Both approaches are always moving forward_COMMA_ naturally moving into an idea. Editing and clarifying the idea is best done collectively_COMMA_ with many different perspectives from others. Upon clarifying created ideas_COMMA_ work is made. I am always eager to collaborate_COMMA_ our realities depending fully on others.
column15: In unifying found objects by color_COMMA_ I strive to set up a scenario that leaves room for my audience to confront their own obsessions with materialism. The Blasphemy Project seeks to address the problematic ways in which culture encourages people to interact. Materials become the means by which we communicate_COMMA_ becoming a substitute for one to one sincere communication of our emotions. Through objects we jump to conclusions about identity_COMMA_ rather than slowly engaging with the newness of the other. In short_COMMA_ objects become proxies for others and control our experiences with others._NEWLINE_My work is tangible in order to be confrontational. I work to coerce viewers to regard everyday objects in a new light. In this body of work_COMMA_ I am taking objects laden with feminine expectations_COMMA_ altering them into a silhouette of color_COMMA_ and re appropriating them into a substitution for women. The pink I use has a similar level of energy as a bright red_COMMA_ but is less aggressive. In popular media_COMMA_ pink is a color associated with women. In painting these bright pink objects they become a tongue in cheek representation of themselves_COMMA_ amplifying their feminine nature to an even higher level._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://gracemcmicken.tumblr.com/
column16: I have not experienced a living experience this unique yet in my life. I am eager to experience connection on this level.
column17: In my current practice_COMMA_ I have always had a kind of power struggle with my instructors. I want thinkers and collaborators to be able to completely open themselves up to connection_COMMA_ without restraint in regards to hierarchical "roles". These roles are made up and set up boundaries between student and instructor_COMMA_ and I wish to break through these boundaries to enter into genuine_COMMA_ open connection and insight. I see this as a fantastic opportunity to do so._NEWLINE_I am drawn to the Unthinking/Unknowing program as a means to separate myself from the act of thinking in order to enter into meditative creation.

column13: I was born in 1954 to a family of Yoruba wood carvers called AJIBOGUNDE in the western part of Nigeria_COMMA_ Ogbomoso. I had my elementary and part of my secondary education in Ghana_COMMA_ between 1966 and 1969. I came to Nigeria in 1970 to further my secondary and tertiary education. I am currently a painting lecturer in the department of art_COMMA_ design and printing technology_COMMA_ The Polytechnic_COMMA_ Ibadan Oyo State_COMMA_ Nigeria. I bagged my first degree in Painting from The Ahmadu Bello University_COMMA_ Zaria in 1985 and a master’s degree in African studies (visual art) from The University of Ibadan in 1991_COMMA_ Ph.D in Art History from The Commonwealth Open University_COMMA_ British Virgin Islands_COMMA_ U.K. in 2013. I was the pioneer art teacher at the Local Authority Teachers College_COMMA_ Osogbo_COMMA_ before I joined the Polytechnic_COMMA_ where I am now a Senior Principal lecturer of painting and Art History. I was made a justice of Peace of Oyo State in 2000._NEWLINE_Between 1999 and 2001_COMMA_ 2007_COMMA_ 2009-12_COMMA_ I was the Head of Department. In 2006_COMMA_ I participated in art workshop in Egypt and in 2006 was artist in residence at Air Le Parc_COMMA_ Pampellon_COMMA_ France._NEWLINE_I have participated in different art exhibitions_COMMA_ art fairs and biennale such as PANAFEST_NEWLINE_1997 AND 1999 and SIAO in Ouagadougou_COMMA_ Burkina Faso 1998 and 2000. I have many articles in academic journals_COMMA_ twenty group exhibitions and six solo. I was in Atlanta_COMMA_ Georgia for artist in residence programme in 2009/10 and in Zambia for art workshop in 2010(Insarkartists Workshop_COMMA_ Livingstone) My works are seen in private and public places which include World Bank Washington DC_COMMA_ USA.I am a fellow of Hambidge Centre for the creative arts and Virginia Centre for the Creative Arts all in USA. I am the Executive Director of Centre for Afrikan Art and Designs_COMMA_Awotan-Apete Ibadan. I am happily married and blessed with children.

column13: I am an artist living and working in Brooklyn_COMMA_ NY. My background is in sculpture and I really enjoy learning about building and fabrication. For the past 8 years I have worked two dimensionally and the last three years specifically in painting and printmaking. For the past five years I also worked as the Director of a non-profit arts organization in NYC and now work as a freelance grant writer and consultant for artists and organizations. I am also an avid cyclist and take long rides upstate as much as possible. I have a penchant for American History and read a lot of books on various topics of war_COMMA_ Native Americans_COMMA_ slavery and the psychology of killing (as it relates to war and ritual).
column14: I rely on collaboration in various ways_COMMA_ but primarily through having a wide range of people through my studio for visits where we talk about art_COMMA_ painting_COMMA_ my paintings and many other things_COMMA_ sometimes only indirectly related to art. The people who participate in studio visits range from artists_COMMA_ curators_COMMA_ galleriest and collectors to writers_COMMA_ musicians_COMMA_ and non-artists. I have collaborated in the past in a more traditional sense that involved equal input on creative and aesthetic fronts. Also_COMMA_ because painting can be a relatively solitary practice_COMMA_ I have side projects I work on making zines and collaborating in a variety of ways using the zine format as the basis for development.
column15: In 2009 I collaborated with artist Heather Willems for an outdoor project hosted by Art In Odd Places_COMMA_ NYC. Together we built more than 60 individual letters of the alphabet (50 inches tall) as soft sculptures that were paraded down 14th Street by volunteers and then arranged to spell several different empowering phrases once we reached Union Square. If was a fun project and got more interesting when the public wanted to join in and start spelling their own phrases and words. Below is a website we set up for the project and a link to an interview we did at Union Square. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://loudspeakerpresents.wordpress.com/tag/jenn-dierdorf/_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HtGR75T24M8
column16: Art related communal living experiences would include the 3 residency programs I've participated in. Each was very different in the way they were set up and how much interaction was encouraged in each_COMMA_ but in all three the relationships I built during my time there was important and continue today. I really enjoy and benefit from communal environments_COMMA_ but usually due to work_COMMA_ studio and other obligations I dont have much time to devote to nurturing those types of relationships/environments for myself. I would welcome the opportunity to meet new people_COMMA_ learn and share about things and have provocative conversations. I get along easily with others and am generally flexible and have the ability to adapt to new situations well.
column17: I think that completing a 50 mile hike with a group of interesting people I've never met will be a fun challenge. I'm interested in what I may find along the way_COMMA_ in terms of new things_COMMA_ things I can learn about myself and about others. I think its important to change your environment from time to time and that a disruption in a routine can make room for new things in interesting ways. I deliberately instigate disruptions for myself_COMMA_ however this experience would give me less control over the situation (who is there_COMMA_where we are_COMMA_ what we're doing) and that interests me.
column18: My initial thought for a project of this nature_COMMA_ and something dear to me that I could share with a group would be that I could host an ongoing "storytelling" event throughout the hike._NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_ I have read an extensive amount on the history of New York City_COMMA_ the whaling industry in the U.S.and the ship wreck of the ESSEX (the story the Moby Dick is written about)_COMMA_ abolitionists_COMMA_ the Gold Rush_COMMA_ and much more. I find specific stories related to these topics reveal an intimacy and connection that remove some of the distance between our contemporary selves and the ancestors that created that history. They are also incredibly fascinating stories! I would probably select a story for each night of the hike and research the topics in order to put together a concise story to tell. Each story could be organized in to a category to be considered_COMMA_ i.e. "The 9 Levels of Hell" (Dante's Inferno) or "The 5 Hindrances" (Buddhist thought).
column20: List three new things you've learned in the past year. And one thing you plan to learn. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Last year I learned 1) how to play the ukulele_COMMA_ 2) how to survive massive change in my life 3) how to bake a good biscuit_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I want to learn how to do a wheelie.

column13: I am a very warm hearted individual. I am hardworking and inquisitive. I swim in the ocean when it’s cold outside. I am buoyant and carry a strong optimism. I look to wonder and possibility. I like to wake up early_COMMA_ early enough_COMMA_ just before the sun gets up because then it is like we are getting up together. I open the curtains and observe the beginning. I like to get outside first thing_COMMA_ check in with the air; most often I do this by bike. I grew up in Watsonville_COMMA_ CA at the bottom of the Santa Cruz Mountains_COMMA_ across from raspberry fields. I moved south as an adolescent and back up north to Olympia for university at The Evergreen State College. This is where I really started to develop my relationship to thinking and making_COMMA_ thinking as a making. Now I live in Oakland_COMMA_ CA where I share house with my partner and 6 other people; I rent and share studio space in Chinatown. My studio is a thinking room. I go here to collect my experiences and perceptions and turn them into questions or remarks. My day jobs are on either sides of Chinatown at a coffee warehouse facility and a farmers market. These places all form a constellation that is my sanctuary.
column14: I see my way of thinking and making as collaborative. Not only in the kinds of art that I am producing but also in how I think about what art is. I think about art as something whose value is found in process or in the making. The work that is interesting for me to make is that which is experience oriented or that which exists in the direct engagement of someone with the work. Often times when I am constructing something_COMMA_ I am thinking about a conversation that I want to have and the work becomes the prelude to that conversation as well as evidence of it. Through my practice_COMMA_ I begin to make a trail that weaves in and out of objects and experiences_COMMA_ out of sitting and reading_COMMA_ to drawing and teaching. The practice that I have is kind of like thinking because it is never really over_COMMA_ it is an exploration; it is inquisitive.
column15: I recently went to Iceland. I wanted to go to a very isolated place to investigate if you can experience a landscape paying attention to you or if you can only experience a landscape paying attention to itself. This question developed in tandem with a fascination for ASMR (Autonomous Sensory Meridian Response). Most causes of this sensation are mundane: whispering_COMMA_ chewing_COMMA_ getting a haircut_COMMA_ unpredictable movement_COMMA_ etc. and produce an intense tingling sensation in the back of the neck_COMMA_ on the head_COMMA_ and other places on the body. The sensation is distinctly non-sexual. People are experiencing intense pleasure from watching and engaging in activities where nothing really happens. It is not about the action that is taking place but what state of attention these mundane actions have to offer. There seems to be an underlying practice of empathy that this kind of engagement has to offer. I am drawn to this community that has formed around participation in nothing and I would like to explore what else there is to learn from it.I have been making a series of experiments based on my Iceland adventure and ASMR research. I created a performance in which someone sits down at a table_COMMA_ puts on headphones and is then guided through peeling and cutting a potato. I sit across from them and watch.
column16: I currently live in house with my partner_COMMA_ 6 other people_COMMA_ and Shasta_COMMA_ the dog. All of us are in our mid-twenties to early thirties and are social justice_COMMA_ direct service oriented. We have a big backyard with three raised garden beds. Kevin and I grow a variety of vegetables for the house. We all share food and upkeep responsibilities. We cook for each other and we gather once a month for a meeting. We don’t have a lot of firm cooking/cleaning structures but we all respect the space and each other and our house reflects that. Since moving here 6 months ago_COMMA_ I have really enjoyed the sense of support and care that comes with sharing a living space. At times_COMMA_ I have also found it challenging to live in a social environment where sometimes have to compromise time alone. Ultimately_COMMA_ I feel so lucky to share the space I do with this group of people and for how I continue to grow through the experience.
column17: The question “How can one make thinking?” is one that drives my practice. At this time in my life_COMMA_ I find that I explore this question and I mostly explore it alone. Since returning to SF Bay Area_COMMA_ I have built a strong community and yet I have struggled to find people who engage in making as a practice of thinking like I do. A lot of the people_COMMA_ artists among them that I have built strong alliances with here_COMMA_ are more material driven in their work. This has been an ongoing challenge for me because of how much I enjoy the exploration and collaborative engagement that comes from discussion and work that is defined by its nature of being unfinished. I largely focus on making thinking and ways of knowing visible and I would strongly benefit from looking at unmaking thinking and making unthinking_COMMA_ etc._NEWLINE_I am also really drawn to where both teachers-in-residence_COMMA_ Benjamin Korta and Danièle Bourque_COMMA_ are coming from_COMMA_ specifically their respective relationships to Zen and spiritual care. Attention and awareness have been strong guiding principles in my work and I would be interested in working with people whose work is founded in these concepts.
column19: I would take the work that I have been doing with the ocean and explore it in the context of unthinking/unknowing with the other residents. I would have us all go to the ocean for 2 days and run a series of exercises to practice making the sound of the ocean at different points along the shore; presumably different sounds for different places. At each place we would gather a part of the ocean to bring back with us to the residence. There_COMMA_ we would place our large samples of Atlantic Ocean into big_COMMA_ quiet freezers. When the ocean will have frozen_COMMA_ we would set the different samples in a large room on the floor and sing the sound of the different ocean homes that we had learned from our practice_COMMA_ slowly the sea water would melt and the performers would come to face each other making their respective sounds of the ocean.
column20: At what point is the ocean not the ocean? _NEWLINE_The ocean will always be the ocean_COMMA_ even when it is only salt
column21: I don’t foresee any scheduling conflicts. I may like to have a visitor or two.

column13: I am a Mexican artist living and working in New Haven_COMMA_ Connecticut. I received my BA in Fine Art from London Central Saint Martins College of Art & Design._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Although my practice is irrefutably linked to photography_COMMA_ it embraces the sculptural. At its core lies a preoccupation for the photograph’s conflictive nature as both a body in space and an image’s carrier. Moreover_COMMA_ within my work there is always the aim to further understand how information is structured_COMMA_ specifically within visual and physical frameworks_COMMA_ and how we maneuver our way through these information systems. I am interested in the role memory and culture play in our reading of both images and objects_COMMA_ and art production’s relation to this as a gradual reshuffling of cultural forms through their strategic re-use and transformation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My work has been previously exhibited in several exhibitions throughout London_COMMA_ such as "Rare Gifts" at The Residence Gallery (London_COMMA_ 2012)_COMMA_ "TRACE" at Frameless Gallery (London_COMMA_ 2012)_COMMA_ “Inhabited (Flatfile) at Artspace (New Haven_COMMA_ 2013) and “Digital Ground” at Ely Slade House for Contemporary art (New Haven_COMMA_ 2013).etc. In 2011 her work was shortlisted for the BARTUR Award in Photography_COMMA_ and was also shortlisted for the Zeitgeist Open 2012. . Last May I was awarded the Artspace New Haven 2013 Year-long Residency My work has also be featured in Fan the Fire Magazine’s July 2013 issue_COMMA_ Studio Magazine’s Winter 2013 Edition_COMMA_ in the Hartford Courant_COMMA_ amongst others. My work is currently being exhibited as part of Artspace NH’s Crown St Window Project (Feb-March ’14) as well as a within four month project at the Young Men’s Institute (New Haven_COMMA_ CT). Additionally I am now working on curating a show for the YMI’S Gallery_COMMA_ which will open this May.
column14: Intellectually my practice is fed by the contemporary art flux and is influence by its context. I find that maintaining a dialogue about my ideas related to my work is key to my thought structuring process. Conversations makeup the intellectual feeding and testing ground for my ideas/projects. Thus_COMMA_ I try to have regular studio visits and I have a weekly skype session with another artist with whom I have collaborated on various joint projects. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I have previously collaborated and shared authorship over larger works and in curating exhibitions. Ei: with Isabelle Gressel_COMMA_ I created the Unhomely Project. This work consisted of a public domestic environment using temporary donations of personal home items and functioned as an art installation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Likewise_COMMA_ part of my practice seeks to question who is the audience and what is their role_COMMA_ implicating others directly within my work. Ei: In The Postcard Project_COMMA_ people close to me with whom I’ve share an experience_COMMA_ receive (without any prior notice) a post-card with an snapshot of the event_COMMA_ shaping the work and becoming the work’s primary audience. Meanwhile those external to the work must rely solely on the description of the project and their imagination_COMMA_ functioning as a secondary audience. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Similarly_COMMA_ I am currently working on curating a show that will be the end result of an postal art project titled “Por Oaxaca”. Here I have sent a selection artists from different backgrounds/countries a photograph and asked them to respond to the image without any further instructions or information on the photograph. My aim is to question my role as an author of a piece_COMMA_ while incorporating various narrative voices_COMMA_ and question how cultural and social factors affect our reading of a culturally loaded image. Only the artworks produced by the participant artist will be displayed within the exhibition.
column15: My current series in progress would very much represent the thought_COMMA_ research_COMMA_ and making process that take place within my practice. This series_COMMA_ titled Maroon Bells and Paradise_COMMA_ plays with fragmenting photography’s materiality_COMMA_ both physical and/or digital. The series is composed of a set of photograms made-up of downloaded_COMMA_ pixilated_COMMA_ and recomposed landscape photographs from notable photographers. In these there is a use of abundant texture and image distortion meant as strategies of reappraising the history of landscape composition_COMMA_ while confronting the viewer with a screen that allows no visual progression into it. Its aim is very much to place the viewer in a state of already knowing (having encountered images in this state of decomposition_COMMA_ as much a landscape images prior to this) conscious or unconsciously_COMMA_ and unknowing given that he can’t make any logical sense of what the image is as a whole. Given that he is presented with a screen of information that contains no given structure to order the viewing experience. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The series aims to play with shared images (abundant in our contemporary media society) and strategies of appropriation. It would also address the contemporary erosion of visual data_COMMA_ contesting the relationship between digital and analogue manipulation. Likewise it looks into the visual and physical frameworks that structure our engagement with reality. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My aims to question the false utopia of access and commonality advertized by contemporary image media. The paradox of the digital and image era is that it ultimately denies us any entry_COMMA_ visual or tactile_COMMA_ into the universe of screens that compose it. We are constantly in a state of knowing/unknowing. The series spotlights our shallow visual reading skills and our contemporary understanding of reality based on a myriad of images in which we have no real presence
column16: Besides having lived with multiple flat-mates and going to summer camp as a kid_COMMA_ was going to boarding school as a teenager was the most intense experience and condensed communal living experience. I went to a co-ed school_COMMA_ where dormitories were male/female only_COMMA_ but we could invite boys over to our ‘living room’. In addition_COMMA_ I had to share my bedroom and the dormitory had communal bathrooms. This meant that we spent all day with a closed group of people sharing every moment from breakfast to afterschool sports_COMMA_ and even field trips to the local cinema. Although the experience was intense_COMMA_ it was very rewarding. I made some long-term friendships there and became much more tolerant and flexible towards others personalities_COMMA_ needs_COMMA_ and beliefs. Furthermore living and going to class with the same group of people benefited my learning process_COMMA_ my friends were more open to discuss school topics as dinner conversations and help out each other in areas one was falling behind. Boarding school became a stepping-stone in my coming of age_COMMA_ helping me gain some independence from family life and shaping myself as an individual within a social context.
column17: I feel the need to reconsider my processes in relation to my artistic concerns_COMMA_ and how they are understood in and across different social_COMMA_ artistic and intellectual contexts. Being in a collaborative environment with artists across disciplines would open my artistic horizons. The arising conversations will provide a testing ground for my ideas and spur my practice forward._NEWLINE_Being in such an environment would force me to re-appraise my innate structured thinking and creating logic that seeks to order and accommodate an incessant amount of thoughts. Although I am mentally flexible and can adapt to variety of thinking environments_COMMA_ having a mixture of lecture_COMMA_ physical-psychological exercises_COMMA_ creative and collaborative time will allow me to gain a perspective on my own work which unattainable to me at the moment. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Moreover_COMMA_ the concept of unthinking/unknowing_COMMA_ in relation to that of entry and being held at bay by art as well as an understanding of emptiness and totality (infinite) at one point being equivalent_COMMA_ have been and are prevalent through out my practice.
column19: I would produce one of the immersive image-environment installations that I have been recently planning. This would be composed of self-standing wooden walls_COMMA_ laid out overlapping each other. These would be placed in the middle of the gallery_COMMA_ emphasizing the work’s sculptural nature and allowing the audience to both walk between the panels and stand back to see the work as a one whole composition. The installation would address the visual and physical frameworks that structure our engagement with space_COMMA_ exploring how art historical notions like perspective and the picturesque have been carried forward through the prevalence of contemporary image-media. _NEWLINE_Likewise_COMMA_ I’ve been thinking of having an image/s printed on curtains. The images would be representations of either landscape or architecture_COMMA_ blown up to almost a 1.1 ratio. Within our contemporary media we constantly engage with ‘image milieus’ where we have no real physical presence – a constant interplay between entry and referral. Printing on curtains would allow the audience to walk through the image_COMMA_ seemingly entering it_COMMA_ while paradoxically emphasizing the surface nature of images. The audience would thus engage on a physical level with the image_COMMA_ spotlighting the images’ dependence on a medium/body and their screen-like presence.
column20: What is a good_COMMA_ note-worthy question to ask and answer? Unfortunately no good question can be given one straightforward answer_COMMA_ at least within my personal thought process. Answers are dependent of the context_COMMA_ the depth of the response_COMMA_ as much as the person answering subjectivity and cultural_COMMA_ socio-economic background. As an artist I enjoy asking unanswerable_COMMA_ hypothetical or rhetoric questions. Questions where multiple answers would be fitting.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I am a natural creative. Since I was a kid I have been fascinated with playing with materials and drawing. I take great joy in the sense of accomplishment and confidence that I get from making and seeing my ideas come into fruition. it was in my teens that I took on the identity as an artist. Since then I have been working with clay making functional pottery that feels like it has purpose in the world. i also work with wood and make mixed media paintings and collages. I find that i feel most comfortable in the company of other creative people. When friends and i collaborate we form strong bonds and are able to prosper in a special way. I sincerely hope that the activity of making art_COMMA_ which brings me so much joy_COMMA_ can also serve others and be positive and useful contribution to the world.
column14: I find that though one person can accomplish much on his or her own_COMMA_ it is almost incomparable to the abilities of a group working together. While I push myself in my own mediums and ideas_COMMA_ time and maturity has taught me that an individual is always susceptible to lack of foresight and tunnel vision. Others can always offer counter opinions and different perspectives. Not to mention that others will be able to fill in the gaps of another's knowledge and skill set. With this in mind I actively pursue collaborators. Also the nature of working with materials small and large scale requires a crew like mentality. A hand is always needed for my work_COMMA_ and a hand is always ready to be lent for others.
column15: I would say that my recent work with clay forms that interact with plants would represent me as an artist fit for your program. I think this for two reasons in particular. First is that this work is very much derived from nature. Clay as a material is derived from the earth and conveys the beauty and chaotic order of the natural world. And the second reason pertains to their concepts_COMMA_ all of which deal with the artist working in unison with nature. One series of clay objects was four orbs that are cultivating succulents and presenting them in interesting ways. Another is a series of terrariums that bring bits of nature into an interior space and are presented stylistically as if the housed moss or plant had a unique personality. Another_COMMA_ is a sub-irrigated planter that waters plants through a cotton wick from a well below the soil. column17: I often contemplate issues of nature vs. nurture. I think about what can be said of our true selves. Is it something that lies in our instincts that we are born with? are the values and practices that are cultured within us derived from truth or are they deviations from such? are we moving towards disharmony with nature? or are we functioning in our own natural fashion even if it is expressed destructively or in a synthetic way? A course on reconstructing wildness reads to me as a course in getting in touch with one's primitive roots. I feel that I attempt this in my own work. Being immersed in an environment that is conducive to this process_COMMA_ with others who are looking to do the same_COMMA_ will bring us closer to understanding these issues.

column13: I live in Hamilton_COMMA_ Ontario_COMMA_ Canada_COMMA_ with my wife_COMMA_ our daughter and dog. I make sound_COMMA_ sculptural and musical artworks. In addition to being an artist_COMMA_ I work as a librarian. For as long as I can remember_COMMA_ I have always wanted to be an artist. My father was a hobby painter. I grew up in a semi-rural small town in Ontario Canada. Being outside and close to nature has always been important to me. I like camping and hiking. I also like cooking_COMMA_ traveling_COMMA_ drinking beer in pubs_COMMA_ drinking wine at friend's places_COMMA_ drinking coffee in cafes_COMMA_ watching movies with my wife_COMMA_ going for walks with my daughter_COMMA_ walking my dog_COMMA_ reading_COMMA_ listening to music_COMMA_ listening to music loud in my living room and dancing with my wife and daughter (the dog doesn't understand dancing). I like all kinds of music. I like all kinds of art. I think art and music are of the greatest and most hopeful things that people can do_COMMA_ which is why I keep doing it.
column14: I have been involved with a few collaborative projects_COMMA_ particularly with making music. I find collaborative experiences to be very generative and rewarding. The more sculptural work that I am doing now is not highly collaborative but there are elements: I prefer to work in an group/social studio space and have colleagues around to discuss ideas_COMMA_ art and the world around us. I find my ideas develop when I've been talking about them. When I am working on a major project_COMMA_ I likewise prefer to have people around me to give input (and a helping hand) and this always ends up influencing the art I make. I do have one fully collaborative project that I am involved with currently_COMMA_ which is an extension of a project started ten years ago. A friend and I started making noise-music together with a freeform_COMMA_ totally improvised_COMMA_ process driven approach. Back then we were next door neighbours_COMMA_ now we live on different continents and the project is based on trying to maintain this improvised approach through technology.
column15: The Pink Glass Swans was the noise band that I started with a friend mentioned above. Our goal was to work within a very minimal framework to allow for_COMMA_ as much as possible_COMMA_ a totally free-improvised sound at the borders of noise and music. This was achieved through an agreed upon process_COMMA_ which had the effect of stopping any discussion of what we were making and to focus only making in the moment and only communicating through making. The framework was represented by the situation: a medium sized room containing a robust array of sound intoning objects and amplifying devices ranging from the conventional (guitars)_COMMA_ the novel (kids toys)_COMMA_ the quotidian (pots and pans)_COMMA_ and the specialized (electronic effects processors); a routine- meeting every week at around the same time for about the same amount of time; and a way of documenting (usually a cassette recorder). The process followed a set of “rules”: anyone can make this music_COMMA_ any object that can be used to make sound can be used_COMMA_ nothing is decided beforehand_COMMA_ listen and respond to what you hear_COMMA_ and play it loud. We invited people to joins us_COMMA_ some regulars others only once or twice_COMMA_ and what happened was everyone present just started_COMMA_ either clapping or strumming or banging or turning on and off a radio and then for the next few hours the sound would build in waves as patterns developed and dissolved_COMMA_ and as people freely moved around the room picking something up or plugging something in and playing it until something urged them to change. The recording was an important part of the “noise jam” and often we would listen to the entire recording right away in order to reflect on what was made. At the time of this project I was influenced by free jazz_COMMA_ and in particular the political ideals of anarchy and freedom embodied in the music_COMMA_ and also the spiritual aspects of the music. The Pink Glass Swans project was for me one of the most influential artmaking experiences of my life. http://www.last.fm/music/Pink+Glass+Swans
column16: As part of travelling_COMMA_ my wife and I have volunteered on farms (through the WWOOF organization). One such experience in Italy had about ten of us living together in one barn/loft_COMMA_ eating large communal meals and working together in the fields. We were there for two weeks. It was all organized by the host so we didn't have to plan much_COMMA_ just how to be together. We had a wonderful time. I also think of sharing studio space as a type of communal living_COMMA_ which I have been doing on and off for ten years or so.
column17: I do not know how the hike will aid my artistic development_COMMA_ which is why I like the idea. I do know that I find it productive to walk and think_COMMA_ also I find it beneficial to go and come back. I like the doing aspect of this hike- planning_COMMA_ traveling_COMMA_ walking_COMMA_ talking_COMMA_ meeting new people- a departure_COMMA_ which at this time is something I am seeking_COMMA_ but not just any trip_COMMA_ I am seeking something which brings a dedicated focus to thinking about my art practice and discussing/experiencing it with other likeminded seekers in hopes of finding something new_COMMA_ something yet unthought of. I will bring a portable audio recorder with me and these recordings could potentially be the basis of a new artwork._NEWLINE_Reconstructing Wildness has a similar appeal_COMMA_ however I'm imagining this departure will lead to a very different part of the woods. Part of my attraction to noise is the wildness of it; the way you can submerge yourself in it_COMMA_ lose yourself in it. This is a rare experience. I am very interested in exploring self-transcendence in different ways and connecting it to ideas of wildness is very intriguing. Religious experience and expression has been a long time interest of mine and I have been recently been thinking about transcendence_COMMA_ especially in relation to religious practices which focus on mind-body-self connection. I have experimented with meditation_COMMA_ yoga and chakra opening to limited degrees_COMMA_ as I always find a disconnect between these established practices and the modern world. The complexity and contradiction of seeking spirituality within modernity has recently been influencing my art. I think there is a connection with this line of thinking and the direction proposed for Reconstructing Wildness.
column18: Following R. Murray Schafer_COMMA_ who developed many of the ideas of what is known as acoustic ecology_COMMA_ I will lead a workshop on structured listening. This will involve a brief talk on acoustic ecology_COMMA_ reading a bit of Schafer's writing and then proceeding as a group to follow some of the listening exercises designed by him. The most well known of Schafer's exercise is the sound walk_COMMA_ which is a focused listening of an environment experienced by moving through it_COMMA_ and is often followed up with a discussion of what was heard.
column19: I envision a SMT session in immersive sound and listening. One aspect would be noise making- setting up a situation for free improvisation with musical instruments and other sound making devices and amplifiers and microphones. Also listening workshops like sound walks_COMMA_ as described above. Another aspect could be something influenced by sound therapy and how sound vibration is used in healing- creating immersive sound environments/situations for the purpose of immersive listening_COMMA_ but also to work with participant's practices_COMMA_ such as creating sound for a performance_COMMA_ or sound to go with painting.

column13: I'm a queer art lady_COMMA_ who is pretty into comics_COMMA_ storytelling_COMMA_ mythology and fantasy. I'm a lovable Leo sign_COMMA_ who is loyal and respectful. column14: I have been doing various media projects with queer folks: coordinating the Slippery Slope Cabaret_COMMA_ hosting a radio show/ interviewing trans*artists and activists_COMMA_ and engaging in the youtube community. Interacting with people and having meaningful conversation inspires my practice as a writer and thinker. _NEWLINE_Of course_COMMA_ my social interactions can also be full of hilarious misunderstandings or micro-aggressions that are just as inspiring to my art and thinking. column15: http://morgansea.wordpress.com/performance-work/super-powers-the-slide-show/_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It’s a piece that talks about my trans experience and queer politics with the question_COMMA_ “Which super power would you choose and why?” It gets pretty funny as_COMMA_ during the performance_COMMA_ I have a sort of existential crisis trying to find out if I am more into Shapeshifting or Telepathy. With shapeshifting_COMMA_ I could be as visually appealing as I wanted to be_COMMA_ gain various degrees of privilege_COMMA_ and explore amazing possibilities with a super-fluid queer body. With telepathy_COMMA_ I could change people’s minds and subtly shift their social-political views with persuasive comments that cater to their subconscious. However_COMMA_ could I trust myself not to straight up re-write their brain? What are the consent issues involved in telepathy? Which would I choose now? I still don’t know. Scratch that_COMMA_ shapeshifting_COMMA_ totally.
column16: I attended SMT in 2012. I really enjoyed the cooking_COMMA_ the conversation_COMMA_ and the creative peoples. I’ve also lived with a lot of roommates and generally aim to please within a communal space.
column17: Session B_COMMA_ Unthinking/Unknowing sounds really good to me. The physicality of the Bourque's class sounds like a good way to break from my urban habitual laze and enter the space with an active body and mind._NEWLINE_The unthinkable makes me think concepts or ideas that have become unspeakable_COMMA_ removed from societies lexicon. This seems like a good thing to meditate on an add to my queer theory toolkit in my ongoing battle with hegemonic oppression! _NEWLINE_I'm excited to explore Deleuzian concepts and think Bourque's background experience teaching contemporary mythology would benefit my own practice which often queers ancient mythology_COMMA_ archetypes_COMMA_ and contemporary mythology.
column19: I would like to make a series of short videos or photographic essays exploring the hierarchy of Daedalus and the Minotaur . (Daedalus the greek mythological inventor not only built the apparatus for the Cretian Queen to mate with a bull_COMMA_ he also designed the Labyrinth that the beast man would spend his life in. Additionally supplying a special thread that would help Theseus navigate the Labyrinth and kill the Minotaur once and forall.) My vision would see the Minotaur set free in the Catskills. Daedalus and his son Icarus performing a wax dripped S&M practice. And giving unlimited funding_COMMA_ the creation of a stone maze for meditation.
column20: What does this open-ended question remind you of?_NEWLINE_I’m standing soaking wet in front of a store clerk in Williamsburg. She thinks I should be embarrassed_COMMA_ and I am but only because there’s no easy way to explain that I feel great._NEWLINE_It’s hard to explain in a couple sentences how two weeks in the catskills had affected me. How in touch with my body and nature I felt_COMMA_ only to feel the violent contrast on a nauseating bus ride back to NYC. I was worried that connection was gone_COMMA_ but a 6 block walk in a warm thunderstorm felt fantastic and reminds me of a feelings I still can't describe.

column13: I am a contradicting_COMMA_ well behaved_COMMA_ adventurous_COMMA_ uncertain_COMMA_ brief_COMMA_ efficient_COMMA_ un-hierarchical_COMMA_ chance-loving_COMMA_ unarticulated_COMMA_ optimistic_COMMA_ designer_COMMA_ dabbler_COMMA_ artist_COMMA_ jokester_COMMA_ service industry worker_COMMA_ non-theatrical performer_COMMA_ Minneapolis College of Art and Design graduate and list maker based in Portland_COMMA_ Oregon.
column14: My work is not bound by medium_COMMA_ but by method. I work within boundaries based on a conceptual logic_COMMA_ submitting to patterns and structures that exist naturally. I search for and collect connections and contradictions. I misuse materials and re-appropriate objects. I engage in futile gestures to provoke confusion_COMMA_ seeking out the awareness that occurs through redundancy and subverted functionality. I question when and where art really exists. I collaborate with groups of people as an instigator and facilitator. I challenge cliches and play games with words. I build the box and ask for others to step out of it.
column15: One of my most recent artistic endeavors has been teaching. Last summer I taught a process and idea generation class for 9 to 12 year olds at the Rochester Art Center in Minnesota. While the class at the RAC was for young students_COMMA_ the projects and class structure are similar to activities that I would like to facilitate with adults. I like to act as an amateur teacher_COMMA_ a teacher that knows less than the students. I pose questions with no answers and instigate conversation. The project at the RAC examined a playful logic and encouraged students to draw conclusions and make connections between seemingly unlike things_COMMA_ while working within a given set of restrictions. _NEWLINE_My curating project_COMMA_ POWERPOINT_COMMA_ also represents my system of working within a set of invented boundaries. For this exhibition I solicited works by artists and non-artists created using only PowerPoint. The show resulted in a collection of 2D images_COMMA_ animations_COMMA_ slide shows_COMMA_ sculptures and books. The boundaries set by the program brought limitations that_COMMA_ through operation_COMMA_ provoked a consciousness of the making process and ultimately dictated the product.
column16: Aside from living with roommates throughout college_COMMA_ I have attended summer camp_COMMA_ worked as a summer camp counselor_COMMA_ and volunteered on farms_COMMA_ all of which I was living with and sharing space with others. The most communal living experience I have had was volunteering on farms in Minnesota_COMMA_ Holland and Belgium_COMMA_ where I contributed daily to the homestead by cooking_COMMA_ cleaning_COMMA_ building_COMMA_ and working in the gardens and fields along the other volunteers and farmers.
column17: I believe the collaborative and kinetic nature of the School of Making and Thinking would have an extremely positive impact on my practice. Summit on a Summit_COMMA_ specifically_COMMA_ would be a beautiful opportunity to challenge myself physically_COMMA_ observe myself _COMMA_ learn from others and escape my everyday. On the hike_COMMA_ I would hope to challenge my improvisation skills_COMMA_ and focus on becoming more aware of the moments that I enter a most thoughtful state of mind.
column18: Making Assumptions & Drawing Conclusions Workshop:_NEWLINE_We will each choose a random object found in nature. These objects will become our readymades for which we would generate a title and artist statement/manifesto/description/poem. Based only on what we can glean from the found object we will assign it meaning and determine it's function as an art object. Our tools would be signs and symbols_COMMA_ metaphors and analogies. We would conclude the workshop with a presentation and conversation about the works.
column19: I would like to do a series of small interventions_COMMA_ experiments and exercises with others and by myself that respond to and question the environment. I am unsure if this would result in a "final product" or if it would exist as a continuous performance of sorts. My project would hopefully represent the group as a whole and the individuals within.
column20: Q: Is this art? _NEWLINE_A: I don't know.

column13: Born and raised in Montreal_COMMA_ I am presently completing a Master of Fine Arts at the School for Contemporary Arts_COMMA_ Simon Fraser University_COMMA_ in Vancouver. Prior to undertaking my MFA_COMMA_ I completed an MA at the Centre for Drama_COMMA_ theatre and Performance Studies_COMMA_ University of Toronto_COMMA_ in 2012. My research and creative practice explores identity and belonging_COMMA_ juggling with my experience as an interdisciplinary artist/researcher/human being in an increasingly homogenized society. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The focus of my artistic practice lies in willess acts of self-affirmation around space (public and private)_COMMA_ time_COMMA_ and identity. I am interested in revisiting place by reconfiguring our conception and use of space in the everyday through scored and task-oriented actions. The body becomes the site for my exploration_COMMA_ while repetition_COMMA_ endurance and resistance test the physical and emotional boundaries of my corporeal matter. Working at the edges of discomfort and vulnerability_COMMA_ I continuously re-evaluate the threshold of my body as it breaks down and rebuilds to become a site for change and exchange. I perform the friction of skin against architecture and nature. My hope is to generate knowledge through acts that most have discarded as unfeasible_COMMA_ unthinkable_COMMA_ and absurd. Embodying text and challenging language are fundamental to addressing identity and posing critical perspectives on authority._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am a long distance runner and I am a lover of the outdoors. When not focusing on my research and practice_COMMA_ I enjoy all types of physical activity and exertion. Throughout my life I have actively participated in team sports since they fulfill my need for exchange and community while practicing physical exercise. In the past three years_COMMA_ I have sought opportunities to bridge my practice/research with my enthusiasm for the outdoors through play and collaborative endeavors in mobile residencies. I enjoy combining my academic background and intellectual capacities with the practicalities of everyday living – to take part in the communal exchange of experience and idea based activities.
column14: My creative/intellectual practice is in constant oscillation between spaces of extensive collaboration and focused individual isolation. Collaboration allows me to explore and expand my practice beyond its natural scope. As an artist and thinker_COMMA_ I recognize my intellectual and physical limitations and in doing so actively seek others to help me develop new methods of information creation. Within a collaborative exchange_COMMA_ I find ways to immerse myself in environments (be it urban or rural) that would be otherwise entirely foreign to me._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My interests lie in collaboration as a means of emergence – allowing group dynamics within a variety of settings to inform_COMMA_ transform and guide my practice and that of others. I believe in cohabitation as a means of furthering knowledge in a project_COMMA_ of letting time unfurl as dynamic practice-based encounters reveal new patterns in the bodies and minds of each collaborator. I am interested in the idea of community building in order to transport the encounters beyond their initial framework. My process is about sharing – creating rhyzomatic matrixes of connections and experiences with other bodies in space. In order to do so_COMMA_ I open up my projects to the greater public_COMMA_ inviting them to contribute_COMMA_ challenge_COMMA_ and transform its course according to their own life experience. I enter every project in anticipation that it will somehow_COMMA_ at some point_COMMA_ leave my hands to become molded by the minds of others._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I must also acknowledge that there are times when the collaborative act becomes one of tension in my work. In these times_COMMA_ when ideas collide and actions oppose_COMMA_ I find myself to be the most amazed at what can emerge from individuals not meshing. The balance between my own practice and others begins to blur in these instances_COMMA_ and so we begin an important process of negotiation and communication.
column15: In SHUTTLE (Summer 2013) I joined a group of international artists_COMMA_ designers_COMMA_ performance makers and researchers in a journey through the deserts of the American south-west performing an exploration of the aesthetic_COMMA_ political_COMMA_ cultural and environmental resonances of desert ecologies. As a temporary travelling community_COMMA_ our interests were in movement_COMMA_ environment_COMMA_ and performance. Our work consisted of generating new creative practices and works that shuttled between registers of the known and unknown by exploring performances of mobility. Journeying through seminal land arts works_COMMA_ ancient settlements_COMMA_ desert conditions_COMMA_ and spaces of transit_COMMA_ we performed daily actions creating ephemeral conditions and generating encounters. Our experience took us through an initial and closing event in Tucson_COMMA_ Arizona_COMMA_ and a five-day performance at Performance Studies International (Psi 19) conference at Stanford University in Paolo Alto. We travelled close to four thousand miles from Tucson and back in a white Chevrolet van moving through the Sonoran_COMMA_ Great Basin and Mojave Deserts._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_SHUTTLE explored notions of creative and everyday cohabitation that have prepared and made me seek out more collaborative laboratories that allow for an intense and condensed period of exchange to occur. The constant process of negotiation between each individual of the group_COMMA_ the attempts and desire to fulfill both collective and personal goals_COMMA_ as well as the commitment to each other to hold a communal practice shared by all made for an intense environment of mobile performance and dialogue. The final product of the project was part collaborative and part individual. However_COMMA_ a clear overlap and strong influence occurred between the participants pushing the boundaries of each other’s work in different directions.
column16: During the summer of 2013_COMMA_ I spent two months at Nes Artist Residency in Skagastrond_COMMA_ Iceland. During this time_COMMA_ I shared a family-sized home with three people. Spending most of our days in this space_COMMA_ our group developed a strong relationship with each other that manifested itself through cooking_COMMA_ eating_COMMA_ working_COMMA_ and playing together. Each night of the week a different member of the household cooked a meal_COMMA_ with the rest of the group contributing to its preparation. We used this time to exchange ideas about work and more importantly to discover things about the other people. In the evening_COMMA_ we often played games_COMMA_ usually suggested and organized by a different person each night. These served not only to strengthen our bond as a group of artists living together_COMMA_ but also contributed to the works being created during the daytime. We also began exploring notions of collaboration together. Although nothing complete transpired_COMMA_ our exchanges provided fertile ground for creative stimulation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In SHUTTLE_COMMA_ every aspect of the trip revolved around communal living. The group slowly began to work as a well-oiled machine as tasks and responsibilities became divided within the group. Many have remarked since the end of the trip that the act of everyday living (communally) was the very essence of the collaboration.
column17: My interest in applying to the hike this summer stems from a desire to return and continue exploring notions of mobile collaboration and performance within a natural setting. As a city dweller_COMMA_ I find it necessary to regain contact with nature whenever I can. This challenges my practice and thinking to move out of its habitual relationship to the spatial structure of the urban context and to adapt itself to a different setting. My daily practice often relies on the concrete structures that I dwell and evolve in. These formations become points for me to anchor my physical actions and critical thinking. Outside of the city_COMMA_ living of a packsack and subjected to the power of nature_COMMA_ I develop new and different perspectives and physical actions that would not manifest themselves otherwise. My hope is to break with the monotonous and cyclical behaviour of urban living by immersing myself in a natural context where thinking and doing manifest themselves differently and out of necessity._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am also hoping that the hike_COMMA_ in its collaborative and cohabitation structure_COMMA_ will aid in developing my individual practice and give way to a collective bond. My desire is to take part in a community experience that will expand beyond the session – to make contacts and relationships that will begin to inform further exchanges. As an artist who works through a critical embodiment of space and place my work will inevitably become shaped by the minds and anatomies of those who will participate in the hike. Hopefully_COMMA_ I can bring others into my process and lend myself to theirs in order to develop a dialogue._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The hike_COMMA_ in its relationship to the Central Catskills offers a chance to explore a geographical region that I have grown up driving through and had little firsthand contact with. My hope is to engage the region as a thinker_COMMA_ creator_COMMA_ and human being in order to become more knowledgeable about its ecological structure and habitat.
column18: The workshop I would most likely want to lead during the hike revolves around a series of actions that I have recently developed with an at-risk high school youth group. The workshops reflect on notions of collective walks as spaces of potential insurrection and change. In their current form_COMMA_ they combine immersive lectures and workshops_COMMA_ drawing from art history_COMMA_ popular culture_COMMA_ an embodied practice_COMMA_ and notions of play._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The proposed work involves bringing members of the hike together with a one-meter rope. A direct reference to Linda Montano and Tehching Hsieh’s One Year Performance 1983-1984 (Rope Piece) where the two artists tied themselves with a one-meter rope for an entire year. The workshop explores the physical and psychological manifestation of ‘being tied or roped’ together. What emerges is an interesting collective effort as individuals negotiate being bound together and fulfilling certain tasks/needs in their immediate environment. The workshop would also include a lecture portion where historical precedents for this type of bondage is exhibited_COMMA_ therefore furthering the intellectual exercise of understanding the act being performed. I would anticipate beginning the workshop with groups of two being bound_COMMA_ and slowly work our way until the whole group is tied together thus forming a collective body. The performative actions and thinking that would develop would inevitably be linked to the natural environment we evolve in. The workshop would take this setting into consideration and adapt to the space in order to connect gestures and actions back to the site.
column20: How does it feel to ascribe to a ‘global’ art system? A striking issue in applying for international residencies is that the mode of life that has developed around them is one of privilege. The 21st century ‘mobility’ of the artist figure is an issue that I am interested in_COMMA_ and struggle with regularly. As a Canadian and son of two professionals_COMMA_ I am aware that the movement I follow is in great part a product of my socio-economic standing rather than a sign of a ‘true’ democratic global art system whereby artists can travel freely and participate in residencies. It is this sense of unease in mobility that brings me to ground myself_COMMA_ to look for self-aware communities of artists who recognize their local environment and respect it.

column13: I am a female watercolorist who paints flowers_COMMA_ trees_COMMA_ cats_COMMA_ and moons. While I hate the way that sounds_COMMA_ I like the way it looks. By both honoring and critiquing work of this nature_COMMA_ I make comments on the tradition of “Sunday Afternoon Painters”. My subject matter can be read as sentimental_COMMA_ but I see it as a recording of time. The sun is setting_COMMA_ the moon is moving_COMMA_ and the flowers are dying. How one brush stroke leads to the next is more important to me that the subject matter—the subject matter is just the vehicle to get me from point A to point B. For me_COMMA_ it all comes back to paint on paper. In a current series of paintings_COMMA_ the circle in the form of the moon_COMMA_ sun_COMMA_ streetlights_COMMA_ and balloons formally ties the work together. My work involves a vigorous studio practice_COMMA_ painting everyday. At times_COMMA_ I paint outdoors in plein air on hikes and back packing trips. At night_COMMA_ I paint in my car utilizing my moon roof to capture the night sky. I am trying to reach nature from an unnatural place. My work is a recording of the suburban landscape. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_On a less formal note_COMMA_ I am a navy brat who has lived in more houses than years I have been alive. I have a one-eyed dog and two cats. Currently_COMMA_ I am finishing up my last semester of grad school in sunny and humid Tampa_COMMA_ Florida_COMMA_ looking ahead to the next adventure.
column14: While I still love the romanticized vision of the artist alone in their studio_COMMA_ for me_COMMA_ it’s not a realistic one. My creative practice is collaborative mostly in the sense that I depend on an audience for critique and feedback on an idea or a body of work in progress. I find discussing the ends and outs of particular idea helpful for my own process. In order for my work to be effective I want to find out what is working both visually and conceptually. A collaborative audience provides that valuable feedback to aid in making my creative process stronger. Having been in graduate school for the past three years_COMMA_ I have received this collaboration though the institution of academia. Now that I am leaving academia_COMMA_ I want to search out this richness in conversation from new sources. In addition_COMMA_ I also collaborate within an artist collective called EyeSplice_COMMA_ featuring twelve artists around the country and South America. Together we have formed a network to exhibit together_COMMA_ provide critiques_COMMA_ and work on our professional development. We have upcoming shows in Long Island City_COMMA_ NY and Tampa_COMMA_ FL. Working with this group provides me with support and accountability. We hold each other up to certain standards and look out for opportunities that would benefit one another or the whole group. Again_COMMA_ while the lone artist may be a romantic vision_COMMA_ it’s an impractical one. As artists/thinkers supporting one another leads to richer work and lives.

column16: While most nights were not spent sleeping there_COMMA_ I feel my graduate school studio provided one of my many communal living experiences. When you’re spending an average of eight or more hours a day in a shared space_COMMA_ it becomes a community_COMMA_ or at least it should. Luckily for me_COMMA_ my experience led to a wonderful exchange of ideas_COMMA_ supplies and support. When I needed advice_COMMA_ someone was usually there to take a look at a piece or bounce an idea off of. When I ran out of something_COMMA_ there was a chance someone had some more. Most importantly_COMMA_ in the moments I doubted myself_COMMA_ one of my colleagues provided with me with support to keep me going. I was also there to provide the same for my studio mates. While the studio wasn’t my actual home_COMMA_ the sense of community there made it feel like one.
column17: The theme of this course is what first brought me to apply to The School of Making Thinking. Recently_COMMA_ I had a discussion with my mentor and professor Elisabeth Condon about my work’s approach to the natural through the unnatural. Like the Tonalist before me_COMMA_ my work is in part a reaction to the industrialization and suburbanization of the natural world. In a way_COMMA_ my work is a survey of the suburban landscape. Part of my reasoning for painting outdoors in natural spaces allows me an attempt at connecting with the natural world and recording this attempt with paint on paper. However_COMMA_ unlike the Tonalist_COMMA_ there is an unnatural quality to my work_COMMA_ too far removed from the natural state. This is why I am interested in exploring whether or not it’s possible to reconnect with The Wild.

column20: What the best thing you’ve ever won?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_When I was in the sixth grade_COMMA_ we lived in Hawaii in military housing. My parents kept making jokes and reciting Beatles lyrics in the weeks between winning and going. I got to see an octopus crawling along the ocean floor. It’s one of my most vivid memories.

column17: I have always been interested in meditation_COMMA_ ever since my dad taught me to meditate at an early age. column19: I am interested in experimenting with an artistic process that merges writing and creating with personal ritual and spirituality. I'd maybe even hope to stage scenes from this writing with other people at SMT to feel out how they work_COMMA_ and whether a ritualistic writing process might yield a different performance process for an actor/collaborator.

column13: Since graduating from university in 2011_COMMA_ I’ve been trying to re-learn how to make art like I did before I had a degree in Art. I don’t want to unlearn what I learned in school_COMMA_ because much of it was valuable to my intellectual development and creative practice. Rather_COMMA_ I’m trying to re-inhabit the state of inhibition that I remember occupying before all of the high concept and theory. In my ideal state_COMMA_ I’m able to create in a way that is unencumbered and fluid_COMMA_ and my creative mind is in constant dialogue (verging on unified) with my critical mind. Much of what I internalized about artistic discipline through higher education has formed an obstacle to the act of creation. Bit by bit_COMMA_ I am disintegrating that obstacle and allowing myself to play_COMMA_ enjoy not knowing_COMMA_ and let go of outcome expectations._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In order to achieve equilibrium_COMMA_ the next big step in my life is to find the right physical place and space to occupy and call home. This is essential. At the moment_COMMA_ I feel like I’m drifting through the sea_COMMA_ not in a huge hurry_COMMA_ not exactly sure where I’m headed_COMMA_ only certain that I’m going wash up onto the shore somewhere new. Over the past few years I’ve split my time between the Bay Area of California and the Research Triangle of North Carolina. In a couple of days_COMMA_ I depart for Iceland for a two-month residency in Reykjavík. When I return_COMMA_ the next move I make will be to my new home_COMMA_ and I’m excited about that. I just need to figure out where it will be. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Rather than a biographic summary_COMMA_ this is me now_COMMA_ putting one foot in front of the other until I arrive.
column14: Conceptually_COMMA_ I consider all creative and intellectual work to be collaborative. Whether drawing_COMMA_ performing live_COMMA_ or writing a research paper_COMMA_ each expression is influenced and by all of the things I have learned_COMMA_ read_COMMA_ seen_COMMA_ heard_COMMA_ discussed_COMMA_ felt_COMMA_ and understood prior to the moment of expression. Any artist is in a collaborative relationship with the world around them at all times_COMMA_ and this relationship includes current events_COMMA_ media_COMMA_ trends in art_COMMA_ peers_COMMA_ creative partners_COMMA_ professional expectations_COMMA_ financial obligations_COMMA_ available materials_COMMA_ available work space_COMMA_ etc. Not only are the ideas that I have a result of my collaboration with the world around me_COMMA_ but the way my ideas manifest (and even which ideas I am able to manifest) depends greatly on who I am_COMMA_ what I have to work with_COMMA_ where I am_COMMA_ and when I’m doing it. I depend on collaboration at every moment. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Actually_COMMA_ I collaborate with many peer artists. I view my network of fellow creatives as a resource for mutual support and growth. Since 2009_COMMA_ I have been working with a group called The Performance Collective_COMMA_ which I helped found in Chapel Hill_COMMA_ NC during my time as an undergraduate. Our work is original_COMMA_ devised_COMMA_ experimental performance_COMMA_ which we develop through a process of ideation based on sharing_COMMA_ exchange_COMMA_ and improvisation. It is in this process that I developed not only the capacity to work with other artists_COMMA_ but the ability drop my focus on authorship_COMMA_ say yes_COMMA_ and co-create. This experience has undoubtedly been a benefit across the board in my life. Besides TPC_COMMA_ I have done collaborative projects_COMMA_ from building renovations to essays_COMMA_ with many groups_COMMA_ including Rock Paper Scissors Collective (Oakland)_COMMA_ Signify Sanctify Believe! (LA)_COMMA_ the Xhurch (Portland)_COMMA_ Girltown (multi-city)_COMMA_ The Queer Explorer’s Club (NYC / Greensboro_COMMA_ NC)_COMMA_ Queerlab (Greensboro_COMMA_ NC) and Elsewhere (Greensboro_COMMA_ NC).
column15: The 2012/2013 project I created with The Performance Collective members Brian Hicks and Larissa Kaul called “(YOU YOURSELF WE WE ARE ARE WE) EVEN HERE <?” was all about asking and answering questions related to gender_COMMA_ identity_COMMA_ and performance. We began with a set of questions about queerness and art and knew we wanted to turn the exploration of these questions into a performance. Over the course of three months_COMMA_ we did writing exercises_COMMA_ improvisational movement research_COMMA_ had many discussions_COMMA_ and turned our thoughts into images_COMMA_ sequences_COMMA_ and eventually a show. Not every project I do takes the form of an hour-long performance_COMMA_ but the process tends to be similar_COMMA_ starting with questions and using whatever media I am focusing on to express my thoughts_COMMA_ answers_COMMA_ and sometimes even the questions themselves. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I like to make art that is political_COMMA_ but not polemical. I imagine that the best thing a piece of (political) art can do is confuse someone who thinks they already know the answer. Art can / should ask questions and start / participate in conversations. I try to use creative processes and critical research processes interchangeably_COMMA_ so that art projects become an educational experiment. Each project is ultimately about learning something or at least understanding it better than when I started. I believe that this approach is very much in line with SMT’s pursuit to_COMMA_ “expand traditional notion[s] of thinking.” Academia encourages you to have a thesis that you can support with other people’s previous work or a hypothesis that you seek to prove. This approach can be valuable_COMMA_ but when you’re looking for something specific_COMMA_ you’re likely to miss other things that are there. The practice I have described is more of an attempt to travel through questions without a destination in mind.
column16: As an undergraduate_COMMA_ I was part of a co-ed literary and arts society called St. Anthony Hall. We had a house_COMMA_ which was a residence for (give or take) seven people_COMMA_ but a part-time home for anywhere between twenty and thirty. I lived there for a little over two years. Luckily_COMMA_ it was an overall positive experience_COMMA_ but it was full of challenges_COMMA_ compromises_COMMA_ and lessons. In addition to simply sharing space_COMMA_ we coordinated regular chapter meals_COMMA_ shared cleaning responsibilities_COMMA_ and undertook projects on campus and in the community together. In hindsight_COMMA_ I’m always proud of how well we organized it all_COMMA_ even if it was chaotic on the surface. As a member of The Hall (as we called it) I learned that clear communication and a constructive_COMMA_ cooperative attitude are essential to the mental health of everyone involved. I have numerous friends who have had negative communal living experiences_COMMA_ both in coops and normal multi-roommate houses. In all of these situations a lack of communication and/or bad attitudes were the culprit(s). We had some rough times at The Hall_COMMA_ but we did a great job of trusting and supporting each other while identifying the problems and dealing with them.
column17: I’m drawn to “Unthinking / Unknowing” because_COMMA_ as I began to explain in my “About Me” section_COMMA_ I am currently in the process of undoing certain aspects of my higher education training in an attempt to re-learn ways I was working creatively before then. The idea that_COMMA_ “Thinking is always something that happens when we are least prepared_COMMA_ unexpecting_COMMA_ unknowing_COMMA_” resonates with me deeply. This is something that I do my best to lean into in my artistic practice. The content of this session is related to conceptual interests of mine (especially Deleuze and also the work of Paolo Friere) and will use methods I am comfortable with and greatly enjoy (especially physical and meditation practices). I am excited about the combination of physical_COMMA_ textual_COMMA_ and internal approaches described in the session information_COMMA_ because it seems to parallel the type of process that I have undertaken in the development of prior work_COMMA_ especially performance. This is a unique opportunity to engage in this type of process with a group of completely new people and without the purpose of creating a performance at the end of it all. What else could come out of this work? I am eager to find out! As I said in the above section_COMMA_ when we are looking for a specific outcome_COMMA_ we miss other possibilities. In lieu of working towards a performance_COMMA_ there is great potential for something I have not even imagined to manifest_COMMA_ which is very exciting to me. Finally_COMMA_ from what I have read about SMT_COMMA_ the exchange between / among “teachers” and “students” seems to be much more symbiotic than in a traditional learning environment. I feel like this is a session that I will not only benefit from attending_COMMA_ but to which I will be able to make meaningful contribution.

column19: At SMT I would challenge myself to do something outside of_COMMA_ or at least not primarily focused in_COMMA_ my normal repertoire_COMMA_ which would be some sort of devised or improvised performance_COMMA_ probably involving a video or other visual art element. column13: I woke up dreaming of the next world and then I went to sleep and dreamed of the world that came after that. Then satellites lowered by degrees and I used them to look through a building. Then I woke. Then I fell asleep again. Then I found myself in a place I didn't know_COMMA_ in the bottom of a building near the boiler_COMMA_ with people who didn't belong to me. Then I belonged to them. Then I looked through the eyes of a satellite. Then I looked through the eyes of a CTV. Then I looked through someone's cell phone. I also remember a train: a train carting satellites to a satellite graveyard. I remember salvaging them and launching them back into orbit. One day_COMMA_ seeing through a satellite will be as common as looking through a camera. One day_COMMA_ seeing through someone else's eyes will be as simple as making a phone call. One day_COMMA_ I decided I could not be invisible_COMMA_ so I would have to plug myself in_COMMA_ as deep as it is possible. At a certain point_COMMA_ I thought I was becoming something ancient_COMMA_ like a figure repeated across paintings in a museum_COMMA_ marching across epochs_COMMA_ but actually_COMMA_ I was only becoming a machine. I installed a series of LEDS beneath my skin and walked across the snow_COMMA_ opening a security protocol_COMMA_ so people could use my body like lantern_COMMA_ or a marquee.

column15: Below is a link to a video project entitled_COMMA_ Dedication to this View. It is a 45-minute video that pieces together original and found footage to create a long_COMMA_ meditative work addressing themes of distance_COMMA_ concealment_COMMA_ sexuality and the act of viewing. Though theme was clear when I began the project_COMMA_ the process of taking and then editing the footage organic and highly institutive. This way of making is very different from other projects of mine that use structure and constraints in their process. The majority of the material was shot with an iPhone_COMMA_ at times entering into the realm of the diaristic and banal_COMMA_ producing a video that acknowledges the tool of its production. The video builds through a process of compilation and in its careful attention to rhythm and pattern_COMMA_ and attempts to push the banality of living in the world until its strangeness is exposed. The informal performances and occurrences of day-to-day life that are chronicled in the video are abutted by altered footage from historical film and performance art. Dedication of this View acts as representation of_COMMA_ and meditation on_COMMA_ the intersection between these considerations. As the video weaves together a series of sources_COMMA_ the subjectivity of the artist/performer/editor emerges as the constant and is continually projected into the frame of both original and found footage. This video and the process I engaged to produce it felt to me to be a process of unthinking_COMMA_ of allowing my daily life to bleed into my artistic life and vice versa. I was interested in breaking down and challenging the way I was ‘knowing’ and approaching my artistic practice while in graduate school. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_An excerpt: https://vimeo.com/52748764_NEWLINE_Full video (40 min long): https://vimeo.com/60756183
