column13: Circle All_NEWLINE_A. I am a tender loving persona and I love furry cats and skinny dogs. “stickers”_NEWLINE_B. I used to think I was different. Now I know I am interdisciplinary_NEWLINE_C. I'm >44 looking like <30 to those >25; for those <25 I am 'mam'_COMMA_ 'miss'_COMMA_ 'babe'. _NEWLINE_D.Syllogism_COMMA_ algorithm_COMMA_ and synesthesia: plural incarnation for one alter-ego>>> Consider this syllogism_COMMA_ "A house(1) that is not pricy(2) is rare(3). Something rare(3) is pricy(4). Therefore_COMMA_ a house(1) that is rare(3) is also pricy(4)." ~ my father. I hear music* when I hear/see algorithms and algebra. *My type of synesthesia is from numbers to music to colours and back. Breaking down numbers in single cells stops the music. 4 elements+3 sentences=a sequence of 1-2-3_COMMA_ 3-4_COMMA_ 1-3-4. Models repeat themselves; everything can be broken down into models; models cross AND bridge divides._NEWLINE_E. Wo zhu zai Bei Jing ba nian. I lived in Asia for a decade. This strongly influenced my art practice_COMMA_ structure of creation and diffusion_COMMA_ throw a few heartthrobs for codified dance and visceral performances_COMMA_ including hybrid taoist-populist funeral rites._NEWLINE_True or False_NEWLINE_1. homônumos magazine – founded by Christine Bellerose in Beijing – discourse by people who think for those who think_COMMA_ is a publication in 8 languages. (T)_NEWLINE_2. alter ego and performance art is like clowning (F. Clowns never succeed in the intent of their action.)_NEWLINE_3. Christine Bellerose is an interdisciplinary artist and researcher_COMMA_ specializing in movement performance art. She questions the subjects of memory_COMMA_ erotica_COMMA_ and the immaterial that link the performer_COMMA_ the alter ego_COMMA_ and the social body. (T)_NEWLINE_4. Christine Bellerose participated in M.A. Practice Based Research at Stanford and at Université du Québec à Rimouski...and it changed her life (F. PBR has been part of my methodology for a while now_COMMA_ I just didn't know 'it' had a name.)_NEWLINE_5. Entering 'Dalidada' – alter ego based on hybrid Butoh_COMMA_ Noh_COMMA_ and burlesque – is like summoning the spirits (F. There is a lot of incarnation of a foreign entity_COMMA_ but also a good share of bringing to life archetypes_COMMA_ living archives through somatic work_COMMA_ and more I shall discover and explore.)
column14: Links:_NEWLINE_@ https://vimeo.com/80681743_NEWLINE_@ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O35hTuhWZIM&list=UUadRt_oZOwPW0m_IKUDtNVw&feature=c4-overview_NEWLINE_@ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQcfEVYXIaA (0.00-1.50)_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In the recent years_COMMA_ my practice has grown more solitary while my research more collaborative. In a sense I am within the times if I think about shareware_COMMA_ and open-source. I think my R&D in groups_COMMA_ with artists coming from varied practice – UQAR with a group of 20 mature artists in the north of Quebec_COMMA_ MPA with 20 professional visual artists women in and around Montreal_COMMA_ PBR at Stanford (MOOC) with a chore group of 5 professionals_COMMA_ artists & engineers from 3 continents (where I met Michael Borowski_COMMA_ alumni STM student)_COMMA_ and RAIQ the Quebec group of interdisciplinary artists. At this time in my evolution as an artist_COMMA_ I am exploring the process of creation through my body as my principal media. Sharing ideas and process with other practicing artists and agents of change is my way of communal thinking and creating._NEWLINE_Prior to my solo exploration through alter ego Dalidada_COMMA_ I have and still remain with a pan-Canadian clown collective (Les Babines)_COMMA_ and curated and plan to reactivate in time Artist as Shaman_COMMA_ a multidisciplinary performances and installations exhibit mixing old and new technologies – the proposition to artists is to pair with an artist of a different field and while creating their own piece_COMMA_ feeding off of each other's process and present at the same time. “Under the Nose” (clown) was presented in Winnipeg during the 2011 Fringe festival and “Artist as Shaman” at Eastern Bloc during the Art Matters Festival 2012.
column15: Links: _NEWLINE_>>>https://twitter.com/MeiGuiHua/status/288997524885344256/photo/1_NEWLINE_>>>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S6CL3D2Qdcg_NEWLINE_>>>https://twitter.com/MeiGuiHua/status/439102281703636992/photo/1_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The most collaborative think-work I have fostered which continues to influence on my practice is homônumos_COMMA_ where a mix of artists and non-artists of many cultures discoursed on a theme. homônumos means 'all humans share one family'. Our mascot is 'siren' which is the 'one human with an idea' ( see Twitter image above) The foundation of homônumos was built on fostering a common sense of belonging_COMMA_ building on our differences such as it existed in the 8th century Alhambra_COMMA_ the sharing of philosophies_COMMA_ arts and science. I have been researching since my return in Montreal how to bring back homônumos presented as a digital open shareware._NEWLINE_My favourite articles are those I worked on with non artists because they led to a self discovery_COMMA_ repositioning of perspectives_COMMA_ and an opening to auto-determination for all parties. I asked a shop clerk I met at the Russian market to translate a bedtime story of her childhood into English. It turns out she spoke 4 languages with no common roots (Buryat_COMMA_ Russian_COMMA_ English_COMMA_ Mandarin)! I asked her to note when she had to think of a word in Russian or Mandarin. In this way_COMMA_ we mapped her language process. Another favourite article was written by Beijing local&in-the-closet queer tour-guide_COMMA_ reflecting on the dual street names of Guo da jie and Dongzhimenwai da jie albeit in a non historical discourse. And finally_COMMA_ blessed was our round table with Taoist priest in Dali Yunnan and German Protestant pastor in Beijing discoursing on infinity._NEWLINE_Co-directed as a pair_COMMA_ the team selected articles on commission_COMMA_ by people we met in Beijing_COMMA_ in our travels_COMMA_ and through our social network on the subjective basis of simply wanting to hear what a person had to say on a specific thematic. We further asked the contributors to express themselves in the language they thought of the idea so as to preserve the essence of the original thought. The note from the editor and the round table were translated in French_COMMA_ English_COMMA_ and Mandarin. homônumos topped 8 languages in one issue within its first year of publication. Distributed at 1000 units_COMMA_ we sold the magazine in Beijing_COMMA_ Thailand_COMMA_ Hong Kong_COMMA_ it was distributed in literature departments in USA_COMMA_ art galleries in France_COMMA_ sino-science as archive in Belgium' national library_COMMA_ and grassroot cafes in London_COMMA_ We infiltrated DIAF international art festival and are featured in their catalogue without ever having been invited_COMMA_ we self-funded 2 years of existence on print and in-situ performances. While being expelled from Beijing in 2008 in the midst of the Olympic corruption_COMMA_ homônumos disintegrated._NEWLINE_This blurb is well over 400 words but worth 1000 more. I continue to work life as art_COMMA_ and think life as a collective of binding differences.
column16: (2009-2014) years living in a loft with 4 other people_COMMA_ their partners_COMMA_ drop-ins and a variety of plants_COMMA_ shower/bath schedules_COMMA_ and food beliefs. I do much better get along with girls; I live with boys too. I prefer dirty work to sweeping shelves. I keep my mess in my room (not so messy at all). What I like best about communal living is sharing my yoga practice with roomies_COMMA_ morning kitchen parties_COMMA_ 5-7 decompressing with talks on love_COMMA_ commitment/non-commitment issues_COMMA_ health (body and mind)_COMMA_ job-hunting_COMMA_ art projects. Peeking on a roomy rehearsing a performance or training handstand is a plus. I find it hard when roomies slak on their assigned chores.
column17: Practice-based research_COMMA_ outdoors_COMMA_ experiential and explorative knowledge transfer_COMMA_ artists in various fields_COMMA_ communal living_COMMA_ displacement_COMMA_ all ages. All elements which foster potential conflicts_COMMA_ open possibles and reveal impossibles – elements essential to the out-of-the-box creative process I feed on. I likely will come out of SMT better equipped to situate my practice within the field of performative work._NEWLINE_I also met Daniele Bourque in Toronto_COMMA_ while part of a performance that was dedicated to her_COMMA_ and will again meet her during a 2-day individualized coaching with Sylvie Tourangeau (TouVA) on performative presence. Much of my work is dealing with the immaterial and embodiment of. Bourque and Korta are well equipped to understand and guide me.
column19: I envision a project* that would grow into the community_COMMA_ in the divide between the geo-locations of SMT and my own home (Montreal). I would like to propose a project that is the extension of what I wish to come to SMT for – transferring stories of innate objects into living stories in my body. I call this proposal_COMMA_ 'Project 'embodying your daily ritual'-one action of domestic nature'. The first part of the project is to perform my research in a conference-type environment at SMT to current participants + coach a 'how-to' somatic research session. The second part is enlisting bodies + pre-stamp post card invitations and send to residential homes along the train line corridor between SMT and my home. The third part is taking the 'arms' with a cell group (trained at SMT) and infiltrate domestic space by 'embodying your daily ritual'-one action of domestic nature to homes who have RSVP to the post-card invite. The bonus part is possibly infiltrating cell group's own SMT-homebase commute route (extra-extra funding). *always archive for iterative PBR_COMMA_ diffusion_COMMA_ and monitoring evolution. See PBR case with 'Brushing teeth in public' @ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dFQUNHIujZY&feature=c4-overview&list=UUadRt_oZOwPW0m_IKUDtNVw
column20: Q.Do you love me?_NEWLINE_A.I don't. Well_COMMA_ I do sometimes. But it's a waste of time to give you my love.This morning I loved you. I still do now. But I am playing it safe. ~ Letter from self to self._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Q. Will SMT create a Twitter account to put in touch alumni and new students and projects?_NEWLINE_A. --

column13: I am a multi-disciplinary artist with a strong interest in the boundaries of the body and the confrontation with mortality. I spent the previous year as an Arts Fellow at The Drisha Institute of Jewish Education studying Torah with a creative focus on death_COMMA_ destruction_COMMA_ and resurrection in the Talmud. I received my BA from the University of Chicago in 2012_COMMA_ where I studied the intersection of aesthetics and ethics through literature and the visual arts. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My artistic practice stems from a fundamental fascination with the permeability of bodily borders. I investigate the ways in which we experience and process our physicality and materiality in the face of what lies beyond our bodies and our lived experience. I am heavily influenced by the texts and practices of various religious and spiritual doctrines_COMMA_ as well as literature and philosophy that addresses death_COMMA_ aesthetics_COMMA_ faith_COMMA_ emotion_COMMA_ and ethics. Profound attention to the written word_COMMA_ as well as texture_COMMA_ movement_COMMA_ and space_COMMA_ is the foundation for constructing multi-disciplinary art experiences that audience members can access through various layers of consciousness. My work is meant to bring viewers into confrontation with the limits of being in order to recognize the inherent beauty of what lies on either side_COMMA_ in order to transcend fear and liberate pain. I seek to temper the morbid and the grotesque with a reverence for details_COMMA_ to infuse the shadows with grace.
column14: I am very attached to conversation as a tool for processing any stage of creation_COMMA_ from idea generating to logistics. This allows me to clarify concepts and refine details. Whether or not I am collaborating with another person in the traditional sense of sharing authorship_COMMA_ I rely on conversation and consider it a collaborative practice._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Currently_COMMA_ I am collaborating on an experimental film adaptation of a Kafka short story with my brother_COMMA_ an NYC based filmmaker. We began by closely reading the text and building off of each other's interpretations until we aligned our vision of the text. We used these thoughts as a foundation for the screenplay_COMMA_ which we debated at length. Now_COMMA_ we are in the midst of story-boarding the screenplay; we discuss what is contained in each image and its significance_COMMA_ how this moment should affect the viewer_COMMA_ and how we can best frame the moment to achieve this. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Last spring_COMMA_ I co-choreographed a performance piece based on the tahara_COMMA_ the Jewish ritual washing of the dead. The two of us usually focused our energies on different aspects of the work: I was more concerned with the conceptual framework_COMMA_ while my partner was more interested in specific movements and transitions. Much of the work consisted of us moving around in a room together_COMMA_ testing our ideas_COMMA_ and discovering what we both liked. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am eager_COMMA_ always_COMMA_ to experience new collaborative structures.
column15: This is an installation I mounted in June as part the Drisha Institute's Artist Showcase: _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_https://www.dropbox.com/sh/ehkbpqievzr8n3g/2hdsn1K-DV_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Ani Hashem Rofecha: A Cabinet of Curiosity _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The Cabinet of Curiosity_COMMA_ also known as a Cabinet of Wonder_COMMA_ or a Wonder-room_COMMA_ was an encyclopedic collection of objects whose categorical boundaries were as yet undefined. A precursor to the museum_COMMA_ this European Renaissance form was likened to a "theater of the world" and conveyed a certain control of the world. The attempt to classify the unclassified_COMMA_ to possess the elusive_COMMA_ created the illusion that profound knowledge had been grasped. While these cabinets are impressive_COMMA_ their contents spark more questions than answers. Indeed_COMMA_ the Cabinet of Curiosity conveys an attempt to know_COMMA_ and the impossibility of doing so. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Drawing from Chapter 11 of Tractate Sanhedrin of the Babylonian Talmud_COMMA_ I have created and curated a Curiosity Cabinet of objects and ideas. Through the micronarratives in Sanhedrin_COMMA_ we attempt to know God and (wo)man_COMMA_ and in turn_COMMA_ we are given only holy fragments_COMMA_ fragments of a disembodied God and disembodied (wo)man. This cabinet explores God as destroyer_COMMA_ healer and redeemer. The Cabinet of Curiosity doubles as a medicinal cabinet for a body that is entirely decontextualized_COMMA_ wherein bone and viscera encounter the destroying_COMMA_ resurrecting_COMMA_ redeeming_COMMA_ healing God before we do.
column16: Among the many communal living experiences I've had_COMMA_ the most colorful was the month I spent in Tsfat_COMMA_ in the very north of Israel_COMMA_ in an all women's seminary for the study of ultra-orthodox mystical Judaism. The expectations of this community were beyond anything I could've imagined: we were to keep our knees_COMMA_ elbows_COMMA_ and collar bones covered; we were to pray_COMMA_ as best as we could_COMMA_ three times a day; and we were discouraged from interacting with men_COMMA_ should the rare opportunity present itself. I was more aware of my collar bones than I had ever been in my life_COMMA_ developed an intense fondness for the utility of scarves_COMMA_ and sang out loud despite the rebuke of our male security guard. I learned deeply how far I could stretch myself for the sake of community and how far I was willing to go. Despite the everyday frustrations of my short visit to this world_COMMA_ I forged profound connections with my seminary mates_COMMA_ whether through contemplating the nature of God or laughing at ourselves before bed.
column17: The very idea that thinking is a creative act spurs my artistic practice. I am very drawn to a critical approach_COMMA_ and have struggled with the idea that critical analysis can be understood as_COMMA_ by nature_COMMA_ deconstructive. The act of analysis_COMMA_ however_COMMA_ is an attempt at constructing meaning_COMMA_ which is a profoundly creative act. I would like to continue to explore this tension_COMMA_ which informs the core of my artistic practice. The course on Unthinking/Unknowing would be a perfect place to do so._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am extremely interested in the limits of the body_COMMA_ and this fixation is coupled with the less urgent but ever powerful fascination with the limits of the mind. I am interested in exploring this through conceptually and experientially. In the work I create_COMMA_ I seek to draw attention to line between the known and the unknown_COMMA_ between this world and the next. Exploring this liminal space through thought and experience strikes me as particularly important_COMMA_ so that I might gain insight into how to bring audience attention to processing this liminal space when I create my own work. The course on Unthinking/Unknowing addresses my key interests through an innovative and multivalent approach_COMMA_ which appeals intensely to me. I work in a multi-disciplinary fashion in order to access the wisdom of articulated and unarticulated thought and emotion. This course would illuminate these access points and deepen my practice substantially.
column19: I would like to mount an interactive installation that investigates death_COMMA_ memory_COMMA_ and loss. The space would resemble a bedroom and be laden with objects and clues about who once inhabited the space. These three options would be valid: a. the room belonged to a deceased person; b. the room belongs to someone who may or may not be deceased_COMMA_ and who is speaking through the objects; c. the viewer is the deceased. The inclusion of relational objects would be an important aspect of the project_COMMA_ as well as the participation of one viewer at a time. The objects_COMMA_ as well as the space itself_COMMA_ would slip between the extremely mundane_COMMA_ the abject_COMMA_ and the surreal_COMMA_ thus sliding between an awareness of the body_COMMA_ at its most visceral_COMMA_ and the psyche_COMMA_ at its most detached. I would be keen on experimenting with how to blur the line between the felt and the seen; the sense of the living and the sense of the dead. This would ideally be a space of confrontation and healing.
column20: What will you write next? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My next piece of writing shall be an elegy. _NEWLINE_Not because I have lost anything in particular_COMMA_ _NEWLINE_but because I often feel that I have_COMMA_ and will always_COMMA_ _NEWLINE_lose everything. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_When I write again_COMMA_ it shall be an elegy. _NEWLINE_Perhaps_COMMA_ to my body. _NEWLINE_One can never start planning too early._NEWLINE_And there are so many ways to lose a body_COMMA_ _NEWLINE_its pieces and parts. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_We must always return to memory. _NEWLINE_To keep ourselves sane. _NEWLINE_To keep ourselves smart. _NEWLINE_To keep ourselves good._NEWLINE_ _NEWLINE_Or eliminate memory_COMMA_ and soar.
column23: I do not eat meat_COMMA_ shellfish_COMMA_ or insects_COMMA_ for the most part. I am allergic to textured meat protein (i.e. seitan and other glutenous meat substitutes) and tempeh.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)_COMMA_ Session B (UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING)
column13: I'm a musician based in NYC. I release electronic music as Ink Jet._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In terms of employment_COMMA_ currently I work both as a freelance composer (for commercials_COMMA_ film_COMMA_ etc.) and at a small design/branding agency as a producer (jack of all trades). I'm in the process of transitioning toward full time music/audio work._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As an artist/musician_COMMA_ I'm interested in the creative possiblities offered by manipulating sampled audio. The music I produce with samples ranges from basic hip-hop beats ("ripping off" for bars and slapping some drums on it) to more involved productions composed of many tiny samples from various sources. Sampling is often derided as simple stealing_COMMA_ but I think producers like J Dilla_COMMA_ Madlib_COMMA_ the Avalanches_COMMA_ et al. clearly create artistic value with the choices they make. I aim to make music that brings the relationship between sampler and samplee to the forefront._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_On a related note_COMMA_ I've also started writing about the effect that the interfaces of electronic music equipment have upon the music created with them. My current focus is on some of the classic samplers (MPC_COMMA_ SP-1200) used to make iconic hip-hop and house records. The UI of gear almost inevitably leads to specific musical choices_COMMA_ but I haven't seen these choices discussed outside of informal conversations with other electronic music producers._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm also interested in interactive music projects I'm currently developing a project tentatively titled Crowd Raps. I set up a phone line that_COMMA_ when you call in_COMMA_ plays a hip-hop instrumental. The caller is encouraged to rap or sing along to the beat_COMMA_ and anything they do is recorded to a server. The plan is to edit down the best calls and release them as completed tracks online.
column14: My work is collaborative in a few different ways._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Most directly_COMMA_ I sometimes work on music with other artists_COMMA_ writing and playing together_COMMA_ or collaborating in different media (e.g._COMMA_ dance + music)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Currently I'm working on a project called Crowd Raps (described above) that's more of a combination of collaboration and curation. In it_COMMA_ I solicit singing and rapping from callers_COMMA_ then review their submissions and edit interesting together ones for release as the "final product." In this situation_COMMA_ the callers are reacting to music and creating something of their own_COMMA_ but they don't know how their own contribution will exist as part of the final work._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'd also argue that in performing live as an electronic dance musician_COMMA_ the relationship between performer and dancers - traditionally viewed as performer/audience - can in fact be collaborative. I've been in situations where the music I played was directly influenced by activity on the dance floor._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_All of that said_COMMA_ much of my work is produced entirely on my own. I'm interested in the School of Making Thing precisely because I want to open up my creative process to collaboration!
column15: I've recently been releasing music under the name Ink Jet. Last summer_COMMA_ I put out my first record_COMMA_ Grandma Tapes._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The music on Grandma Tapes was composed with a set of strict rules: 1) Every sound on the record was sampled from a box of cassette tapes my grandmother left for me when she died. 2) Each track was created from samples of a single work by a (generally Romantic classical) composer. 3) I used a single hardware sampler to create the record; I wanted to stay away from working in the visual environment a computer offers._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_These rules helped direct me through a creative process that examined the musical taste of a past generation while generating music that sounded vastly different. The experience of listening to the tapes was very emotional for me; I listened to them imagining how my grandmother had. It was also a way to deeply explore the technique of sampling; I learned to doing things like coax a dance-style kick drum out of a symphony._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Currently_COMMA_ I'm working on a series of musical sketches as part of a weekly project I call Natural Athleticism. Every Wednesday in 2014_COMMA_ I'm releasing a new track online. Each one is based on a rough idea from a list I've drawn up: e.g._COMMA_ "make music claps that slowly grow into applause_COMMA_ then return to rhythmic clapping". Natural Athleticism is a way to keep myself working through specific ideas that interest me_COMMA_ rather than simply "writing songs"._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Both of these projects are linked above.
column16: I spent my first two years in New York living with a group of other musicians. This wasn't an organized communal living experience so much as simply living with roommates_COMMA_ but it had a great effect on the art I created. Specifically_COMMA_ my proximity to people with different taste got me involved in styles/genres that I had previously never even tried to understand. E.g._COMMA_ I used to think that most four-to-the-floor dance music was too rhythmically simple to pay attention to; now I make some myself. Long story short_COMMA_ my experience of living with others was one of opening up my mind to different forms of expression._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Another thing that's important to me: communal food. I love to cook and eat with others_COMMA_ and hope that will be a part of the SMT experience.
column17: "Between Nature and Culture": to start with_COMMA_ I agree with the central conceit: wildness IS creatively enticing to me. Let me share a dream I had a couple years back:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I was a small four-legged creature_COMMA_ no distinct species_COMMA_ a proto-mammal. I spent my time lurking in the undergrowth of a forest by a clearing. I would peer out from the shadows and look at a sunny puddle of a milky pink liquid. I felt afraid of an unknown force (a predator above?) but when I worked up the courage_COMMA_ I would dart out to quickly sip at it_COMMA_ then jet back to the shadows. Then_COMMA_ I felt a pressure welling up inside of me. I walked out into the light_COMMA_ raised my little head up to the sky_COMMA_ and roared with my full body and soul_COMMA_ howled at the sun. Then I woke up._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I bring this up because the dream put me in touch with a sort wellspring of primal_COMMA_ weird energy within me that I had been ignoring or suppressing. And in the years since_COMMA_ I have failed to harness whatever powerful experience I had in that dream_COMMA_ though I've thought about it a lot. I realize that this might come across as absurd_COMMA_ but I hope that the Nature/Culture session might give me a helpful lens to address this topic of untapped wildness in myself._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm also intrigued by the subject of Unthinking/Unknowing. I'm always looking for situations that bring about creative thought_COMMA_ from running to meditation to substances to a shower. My current method of making art treats creative thought like work_COMMA_ providing a steady framework in which to let the mind free. I hope that this session would open me to a broader set of exercises that might change the way I think.
column18: N/A
column19: Given unlimited funding_COMMA_ I would love to mount a massive sound installation on a chunk of woodland. I would set up sensors everywhere: microphones_COMMA_ thermometers_COMMA_ flex sensors to sense tree limbs flexing in the wind_COMMA_ infrared cameras_COMMA_ etc. The area would be rigged up like an embassy_COMMA_ but the technology would be hidden as much as possible. I'd use the feedback from these sensors to create a kind of amplified nature_COMMA_ a set of sounds that take direct audio from the microphones and process it based on other realtime data_COMMA_ expressing the conditions of the moment through sound in a way that a listener in that spot could intuitively understand._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Alternatively: given all those sensors_COMMA_ the piece could satirize the surveillance state. The participant is escorted to a hut with a computer terminal. They watch a real time read out of what's happening on the land_COMMA_ stylized like a security system in a movie. The participant is directed to complete a few simple tasks on the terminal_COMMA_ e.g._COMMA_ clicking on boxes to ensure levels are in line. At a predetermined point_COMMA_ the system would "malfunction"_COMMA_ and the real time sound described above would roar all around the participant.
column20: What kind of artist would you like to encounter at SMT?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Of course_COMMA_ I'm open to anyone I might encounter_COMMA_ and I want to be surrounded by a diverse group of people. But one type of artist I think is underrepresented in the "serious art" world: comedians. I'd love to have comedians working out new material alongside all the other artists and writers. In general I enjoy art that has a sense of humor_COMMA_ and I think having someone who specializes in humor around would enrich the experience for everyone.

column13: before i was a cloud i found treasures and shared them with friends_NEWLINE_after i was a cloud i spun around in a confusing way_NEWLINE_until i fell_NEWLINE_falling hurt alot !_NEWLINE_but it was also good_NEWLINE_because i learned how not to be spinning_NEWLINE_just kidding!_NEWLINE_i dont know how not to be spinning_NEWLINE_but it was still good to fall_NEWLINE_and i am committed to the goodness of this experience_NEWLINE_falling down onto the steaming summer lawn with popsicles_NEWLINE_falling into the sky dreaming unravelling wandering mysteries_NEWLINE_falling in love falls through me like a leaky pot in the rain_NEWLINE_i am the moss beneath the leaky pot in the rain
column14: i build experiential interactive installations that are about contagious human behavior_COMMA_ interconnectivity_COMMA_ influence and consciousness._NEWLINE_i use various forms of sensory communication to create experiences of awakening. _NEWLINE_collaborations are a key element in my creation of experiences: working together with the audience and/or creating with other artists._NEWLINE_the "red room"_COMMA_ the "yawning booth"_COMMA_ the "universes"... all are about sensory immersion and participation.
column15: The "Yawning Booth" installation is an environmental and audio sensory experience. It is a booth shaped like an out house that people go to yawn in. Inside the booth soft sounds of me continuously yawning illustrate interconnectivity and mirror neurons in the brain as the audio yawn is "caught"_COMMA_ or passed from one body to another. The yawn enters through the first person's ears in the booth_COMMA_ is absorbed into the body and then reflected back out through the yawning body into the eyes of a live camera_COMMA_ so that elsewhere that yawn will be passed to the video viewer through the eyes. An onlooker can then observe this person yawning in real time_COMMA_ and then receive and pass along more yawns through live observation and so on.
column16: "Nothing like bumping butts in the kitchen"_COMMA_ as my friend eliza's mom from montana used to say. i love cooking and creating with friends._NEWLINE_i once lived in a 2 bedroom house with 13 people in california.... ah good times.._NEWLINE_helped start a farm in upstate new york_COMMA_ still visit often.._NEWLINE_most of the living situations i have had have been communal_COMMA_ i prefer sharing most items: grains_COMMA_ veges_COMMA_ most tools... while maintaining personal autonomy in other areas : face cream_COMMA_ toothbrush..._NEWLINE_my favorite thing ever is family dinner .

column13: I’m applying in collaboration with Ari Marcantonio. I’m currently finishing up my MFA at the University of Iowa. I gave up a tenured job teaching art to high school students to return to school. While most people get their MFA so they can teach_COMMA_ I did the opposite. I love academia_COMMA_ and spent the three years prior to becoming a high school teacher getting an MA in Art Education_COMMA_ but am excited to be finished with it for a while. Due to the dearth of queer studies at the university I’m at_COMMA_ I’ve become a bit of an autodidact in the field_COMMA_ which relates to my work_COMMA_ where I address issues/ideas around the development of queer subjectivity. For many years I lived in the San Francisco Bay Area where_COMMA_ prior to teaching (and a bit less while living a professional lifestyle)_COMMA_ I played in bands and had an amazing house in the Mission where I hosted tons of pop shows. Because of that_COMMA_ I’ve been able to travel extensively_COMMA_ which is something I love. I recently met and talked to Yvonne Ranier_COMMA_ who I really connected with when I told her I studied classical ballet for nine years_COMMA_ and was excited to talk with her about bringing my past as a performer into my current visual-art practice. Which is something I’ve been trying to do and thinking a lot about. I’m trying to commit entirely to my creative practice. While most of my colleagues are applying for jobs_COMMA_ I’m applying to residencies. This commitment is scary_COMMA_ because it means no income_COMMA_ transience and precarity. There is a part of me who just wants house-plants and a cat_COMMA_ but I feel like now is the time to throw caution to the wind and see what happens. I’m excited!
column14: I guess one theme of my life_COMMA_ whether it’s been having shows at my house or teaching in the classroom_COMMA_ has been community building. This is important to me because I believe that we only truly begin to know ourselves through our encounter with others. While the majority of my creative practice has been a kind of traditional_COMMA_ studio based one_COMMA_ I’ve always imagined it to be based in communication and just one tool through which to experience that encounter. Lately though_COMMA_ I’ve been expanding what it means to create work that is in communication with the viewer and make work that actually requires the viewer to participate in order to be complete. I’m trying to collaborate with my viewer not just in the creation of meaning_COMMA_ but in an actual physical experience as well. So_COMMA_ a dance floor that asks you to step up and make a spectacle of yourself_COMMA_ for example_COMMA_ is a different experience than just looking at an object or performance as a viewer. I always thought of my teaching practice as collaborative_COMMA_ and I’ve been lucky through my teaching to have found an actual collaborative partner (you’ll learn a bit more about that in the next section). While here at the University of Iowa I have collaborated with another person in my department to build community through the organization of a queer print exchange portfolio that’s going to be shown at the Southern Graphics Council International Printmaking Conference. Part of the reason I wanted to participate in an MFA program was for the critical community and the opportunity for growth that can be experienced through collaborative thinking and dialogue. I’ve been lucky to have that community the past three years and I hope to continue to figure out ways to keep having it.
column15: In 2012 I participated in an artist residency in Northern NM called PLAND (Practice Liberating Art through Necessary Dislocation). It consisted of living in a trailer for three weeks with my collaborator_COMMA_ who used to be my student_COMMA_ in the desert outside of Taos. Rather than write a description of it here_COMMA_ I would ask that you follow the link to the collaboratively written piece we wrote for the Notes on Looking website titled “Take A Sauna”. Thanks_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://notesonlooking.com/2012/10/take-a-sauna/
column16: My most intense communal living experience would probably be that of a touring band. Several times in my life I have been on tour with more than nine people at once. Living in this way_COMMA_ making decisions_COMMA_ trying to find some personal solitude while packed in a van_COMMA_ sardined on the living room of some strangers house_COMMA_ or back stage_COMMA_ or even just being able to navigate the myriad issues that come up when nine plus egos are trying to find consensus on where to eat in some unknown city can be crazy making. I have found though_COMMA_ that I'm a good peace-maker. I've always been a good listener and very empathetic_COMMA_ but with little tolerance for BS and not really afraid to call it. That's served me well in these situations and I think that I’ve been an asset to my groups of friends in these instances_COMMA_ helping to alleviate tensions and opening avenues of communication.
column17: Standing on the precipice of life after graduate school is terrifying_COMMA_ not because I’m worried about work (finding it or making it for myself)_COMMA_ or even because (like many of my colleagues) I don’t know what I want out of life. I DO know what I want out of life_COMMA_ and the terror comes from an understanding that the structure of our society privileges a certain type of person to achieve it. I know what it’s like to try and pursue a creative life outside of the academy_COMMA_ how the pressures of living make it more and more difficult to dedicate time_COMMA_ resources and physical and mental faculties to something that is often simply a labor of love_COMMA_ with little or no return. I’m interested in the session Unthinking/Unknowing because I want to challenge myself to do just that. I want an opportunity to think differently about my creative practice. How can I engage with it in different ways that don’t rely on what have become standard ways of making for me? Collaboration with Ari is one way that I have achieved that. In our own collaboration we ask how we can undo trusted modes of inquiry_COMMA_ use of critical texts and attachments to theory to become more articulate with ideas in an expanded realm of cultural production? This session and the description of the process seem to be exactly the kind of thing that will help us do that. All of this and engaging in a critical community and building relationships across disciplines and geographic location are why we would love to attend SMT. Timing is also important. I am dedicating this year to pursuing residencies before having to buckle down and get a job. July is when my new life begins.
column19: Ari and I recently had our astrological charts read in an attempt to better understand our fundamental differences and how they impede our communication. During our sessions with the astrologer a strongly coincidental similarity in our charts lead to the possibility that we had a relationship in a past life which ended tragically and that the current difficulties in our relationship might be the result of this past life trauma. If we had enough money to pay for it we would hire a hypnotist to lead us through past life regression therapy in an attempt to better envision how this past life narrative might take form. Our interest is in the metaphorical potential of this narrative to shed light on the actuality of our lived relationship and on the macro level parallels that our conflict might have in contemporary society. This closely relates to the theme of session B. Through this process we are working towards unthinking and unknowing our current modes of communication_COMMA_ stagnancy in our relationship_COMMA_ and to open up new and radical modes of relating to one another and the world. We see the potential to reimagine the possibilities of both our friendship and our creative collaboration.
column20: I often ask myself “why art?” In a world where commodity fetishism and rampant neoliberalism rule the art market I wonder why it feels so important to do the work of cultural production. In the end_COMMA_ I realize that it is because the inquiry that happens through the creative process is ultimately valuable. That the questions that arise out of that process_COMMA_ and the process of sharing those questions and the tenuous and myriad answers that are sometimes produced_COMMA_ allow for different ways of thinking and hopefully_COMMA_ through a carefully articulated aesthetic experience_COMMA_ eventually_COMMA_ actual radical change.
column21: none

column13: I am applying in collaboration with Jaime Knight. I am an artist_COMMA_ writer and chef; I recently graduated from university where I gained valuable insight into the process of socialization through a series of powerful participatory examples and am now trying to unpack the notions I have about how to be a productive and socially engaging artist_COMMA_ human and thinker. My recent artistic practice has taken form as a multi-disciplinary investigation of collaboration_COMMA_ competition and support_COMMA_ whether in the physical_COMMA_ psychological or interpersonal sense of the words. I work from two basic methodologies: the first being a critical model that investigates how things are and why and its counterpart_COMMA_ a productive model that proposes and enacts alternative structures._NEWLINE_I am invested in the power of social organization and solidarity—the ability of human beings to build agency_COMMA_ empathize more effectively and effect change by speaking and acting with one another. I have been greatly influenced by the critical pedagogy of Paulo Freire and Bell Hooks and the social theory of Michel Foucault. From these writers I have gained valuable insight into the power of discussion as a tool for social liberation and fluidity_COMMA_ an understanding that informs the structure_COMMA_ content and form of my own practice and my appreciation of art in general. My recent work has been as diverse as building a functional sauna for a nascent artist residency in New Mexico_COMMA_ founding a pop-up dinner club that raises and distributes funding for underrepresented artists and facilitating discussions with my peers about the course of the art world and how we view our futures within it.
column14: I work individually about as often as I work collaboratively and place great value in the potential of conflict and difference to challenge my preconceptions and enable me to empathize more readily. My collaborative work varies in structure (some examples are physical objects_COMMA_ performances and interviews/discussions) and I do not necessarily seek projects in which labor and investment are equally divided (although this has happened in rare cases) but am open to a wide variety of ways of working with and learning from the people around me. I believe in the potential of art to act as a socially mobilizing force and_COMMA_ whether I work individually or collaboratively_COMMA_ value the processes_COMMA_ discussions_COMMA_ arguments and reactions that the work can engender over any physical product. I view discussion_COMMA_ education and collaboration as tent poles of my practice more so than any medium-specific categories and I am excited by the prospect of a residency program that is based on dialogue_COMMA_ mutual growth and education.
column15: While in residence at PLAND in 2012 my collaborator and I built a functional sauna to serve as a bathhouse for future residents. Rather than describe the work here I have attached a link to an essay co-written by my collaborator and I about the project:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://notesonlooking.com/2012/10/take-a-sauna/
column16: While in residence at PLAND (Practice Liberating Art through Necessary Disclocation) in Tres Piedras_COMMA_ NM I lived in an off the grid trailer with my collaborator for three weeks. In addition to dividing the physical and conceptual labor of our project we shared domestic chores such as cooking_COMMA_ cleaning and maintenance of the space. The work we did while in residence became as much about the physical structure we were producing as the process of living and working with each other in an isolated environment.
column17: The notion of unthinking/unknowing uncannily describes a feeling I have as a recent undergraduate. Art school was a blur of rapidly expanding potentials. My capacity to envision what art is or could be grew exponentially_COMMA_ at times reaching a critical mass that made any forward movement feel impossible. Now_COMMA_ that framework of critical mining is gone and I feel as though I have woken up at the bottom of the shaft. The important work ahead of me is to climb out of this space with the attention necessary to unpack what I found along the way. I have been given a powerful gift of multiple perspectives and the deconstructive tools necessary to balance them but what feels most necessary now is to forget everything I have been told_COMMA_ drop the baggage and find a way to make the practice I need for myself and my community real. Doing this is easier said than done and I know I cannot forget. But I can change my relationship to what I remember. For me_COMMA_ to envision thinking what I do not know how to think means making tangible what I know I need but cannot touch. I have touched many things like it but they all belong to others and do not quite fit me. I know I want to build something that can contain and support a collaborative yet challenging and discursive space_COMMA_ something that is responsive to the multiple desires of those involved and is flexible enough to meet them. I know I want this thing but as of yet it is only an abstract conglomeration of other structures_COMMA_ a reaction to what has come before. In order to think what I cannot think for myself I need to unknow what I have been told to want.
column18: I recently attended a participatory group dynamics conference the goal of which was to analyze the dynamics of those attending as they emerged. In this structure (known as the Tavistock method) participants_COMMA_ supervised by a largely inactively participating team of psychiatrists and psychoanalysts_COMMA_ are divided into groups and given no further instruction but to analyze their group dynamics in the “here and now”. I found this method enlightening and productive and would like to organize a “here and now” session at SMT. This would consist of sitting together for about one hour and simply saying what we feel as it arises.

column20: Are there any art world structures_COMMA_ opportunities_COMMA_ institutions_COMMA_ etc that you do not know of existing but wish existed?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My sister lives and practices at a Zen monastery and while visiting her there I was amazed at the community that had been built around maintaining such a specific yet individualized practice. The monastery is in a beautiful location and operates as a resort for the summer. During this time the students work full time (in addition to their practice) in exchange for room_COMMA_ board and zen instruction_COMMA_ in order to maintain and operate the resort. This three months of work supports the monastery as well as two others for the entire year. I want a school and residency program that is based on mutual support and collaborative life/work that engages capitalism in a way that the participants find comfortable in order to sustainably support the practices and lives of those involved.

column13: Hi SMT! My name is Rebecca and I’m a multidisciplinary artist and designer who lives in Brooklyn_COMMA_ New York. You may know me from last summer when I started a project about visual poetics using images from Google Search by Image_COMMA_ madegreen smoothies and read a lot of Kenneth Goldsmith in the hammock. My time at SMT last summer not only was a launchpad for an important project I’m still working on and developing_COMMA_ but helped me refine the kind of artist and thinker I want to be and continue becoming._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My creative and intellectual practice has thus far spanned many different disciplines_COMMA_ scales_COMMA_ and modes of making (from sculpture to video to performance to design to image-based work) but my interest in technology and digital media_COMMA_ and in exploring the larger questions they raise_COMMA_ is one of the threads that runs throughout my recent work. Working on my project at SMT last summer solidified for me that this is a thread I want to continue to follow (both conceptually and technically) and helped inform my decision to apply to new media art graduate programs for Fall 2014._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_At SMT this upcoming summer_COMMA_ I hope to build on the experience I had last summer and push it even further; make better work_COMMA_ speak up more_COMMA_ develop even closer friendships and have deeper conversations_COMMA_ go on more adventures. I hope to continue to open my heart and mind to others_COMMA_ to learn how to wander_COMMA_ and continue to stretch my definition of what it means to be an artist and a maker.
column14: My creative and intellectual work is collaborative both in literal ways and more oblique ones. That said_COMMA_ everything I do creatively is fundamentally and deeply reliant on my engagement with other people. In certain modes of making_COMMA_ I work actively with a collaborator or collective in a shared process of making and thinking (such as in my work on RECAPS with my collaborator Martabel Wasserman_COMMA_ or in my design practice); other times_COMMA_ my work is more independent and self-driven but nonetheless informed by a dialogue with friends_COMMA_ peers and other artists and thinkers._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My most recent body of work_COMMA_ visually similar imgs_COMMA_ grew out of a project that I started last summer at SMT and the direction of the work (which is still constantly shifting and changing) was shaped largely by conversations and feedback and experiences that I had throughout the course of the session. I’ve been fortunate to have other opportunities to present the work among peers and groups of people_COMMA_ and each time the feedback I receive and the dialogue I enter into is incredibly useful and fruitful for me._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Lastly_COMMA_ research is an integral part of my practice_COMMA_ and I see this as part of a process of collaboration in the sense that I am joining a dialogue or conversation that already exists.
column15: http://rebeccalieberman.com/visually-similar-imgs-books_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In David Buuck and Juliana Spahr’s An Army of Lovers_COMMA_ two poets come across a plot of land. Their initial discovery leads them through a progression of dream-like spaces_COMMA_ in which the plot of land is “also an enormous food court…not just a food court_COMMA_ but also an outdoor rehearsal space…not a rehearsal space_COMMA_ but a soundstage for gigantic live entertainments.” Through this protean space_COMMA_ in which theater is a warehouse is a bunker_COMMA_ the protagonists inhabit a universe in which things become other things_COMMA_ depending on how you look at them. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In the kaleidoscopic odyssey of these characters_COMMA_ I see many of the questions that drive my work. My interest in creating a vocabulary of surrogates and substitutions is a thread that runs through both my major bodies of work to date: Whitetail Deer_COMMA_ A to Z and visually similar imgs. Through these projects_COMMA_ I’ve engaged with formal questions around the semantics of materials and the poetics of simile. I’ve explored strategies of remaking and restaging to estrange familiar systems and objects_COMMA_ and I’ve used formal grammars of equivalence_COMMA_ where things stand in for other things_COMMA_ to probe the contingency of meaning. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_visually similar imgs_COMMA_ which uses digital imagery culled from Google’s “Search by Image_COMMA_” currently exists as a group of artist books_COMMA_ a website-based image work_COMMA_ and a series of looped video projections. Gesturing at the seams of familiar technology_COMMA_ I use material mined from search results in which Google fails to match an image based on visual DNA. In these proliferations of “visually similar” analogs_COMMA_ images become material: shapes and forms_COMMA_ pixel topographies_COMMA_ histograms of the everyday. They take on the ability to shapeshift into other things—a scene from a sci-fi apocalypse film parades as a fiery sunset and a fluorescent hotel room—and in them_COMMA_ I see poetic equivalences among the nonsense. visually similar imgs attempts to articulate a digital poetics of search_COMMA_ in which a grammar of simile and substitution is formed from the internet’s detritus. Mute and fragmentary images are liberated from conventional structures of meaning and reconstituted as semantic building blocks_COMMA_ like words in a poem. A dreamscape unfolds across the pages of a book_COMMA_ and the browser doubles as a hall of mirrors where unstable objects endlessly mutate and multiply.
column16: My most recent communal living experience was this past summer at SMT during Session B. Cohabitating with the seven or so other participants – cooking and eating meals together_COMMA_ sharing space in the barn_COMMA_ taking walks_COMMA_ making spontaneous morning smoothies and leaf collages – was a wonderful and fulfilling experience that I think allowed me to make better work_COMMA_ at the very least because I was so happy. Support structures of family and friends and roommates are incredibly important to me_COMMA_ and I understand the balance of giving and receiving that they demand._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Prior to that_COMMA_ my most substantial cooperative living experience was during my last two years of college_COMMA_ when I was a member and resident of the Dudley Co-op_COMMA_ a 32-person cooperative house for Harvard undergrads in Cambridge_COMMA_ Mass. My time at the co-op was emotionally_COMMA_ intellectually and socially crucial to my growth as a person and as a friend and as a thinker. Within the broader culture of Harvard_COMMA_ this community was a safe haven for me_COMMA_ my ideas and interests_COMMA_ and my changing identity. It was a place where I made incredible life-long friendships_COMMA_ activated my own political beliefs and was exposed to new ideas and people that destabilized many of my most fundamental assumptions about the world._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Being part of the co-op also gave me an important and lasting lesson in intentional living that has to this day impacted the way I treat my space and my community. Daily chores were part of the routine_COMMA_ as were attending weekly meetings to make community decisions and taking on longer “stewardships” to oversee larger things within the house.
column17: I hope to participate in the SMT Hike this summer because I’m interested in taking on an experience that feels new and profoundly challenging to me_COMMA_ both on a physical level and an intellectual level. I look forward to having a creative and intellectual experience that takes place quite literally “in the field” rather than in the confines of the studio_COMMA_ or the pages of a book (though I imagine we’ll engage in those kinds of activities as well). _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Within the past two years_COMMA_ much of my making practice has become somewhat immaterial and screen-based_COMMA_ in a way that makes me long for the days when I made very material work (large-scale sculptures_COMMA_ woodworking and performance) and engaged my body in that process. Last summer at SMT when I was thinking about this_COMMA_ I became interested in the idea of a walking practice. I hope to see how that practice of walking might become or intersect with my practice (if only for a few days)_COMMA_ and I’m excited to feel what it’s like to be present intellectually as well as physically. I imagine being engaged in this different way might deeply impact the way I think and create._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I also hope to participate in the hike because I’m interested in sharing an intellectually and socially intimate experience with a group. I look forward to the kinds of bonds that form and conversations that emerge when people are removed from their everyday structures and environments and placed into this kind of new configuration.
column18: I have many ideas for an immersive workshop or lecture to be given on the hike_COMMA_ but here are a couple. In the past few months_COMMA_ I’ve begun a meditation practice and so my first idea is to lead some kind of group meditation on the hike. It might be a sitting meditation (perhaps a Loving Kindness meditation_COMMA_ which is the kind I have been doing lately) or it could be a walking meditation_COMMA_ though I would have to look into these techniques a bit more. Either way_COMMA_ I think it could be a great group activity given the structure of the hike and the fact that we will be out in nature._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My second idea is to lead sessions of structured making while on the hike_COMMA_ that are instruction-based and short in nature. Some ideas might be:_NEWLINE_- Make an object for walking_NEWLINE_- Make a work at the scale of the hike_NEWLINE_- Make a work at the scale of a stick_NEWLINE_- Make a work at the scale of a small pebble_NEWLINE_- Make a work using text
