column13: I am a person who lives with intention. _NEWLINE_I am patient._NEWLINE_I am not interested in being current._NEWLINE_I am interested in being present._NEWLINE_I listen to music obsessively and write about it actively. _NEWLINE_I like to listen emphatically and ask people sneaky questions in hopes of exciting or challenging them. _NEWLINE_Recently_COMMA_ I stumbled upon the thought that 'I love interstitial time and hate interstitial space'. At first_COMMA_ it was just a fun thing to say to myself. Now_COMMA_ I believe it to be intensely true; unavoidably so. Some of my writing happens this way._NEWLINE_Confrontation is not my forte_COMMA_ but I am working at it when it counts._NEWLINE_I wish that people of varying age groups would spend more time together. I value greatly the time and experiences that I share with those much younger and much older than myself._NEWLINE_I have begun to exorcise myself of the concept of linear time._NEWLINE_My friend Seth refers to me as a 'deep Pisces'._NEWLINE_In a recent letter_COMMA_ my friend Katie described herself_COMMA_ regarding the consumer anxiety resultant from her purchasing an expensive leather bag_COMMA_ as "not a materialist_COMMA_ but super fucking aesthetic". This resonates with me._NEWLINE_I have become interested in contemporary dance. Instinctually_COMMA_ it feels like a close sibling of the language arts._NEWLINE_I am about 6'1 and 200 pounds_COMMA_ barrel-chested. Someone once told me that I move through the world like a small person. I took it as a great compliment._NEWLINE_There is nothing I enjoy more than a colourful meal with interested people.
column14: First and foremost_COMMA_ my practice is collaborative in the sense that the material it uses is language_COMMA_ and language is a massive and complex collaboration. I see it as a system of symbols agreed upon and shared by a group of people; language is delicate and full of imperfections. In this sense_COMMA_ my work is necessarily collaborative; it needs the support and understanding of others._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In order for my work to be witnessed in any way_COMMA_ the reader's (or listener's) vocabulary must meet with mine and intermingle. We may share common ground in regards to symbols_COMMA_ we may not; we may think that we share a common ground when_COMMA_ in fact_COMMA_ we don't (and vice versa). Because of this_COMMA_ my work is as much about the transmission of ideas as it is about the discovery and inspiration of new ideas. It is always a conversation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Furthermore_COMMA_ my work is almost always borne out of the social experience. It is practically essential to my process that the subject-matter-to-be reveals itself to me through an experience 'out in the world'_COMMA_ be it through participation or observation. I find inspiration in the way meaning moves in and out of language; the way conversations that happen subtly in loud rooms_COMMA_ the way words can bear great meaning without intention_COMMA_ the way banal descriptions of things can be taken as psychic metaphors. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My writing is most often an attempt at encapsulating a social event; one that happens in a quiet flash_COMMA_ or one that reveals itself very slowly and in many places._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My writing is at once an accounting of and response to the curiosities of living as a social creature.
column15: https://soundcloud.com/alvin_row-1/a-reading-of-conditional_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This is a piece entitled 'Conditional Performance' and it marks two important firsts for me as a writer:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It is the first piece that I wrote that necessitates an oral presentation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It is the first time I've collaborated with anyone (editor's aside) on the composition of a piece of writing._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Because the creative process associated with it was_COMMA_ for me_COMMA_ new and experimental_COMMA_ I see it as an exciting yet somewhat flawed piece. I included it in this section not because I think it's my strongest work_COMMA_ but because it represents my willingness to explore as an artist and it showcases my budding interest in welcoming people into my process._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I began writing it_COMMA_ knowing immediately that it was an oral piece_COMMA_ but with no specific end in mind. When I was invited to read as part of the OBEY Convention (an outsider music and art festival in Halifax)_COMMA_ I knew that this piece needed to be a part of my performance. After working the piece into a near-to-final draft_COMMA_ I invited my friends Cat and Jeremy (a politician and musician_COMMA_ respectively) to workshop it with me._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Immediately_COMMA_ the two found themselves comfortably at opposite ends of the expressive spectrum: with Jeremy overly drab and Cat overly dynamic. As we worked through the readings_COMMA_ I invited the two to help develop their voices in the text_COMMA_ to sharpen the piece_COMMA_ adding and removing phrases and inflections as we three saw fit._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As I eluded to above_COMMA_ I don't think it's an entirely successful piece_COMMA_ but I feel it offers multiple points of entry and a fair scope of my tendencies (good and bad). I am proud of it_COMMA_ unabashedly. I see the entire process behind it as a potential platform for work that I'd like to undertake at SMT.
column16: In November of last year_COMMA_ I spent five days on an 'inquiry'. It consisted of a walk from Lunenberg to Halifax (roughly 109km) along a trail converted from an old railway track. I undertook this expedition alongside a visual artist_COMMA_ an architect_COMMA_ a basket-maker and a thespian._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The intentions behind the trip were varied and mostly implicit. Each of us had spent time living in both locations so (to my mind) it was an exercise in understanding the mental and physical distance between the two places; a journey which we'd all made many times in ride shares or hitchhiking in the years preceding the walk. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It also served as a time to reflect collectively on artistic ideals. We found walking such a distance together helped facilitate a free exchange of ideas_COMMA_ histories and concerns as well as meditative silences. With a full five days of uninterrupted company and commitment_COMMA_ conversation took on deeper proportions._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The days were spent pacing towards the city. Each night we camped alongside the trail_COMMA_ sharing duties surrounding fire and food preparations. We slept five to a tent for warmth. The mornings consisted of stretching exercises_COMMA_ some readings from journals and discussions of trajectory.
column17: I feel that the themes and structure outlined in the Unthinking/Unknowing session are in perfect harmony with my current artistic fascinations. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My most recent work has been focused on the instances in which language fails us. I understand these instances to bear a kind of freedom. Rather than being problematic_COMMA_ I see the 'shortcomings' of language as opportunities to engage with symbolic or associative meaning_COMMA_ to work through ideas that would otherwise be tangled in reasoning or issues of clarity. I am interested in playing with the way the mind accounts for incomprehensible language. I have been trying to write without concern from comprehensibility. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Beyond that_COMMA_ I believe the social nature of the session will allow/insist that I explore more outside of the usual boundaries of pragmatic and poetic language. Early on in my development as a writer_COMMA_ I saw poetry as a mode apart from social instances; though often borne of social instances_COMMA_ I saw writing as a chance to speak outside of them_COMMA_ to speak free of the social restrictions of audience_COMMA_ time and space. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Now_COMMA_ as I become more confident and immersed in poetic language_COMMA_ and develop relationships that allow for more open-ended_COMMA_ exploratory exchanges_COMMA_ I see that it is possible (and deeply rewarding) to bring that type of language into the social context (rather than the other way around). The more I experience it_COMMA_ the more I find myself yearning for social exchange_COMMA_ for intellectual exploration_COMMA_ that allows me to use language unfettered by pragmatism or social mores and to have that kind of language returned in kind. I see this kind of exposure as entirely formative to my identity as a writer_COMMA_ and I suspect that I'll experience it in spades during this session.
column19: An even-numbered group makes a daylight trip to a lake (ideally on foot or bike). _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Upon arrival_COMMA_ the group is divided into pairs and designated either Onshore or Unsure._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Pairs then stake an area of the shoreline within sight but not earshot of the others._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The Unsure is then prompted to share with the Onshore an inquiry_COMMA_ fascination or psychic hurdle surrounding his/her practice._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The Unsure then swims a length of the lake (with option to break on the opposing shore)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The Onshore develops a response to spur the Unsure deeper into his/her inquiry and re-opens the dialogue upon the pair's reunion._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The Unsure repeats his/her swim with a new question in mind._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This cycle repeats until both partners agree they've reached a mental plateau_COMMA_ wall or divergence._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Once each group is done_COMMA_ all partners and roles are switched._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_After this second round_COMMA_ and a period of contemplation/rest/discussion_COMMA_ individuals are tasked with developing a brief affirmation based on their experience in the exercise (with the suggested exclusion of the terms 'I' and 'you')._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Once prepared_COMMA_ the group is divided equally amongst the two shorelines_COMMA_ and asked to pronounce their statements one after the other_COMMA_ across the water.
column20: If you tried with all your might you?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I won't_COMMA_ I might and I wouldn't.
column21: NONE

column12: Hike (A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT)_COMMA_ Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: My name is Kelly Corinda Kraemer. I’m from Long Island_COMMA_ but I have lived in New Jersey for the past six years. I love literature_COMMA_ poetry especially. I like experiments with words and meaning. I look for art that feels as if it is revealed to me internally rather than added to me externally. I try to write poems and plays that make people feel like they are part of a common human experience (an experience that is more based in the idea of humanity than society). I try to be involved in whatever local scene I can and to learn from the artists in that scene. I have lived in suburbs and cities for all of my life and I would like a different experience than that. I think writing a bio is difficult. I am both quiet and friendly. My writing has lately revolved around salt_COMMA_ skin_COMMA_ golden_COMMA_ and ghosts. I have been dreaming of dirty water for a year_COMMA_ but now it is becoming clean. Some things I like are: dresses_COMMA_ card games_COMMA_ hot sauce_COMMA_ succulents_COMMA_ Sheila Heti_COMMA_ dogs of all kinds_COMMA_ mushrooms_COMMA_ sweet basil_COMMA_ myths and legends_COMMA_ foxes_COMMA_ hauntings_COMMA_ idiomatic language_COMMA_ mistranslations_COMMA_ Austin TX_COMMA_ Heather Christle_COMMA_ blood vessels_COMMA_ Richard Brautigan_COMMA_ Roberto Bolano_COMMA_ Yayoi Kusama_COMMA_ tacos_COMMA_ my family_COMMA_ bays and sounds_COMMA_ shells and fish_COMMA_ how one road can take you to any other road_COMMA_ windows_COMMA_ the radio_COMMA_ and infinity.
column14: My creative practice is collaborative because my favorite way to write is through creative games_COMMA_ as well as because I often try to see how poetry can work with other art forms such as theater_COMMA_ music_COMMA_ and photography. Trying to create a kind of art that is not your specialty or that is outside of your realm of experience usually helps you to see your own art in a new and unexpected way. Playing inspiration and communication games with other artists and writers is a good way to shock yourself out of writing ruts (or any kind of artistic rut). I have found that artists of all disciplines work with a certain level of perfectionism and focus_COMMA_ and explaining your vision to someone else- how it is working_COMMA_ or not working_COMMA_ or how you have been changing it as the work progresses- helps you to clarify your own vision. I like to write based on clouds of ideas and I would like to do collaborative sessions that explore similar ideas in different mediums- even if the ideas are very broad_COMMA_ such as using an animal or a color or a local legend as a starting point_COMMA_ and then seeing where each person goes from there.
column15: I think the chapbook that I have been working on is the work that best represents me as an artist that is fit for your program. The chapbook is called vertebrates_COMMA_ and is a collaboration with my sister- my poems and her photography. I wrote most of these poems with the feeling that one thing could be many things_COMMA_ or at least with the feeling that one thing could be something else. I am open to experiments with voice and form_COMMA_ and am extremely curious and willing to learn about almost anything. I think the most important part of writing this was how much I learned while doing it. It clearly doesn’t read as an academic or scholarly work_COMMA_ but to write these poems I first wrote pages and pages of notes on the meanings of different plants and flowers_COMMA_ Pagan and Roman symbols and history_COMMA_ human biology_COMMA_ different forms of reproduction_COMMA_ New Year’s traditions_COMMA_ and ideas about death_COMMA_ among other topics. I also took notes on various readings in nonfiction_COMMA_ fiction_COMMA_ poetry_COMMA_ and drama_COMMA_ and from studies of visual art. I am very curious and excited and interested in learning_COMMA_ and I hope this comes across in my work. I would love to be able to take this to the School of Making Thinking and have a whole month to work and learn in a new and creative environment. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-3JMOVy-UR8NjFxdGdlM0NXWkU/edit?usp=sharing
column16: I have been living with roommates for the last six years_COMMA_ so I am very used to communal living situations. I currently live with eight other people in a house in New Brunswick_COMMA_ NJ. I have lived in two houses where most of the other people who lived there were also artists or musicians: my current house (Jones)_COMMA_ and my house from 2011-2012 (Fire Island). I also briefly moved back to Long Island while I was interning in the city_COMMA_ and very soon after that my house was destroyed in Hurricane Sandy_COMMA_ so I spent six months saving money_COMMA_ replacing possessions_COMMA_ and learning how to be a very polite guest. I know that communal living requires always doing the dishes_COMMA_ even if not all of them are yours.
column17: I am applying for the Between Nature and Culture: Reconstructing Wildness session. I think that this session will help me develop as a thinker and as an artist because it is a topic that I am extremely interested in and would like to explore more. I am a tame person who feels connected to wild things. I am very interested in animals_COMMA_ humans_COMMA_ bodies_COMMA_ and nature_COMMA_ and how they all interact (especially in ways that feel true to the feeling of being alive). I would like to gain a greater background and framework to write about wildness from. Also_COMMA_ I would love to have the sensory experience of being in the Catskills for a month_COMMA_ and to be able to leave having developed new associations and a new vocabulary for describing nature and wildness in my poetry.
column18: The workshop/immersive lecture I want to lead would be based around texture_COMMA_ meditation_COMMA_ and poetics. I would want everyone to collect objects with different textures- stones_COMMA_ grasses_COMMA_ flowers_COMMA_ anything- and then to meditate while feeling those textures. During this meditation_COMMA_ I would like to discuss the different textures and structure/lack of structure present when creating works of art_COMMA_ how much of an influence environment has on creation_COMMA_ and how much control an artist has over the direction their work goes in after it has begun. Possible texts that I would use for this are “Invisible Architecture” by Barbara Guest_COMMA_ “Some Notes on Organic Form” by Denise Levertov_COMMA_ “The Poem as a Field of Action” by William Carlos Williams_COMMA_ the preface to Leaves of Grass by Walt Whitman_COMMA_ and Madness_COMMA_ Rack_COMMA_ and Honey by Mary Ruefle.
column19: The workshop I would lead would be a foraging expedition led by someone who knows the Catskills very well. The Catskills are good for foraging- specifically for ramps_COMMA_ chanterelles_COMMA_ chestnuts_COMMA_ beechnuts_COMMA_ blueberries_COMMA_ strawberries_COMMA_ amaranth_COMMA_ violets_COMMA_ mustard greens_COMMA_ chicory_COMMA_ and dandelions. The communal foraging and eating would be followed by time for personal creation or reflection. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Foraging is a practice that is in the domain of the very “civilized_COMMA_” high-end culinary culture of New York_COMMA_ as well as the wilder history of the area. How can foraging be so completely civilized and wild at the same time? The same question applies to art. Art is a way to express both wild and civil feeling_COMMA_ and indeed expresses some of the most “wild” and most “civilized” ideas of our time and throughout history. Foraging for nutrients_COMMA_ medicines_COMMA_ and decorations also provides a jumping off point for thinking about how creations develop- how you combine what you learn from society and what you gather from the outside world with your own personal tastes to create something unique. A workshop on foraging and its associated rituals would work very well as a way to investigate the questions that the seminar focuses on.
column20: Question: Kelly_COMMA_ how badly do you want to go on the hike and take the Between Nature and Culture: Reconstructing Wildness class? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Answer: Very badly!
column21: None- I have off from work for the whole month of June.
column23: Wheat- but I will happily bring my own bread/pasta

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I am an artist and educator living in Hartford_COMMA_ Connecticut. I feed myself in two ways: First_COMMA_ I am a fellow in the Studio Arts Department at Trinity College. I advise seniors on their thesis projects_COMMA_ am a teaching assistant in Steffani Jemison’s Video Studio course_COMMA_ and install shows on campus. Second_COMMA_ I work in the Hartford Public School district_COMMA_ where I collaborate with high schoolers on murals after school and tutor recent immigrants in classes that include Engineering_COMMA_ Graphic Arts_COMMA_ Biology_COMMA_ History_COMMA_ and Civics._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In my studio I have been working between wet-paint_COMMA_ light_COMMA_ sound_COMMA_ and video to make ephemeral paintings. This performative process is documented in video and sometimes leaves behind still artifacts.The interactions in my work are alchemical_COMMA_ turning awkward mass into luminous gold. Occasionally I inhabit a character made from the materials in my studio_COMMA_ the focus of the lens_COMMA_ and the painterly metaphors of rap lyrics. She is an obscured "video vixen_COMMA_" caught in the act of building the set surrounding her. Sometimes she seems pressed under glass. Sometimes her costume and figure disintegrate into pattern and light. Her studio is one stage upon which she can melt her own violent or tender experience of content and rhythm. She scratches this itch so hard that she peels back the synthetic skin of the image – only to find another layer of vinyl or Formica beneath it. In a moment of weakness she eats the ice cream she intended to paint with. A jug of acrylic paint slips from her hands and spills. She reaches for it_COMMA_ in a power grab._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am still trying to elucidate the nature of this power. Sometimes it seems contained within the space of the screen_COMMA_ and sometimes it extends into the substance of inarticulate social interaction.
column14: I am applying to SMT as one half of a collaborative duo with Samer Sabri. We began working together as undergraduates at Yale University_COMMA_ and together we have explored a broad range of ideas by creating novel questions_COMMA_ objects_COMMA_ and contexts. In the past_COMMA_ each of us has claimed “authorship” over works we have created collaboratively. We are ready to claim dual authorship_COMMA_ and to attempt to make unauthored works._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Samer has been a character in my videos and has helped me figure out how to situate the works in space during installation. My videos are highly visceral_COMMA_ and their placement in relationship to the human figure is not incidental. I’ve helped him think through computer games and produced the layout and the graphics for some of them. We maintain an ongoing dialogue which catalyzes every stage of our individual processes. We've learned to present ideas to each other at earlier and earlier stages of our creative process and have gotten used to thinking of the other person as the one who helps narrow things from a vast universe of possibilities_COMMA_ rather than the one who simply shifts the course of a work that had already embarked upon a particular path._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_All of my work depends upon augmentation by others. When my collaborators come before the camera they are self conscious. I often set up a narrow space and set of gestures within which others may act. My lens captures the blank stare that originates from a moment caught off guard. Human frailty in a “glamorous” moment is what lends the work its humor and its tragedy. My practice is about timing. Sometimes it is rhythmic timing. Sometimes comic timing. My own beat falls into and out of alignment with that of those surrounding me.
column15: The Work: http://ilanahb.com/UNTITLED-INSTALLATION-2012/solo_NEWLINE_Password: SMT2014_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I worked with Zimbabwean artist Rebecca Aston to make an interactive light installation at the Yale School of Art. Programming was unexplored terrain for me before embarking upon process that led to the work. It began when our personal ways of forming light in space collided. She was saw the code first: its ability to track and to mimic. I had been focusing on the ways light framed and tracked a body moving through space._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_We responded to the ways individuals navigated space in the School of Art. Where was movement predictably directional? On the stairs. On which staircases were people in a rush and on which did they meander? We were privy to the spoken and unspoken collaboration of the students moving through the building. We projected light and saw what happened._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_We tried to capture the hypothetical sensation of existing as silhouette in Hype William’s dizzying video for the crunk hit “Snap Your Fingers.” The result was a projection which tracked the shadows of people as the moved down the stairs with a rainbow of flashing colors that disappeared as quickly as they arose. The work blinded visitors as the moved up the stairs. All the while_COMMA_ the screeching_COMMA_ yet addictive beat looped endlessly in instrumental._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This project came to mind when I came upon the passage on “Collaboration/Individuation” on the SMT website. While working with Rebecca (and learning from those who encountered our work by happenstance)_COMMA_ my own personal voice was articulated with new-found clarity. Collaboration simultaneously defined and expanded the boundaries of my practice. I believe this occurred because of a willingness to change directions in response to feedback rather than get stuck upon prior work and expectations. Our joint efforts were additive_COMMA_ rather than oppositional.
column16: When I was 17_COMMA_ I spent 6 weeks living in the Telluride House at Cornell University. The program was free. I lived with 29 students_COMMA_ reading theory_COMMA_ cleaning house_COMMA_ and finding our own voices. The course I took_COMMA_ “Caribbean Dialogues[.com]” was taught by two Jamaican art-historians named Petrine and Petrina. A key part of the program took place outside of the classroom_COMMA_ in the echoing victorian house we inhabited._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As high school students_COMMA_ we were responsible for deciding collectively how we wanted to interact with the academics we were given access to. We cooked our meals and had a say in how the program budget would be allotted. Some early proposals included spending all funds to fill a room floor to ceiling with ping-pong balls. All choices were determined during evening meetings which sometimes stretched 8-12 hours. We would vote_COMMA_ debate_COMMA_ and vote again in an attempt to reach a kind of consensus. We almost never slept_COMMA_ drifting in a fog full of new ideas. This experience cemented a belief in me that in small communities where mutual respect is a given_COMMA_ massive mistakes and grand triumphs are possible in small amounts of time.
column17: One question posed by the course description excites me in particular: can we embody wildness? In many ways_COMMA_ it seems as though we create the wild. It is formed on every edge by the boundaries of what we deem ordered. And so_COMMA_ if it is we who make wildness_COMMA_ can we make ourselves if we choose to embody the wild?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My practice will benefit in several ways from SMT. The work Samer and I have embarked upon together can grow in an environment which does not place a premium on creation’s adherence to a specific discipline. The process-oriented nature of the session aligns with the way we work. Everything begins with conversations about a larger theme. Sometimes there are tangible remnants of these conversations. Sometimes all that is left is an immaterial lens through which new ideas can be viewed._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My practice will benefit from a process which seeks to let go of “self-constructs.” Many of my videos chart a kind of hyper accumulation of self-construction. I attempt to capture in the moving image the visual and emotional congestion which occurs when one is acutely aware of being gazed upon: so much so that the screen they stare out from becomes an endless mirror to posture in front of. I want to attempt to break this mirror_COMMA_ pick up the shards_COMMA_ and see what is reflected there. Perhaps in this gesture my work might find a new way to approach wildness._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Samer and I have written a purposefully porous proposal. The work we will do at SMT will be greatly shaped by the way others move through it. Where my work has previously been about pushing up against the hard membrane of the fourth wall_COMMA_ I would like to see what happens when it is pierced completely.
column18: n/a
column19: We are interested in the historiography of addiction and its relationship to notions of wildness. Is the addict one who has fully tapped into her inner wildness_COMMA_ or one who is completely submerged beneath systems of organization?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The perceived pervasiveness of addiction is seated in societal anxiety. People choose to cling to the trope of an autonomous self making decisions independently. Faced with the utter failure of this model_COMMA_ they decide that the only kind of person that exists outside of it is the addict_COMMA_ the one of with no control. They thus end up turning every possible tendency and desire into a potential or actual addiction._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_We want to create a series of “addictive games” which will unfold amongst the community at SMT. Later_COMMA_ we will write “code from conversation”; computer games whose structure responds directly to the play as it unfolds._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The games will be inflected by the broken rhetoric of 12-step programs_COMMA_ and influenced by Halberstram’s notion of fruitful failure. 12-step programs frame addiction as an accepted and unilateral state of being. We will build a program that seeks to cure the anxieties framing addiction_COMMA_ rather than the addict herself.
column20: Samer’s question for me: How can repulsion and attraction be polar opposites yet coexist?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A shivering_COMMA_ goosebumped fear spreads through me when I encounter certain patterns. It’s the allure of things that seem organic yet eerily ordered: shapes that remind me of cells reproducing uncontrollably. When I see a scary pattern_COMMA_ my mind returns to it for hours. I have to relive the experience_COMMA_ often sharing an image with people I know share this disposition. Google “Trypophobia.” Many people think trypophobia was willed into existence by internet hypochondria. For me_COMMA_ the fear is real_COMMA_ and so is the allure.
column21: I foresee no conflicts with this summer's scheduling.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I was raised in Lebanon_COMMA_ and I recently graduated from Yale University where I double majored in Computer Science and Ethics_COMMA_ Politics & Economics. I am currently a 4th and 5th grade math teacher in a Lebanese public school._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My technical background is in mathematics_COMMA_ theoretical computer science_COMMA_ and systems programming. I am currently branching out to web programming and writing games for my students_COMMA_ using the “game mode” they get into to teach them math._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I have been devoting a lot of energy to improving life and learning in my classroom. I’m always trying to see what my students see and steer them to what they need to see with the least amount of pain necessary. That means creating silly games_COMMA_ computer games_COMMA_ stories_COMMA_ or activities for new ideas to make sense._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Each day I obsessively break ideas_COMMA_ events_COMMA_ or thoughts down into their most basic components. This habit ties into my background in philosophy. I work in a circular way; meaning that I focus on patterns that are repeated across very different domains. These patterns often even end up appearing in the very structure of my thoughts about them_COMMA_ thus creating a motif akin to a fractal._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I write my philosophical ideas on a blog called “The Analyst of Random Things” (tartisme.blogspot.com)_COMMA_ and I also write a blog on Lebanese and regional politics (in which I am very engaged) called “A country of strangers” (acountryofstrangers.blogspot.com)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am starting as a Business Analyst for McKinsey and Company in Silicon Valley next fall; I think that will allow me to continue improving as a communicator and a problem-solver. I am particularly excited about learning to conceptualize solutions to “systemic” problems because they are intellectually fascinating and they plague my region of the world.
column14: I am applying to SMT as one half of a collaborative duo with Ilana Harris-Babou. We began working together as undergraduates at Yale University_COMMA_ and together we have explored a broad range of ideas by creating novel questions_COMMA_ objects_COMMA_ and contexts. In the past_COMMA_ each of us has claimed “authorship” over works we have created collaboratively. We are ready to claim dual authorship_COMMA_ and to attempt to make unauthored works._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I have been a character in Ilana’s videos and I have helped her figure out how to situate the works in space during installation. Her videos are highly visceral_COMMA_ and their placement in relationship to the human figure is not incidental. Ilana has helped me think through computer games and produced the layout and the graphics for some of them. We maintain an ongoing dialogue which catalyzes every stage of our individual processes. We've learned to present ideas to each other at earlier and earlier stages of our creative process and have gotten used to thinking of the other person as the one who helps narrow things from a vast universe of possibilities_COMMA_ rather than the one who simply shifts the course of a work that had already embarked upon a particular path._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My philosophical practice has increasingly been centered around making sense of the work concepts-in-the-world are doing and how their almost illogical_COMMA_ absurd underlying structure functions. The world of quotidian thought functions much more within that shifting_COMMA_ polymorphous universe than within one of cleanly ordered_COMMA_ axiomatic definitions. I want to keep digging and try to understand it better. This process is impossible without conversations with people about how things become important_COMMA_ and it is in these conversations that I am closest to the structures I am constantly trying to unearth.
column15: I was taken by the statement “Learning is an openness of one’s identity to other’s practices and projects” on your website._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_For my senior thesis in Ethics_COMMA_ Politics_COMMA_ and Economics_COMMA_ I wrote about responsibility for structural injustice (http://bit.ly/MCxGAL). In short_COMMA_ structural injustice occurs when social relations (unfairly) advantage one group over the other overwhelmingly in many dimensions. Structural injustice is_COMMA_ in the vast majority of cases_COMMA_ outside of the control of a single individual or a narrow group. Ending a structural injustice usually requires some form of collective action._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In my thesis_COMMA_ I try to provide a good conception of individual responsibility for structural injustice; my solution is rooted in virtue ethics. I think this work represents me well because it emphasizes that the questions I focus on are questions that I mull over in my daily life and that I believe everyone ought to think about._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I also use several different ways of progressing through my ideas: Chapter 1_COMMA_ where I explain why a virtue ethical approach is ideal to solve the problem_COMMA_ is much closer to analytical philosophy_COMMA_ with definitions and arguments that are clearly stated and structured. Chapter 2_COMMA_ where I argue for the particular “virtues” I have selected - such as “putting background conditions into question” - I use what I call a dialectical approach. I also include frameworks and arguments from other domains_COMMA_ such as game theory and mathematics (pp. 60_COMMA_ 61_COMMA_ 62) or English literature (pp. 66_COMMA_ 67_COMMA_ 78)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I really enjoy making connections between and borrowing methods from very different disciplines and sources to think about a question that’s too “human” and multifaceted to be confined to one discipline or approach. Through my way of working_COMMA_ I can contribute to – and gain a lot from – being at SMT.
column16: Last summer_COMMA_ I went on a backpacking trip to South-East Asia and Eastern Europe with my roommates from college. We’d lived together for the past 3 years_COMMA_ but this trip was a radically different experience. We were nomadic: together from the moment we woke up to the moment we went to sleep for 6 weeks. We had never been to most of the countries we visited_COMMA_ and had very little time in each place. We had to make decisions all the time: where to sleep_COMMA_ what to see_COMMA_ what to eat_COMMA_ how to respond to crises_COMMA_ how to get to the next place._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I think that we knew each other well enough that we knew when to delegate concerns to the right person and trust that person. For more difficult sticking points_COMMA_ my place in the decision-making process was to step out and refine – almost formalize – positions and objections to help the debate stay focused. We strove to find the most satisfying answer rather than the most satisfied victor. We learned to pick our battles and avoid nitpicking when not important or urgent. This trip made us all more patient and better at decentering ourselves.
column17: I think SMT is the best place for me to get better at thinking across fields and methods. Working with Ilana has allowed me to realize that I tend to enjoy instrumentalizing mental content. I am often trying to fit ideas into a framework that includes a thesis_COMMA_ arguments_COMMA_ and counterarguments._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would like to get to a place where I’m exploring with a wider scope of ideas without being constantly on the lookout for “the point” or “the right answer.” This is where the concept of the wild comes in. This concept poses a complex question: the “wild” is very often used to designate a territory that is foreign but also meant to be subdued; is there a way to “open” ourselves up to what we designate as wild without trying to “conquer” it?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Even if that means letting go of the concept of the wild_COMMA_ is there a way to access this territory while respecting its integrity? It seems to me that if there is one_COMMA_ it has to come with a complete change in our mode of consciousness; our mode of appreciating the world.
column19: We are interested in the historiography of addiction and its relationship to notions of wildness. Is the addict one who has fully tapped into her inner wildness_COMMA_ or one who is completely submerged beneath systems of organization?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The perceived pervasiveness of addiction is seated in societal anxiety. People choose to cling to the trope of an autonomous self making decisions independently. Faced with the utter failure of this model_COMMA_ they decide that the only kind of person that exists outside of it is the addict_COMMA_ the one of with no control. They thus end up turning every possible tendency and desire into a potential or actual addiction._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_We want to create a series of “addictive games” which will unfold amongst the community at SMT. Later_COMMA_ we will write “code from conversation”; computer games whose structure responds directly to the play as it unfolds._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The games will be inflected by the broken rhetoric of 12-step programs_COMMA_ and influenced by Halberstram’s notion of fruitful failure. 12-step programs frame addiction as an accepted and unilateral state of being. We will build a program that seeks to cure the anxieties framing addiction_COMMA_ rather than the addict herself.
column20: Ilana’s question for me: Please provide an in-depth description of the sensations you felt during a time you were lost in the act of making._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Recently_COMMA_ I got stuck on the 6th problem of this online programming contest: https://www.hackerrank.com/contests/feb14. For 4 days_COMMA_ I spent all of my free time working on it. Deep in a black hole_COMMA_ I wasn’t weighing my choices. I pursued an almost visceral urge to keep trying_COMMA_ testing_COMMA_ and retrying. I became nothing more than this cycle of problem-solving. Only as I drifted into sleep did my sense of self reappear.

column13: I'm a thirteenth generation American. My ancestors came over in Winthrops Fleet_COMMA_ just ten years after the Mayflower. They eventually settled in Northern Vermont_COMMA_ where the winters are long and cold_COMMA_ and they coped with the isolation by telling each other stories. Tall tales_COMMA_ true tales_COMMA_ absurdist yarns (complete with talking raccoons)_COMMA_ and uniquely American war stories (Paul Revere is an ancestor) were my inheritance. Yet_COMMA_ I was uniquely drawn to visual storytelling in a way that was unheard of in my family. I studied Art History in undergrad_COMMA_ and went on to work in art galleries in London_COMMA_ New York and Los Angeles. While in LA_COMMA_ I started taking classes from Judith Weston author of "Directing Actors" and directed some plays for her theater. I was completely hooked. I applied to NYU Grad Film_COMMA_ got in_COMMA_ and I recently graduated. In the last two years I have been scrambling to make money (those student loan collectors are relentless!)_COMMA_ and to start a Directing career.
column14: Filmmaking is_COMMA_ by its nature_COMMA_ collaborative - and thats the best part of it. There is an electricity_COMMA_ when one crew members idea spark’s anothers and then anothers_COMMA_ and soon you are creating something together that is far more resonant than any of you might have created on your own. That kind of interconnected creation is what drew me to filmmaking in the first place.
column15: I’d like to show you my short film Crazy Glue. https://vimeo.com/22425398_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Crazy Glue is based on a short story. Prior to it I wrote all my own films... but I got myself into a little trouble when I wrote a film about my family. Though the film came out well (audiences responded well - I will never forget watching the waves of laugher as the erupted in the theater - it was a profound kinetic and cathartic experience for me) my father was displeased. Since then I have had trouble opening up and channelling such truths. I am not sure what makes me fit for your program_COMMA_ but I do know why I need a program like yours. I want to open up again_COMMA_ and brave channeling the truth of my own experience. Your residency feels like a place to take risks.
column16: Every living experience I have ever had has been communal. I have always had roommates - at one point I even lived in a factory loft with 10 photographers! I like to laugh and I value the unintended interactions that are a part of everyday when you live with many people. I like that a casual conversation around the toaster can spark a great idea. When you live alone you have to bring all the magic yourself. Its possible_COMMA_ but not nearly as fun.
column17: I am applying for Between Nature and Culture // Reconstructing Wildness and Unthinking/Unknowing because I am intrigued by both of them and well convinced that they could both do my imagination some good._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_At this point in my Directing career my job is to write a screenplay that is a pure expression of my voice. Squeezed in in the hours around my paper pushing day job_COMMA_ I fear my writing has become stilted_COMMA_ stale_COMMA_ a room in desperate need of an open window. It lacks surprise. It lacks wildness. Its too full of knowing and lacks the essential unknowing. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A residency with other artists and thinkers would help me let the magic back into my tired brain_COMMA_ I believe. In my work I strive to delight an audience. I don't think that is a frivolous pursuit. Making sense and un-sense_COMMA_ if you will_COMMA_ of the world is the artist job. We must reframe human experience in a way that enlightens it. But to do so we must be channeling these thoughts ourselves - and that is why I hope to do a residency at The School of Making Thinking. I love the idea of being in a place to run wild_COMMA_ physically and intellectually_COMMA_ and seeing where that takes me and my work.
column19: Well_COMMA_ I would like to write_COMMA_ and interact_COMMA_ and write_COMMA_ and interact_COMMA_ and write. I have a New England story in my head - but I need to get out of NYC and stand on New England dirt to give it space to be born._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I've also long had this idea of open air plays for a small audience. For instance staging Tennessee Williams "27 Wagons Full of Cotton" on a back porch at dusk. I love the idea of an audience that is out in the weather - feeling the air on their skin in a really intimate environment_COMMA_ hearing the crickets chirp as the sun goes down_COMMA_ watching a beautifully performance of a well written text. There is an intimacy in that that reminds me of sitting around the fire listening to my grandparents and uncles tell stories when I was a kid. A primal storytelling experience. In fact_COMMA_ instead of putting up a Williams play_COMMA_ what I'd really like to do is write a play for the occasion myself. It'd be fun to even have it be a "walking play" where the audience has to_COMMA_ unexpectedly_COMMA_ get up and follow the actors into a field (where the play continues) and then into a cave (where it culminates). Something like that would be cool.
column20: Why is storytelling important?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A story can_COMMA_ within minutes_COMMA_ plop us into the shoes of someone with entirely different life experiences and show us what the world feels like_COMMA_ looks like_COMMA_ smells like from their perspective. More that anything else it can shift bigotry and hatred toward understanding and compassion in really unobtrusive_COMMA_ organic ways. Storytelling teaches empathy_COMMA_ which is critical for a humane world. it also shows you that you are not alone - that the root of human experience is similar. Storytelling is also a vehicle for providing an audience with a little bit of magical thinking_COMMA_ which the drudgery of their daily lives might have washed away from their everyday thought process (thats my favorite part!)

column13: Hello. I'm Cassie. I'm a 31 year-old teacher_COMMA_ audio producer and multimedia artist. I live in South Brooklyn with my two dogs and my friend_COMMA_ Sarah. I'm originally from Madison_COMMA_ WI and lived there primarily until I was 25. I was raised by liberal hippies and decided I wanted to be a radio host after watching Molly Shannon and Ana Gasteyer host Delicious Dish on SNL. What great turtlenecks! _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Radio is my jam. I have been co-hosting and producing a live_COMMA_ queer_COMMA_ feminist radio show called Romantic Friendship for three years. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am also currently finishing up my M.F.A. in Integrated Media Arts from Hunter College. My thesis is an hour long radio documentary about my family's experience in an evangelical Amish mennonite settlement in northern Florida in the 1950s. It's an exploration into group identity_COMMA_ belonging_COMMA_ and the Amish values that live on in my family. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_For work I teach: radio production_COMMA_ new media_COMMA_ and journalism at SUNY Old Westbury_COMMA_ and robotics to elementary school students. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I love to be outside and walk in the woods. I also like knitting very simple things_COMMA_ drinking beer_COMMA_ and making hand-made birthday cards. Most things are political to me and I like to have fun_COMMA_ sexy conversations about life and politics.
column14: My longest standing and most intensely collaborative project is my radio show_COMMA_ Romantic Friendship. My co-host_COMMA_ Sasha Wortzel_COMMA_ and I conceived of the project together three years ago_COMMA_ and have made all decisions around content_COMMA_ production and distribution together since. It is both challenging and extremely rewarding to work collaboratively on this show. There have been moments of frustration (and near demise) – but for me_COMMA_ the collaboration is what keeps the show going. It gives energy and life to the project. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Being a live radio show_COMMA_ we are also collaborating with our guests and the community of hosts and project managers at BBOX_COMMA_ our radio station. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I teach media production at the college and community level – and this is also a collaborative process. In this role_COMMA_ I am actually providing space and guidance for my students to collaborate with each other. I have learned so much about how to be effective in this role in the last few years. When I started I was way too hands-on_COMMA_ and stressed out about making sure the final product was top-notch. This distracted from my students ability to experiment and be creative! I feel much more confident now in respecting the process – rather than focusing only on the end product. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Funny side-note_COMMA_ I opened my CV yesterday to update and upload_COMMA_ and remembered I had given myself the tagline “audio producer_COMMA_ teacher_COMMA_ collaborator.” Made me chuckle a little.
column15: Links: _NEWLINE_http://sogsounds.com/_NEWLINE_http://www.prx.org/pieces/101233-farmer-confession-booth-i_NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In 2013 I was selected to participate in the Andes Sprouts Society residency_COMMA_ a program based on the idea of bringing artists and farmers together to create new ways of thinking about food_COMMA_ agriculture and the natural world. The main project I created during the residency was SOGS – a daily recording project that combined documentary and sound meditation. I also mounted a “Farmer Confession Booth” for our barn art show_COMMA_ and showed a short film about the foodways of my Amish-Mennonite grandparents – projected onto the side of the barn. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As residents of the farm we also worked on the farm and at the farmers market. The combined experience of creating art and being part of a working farm community was beautiful and stimulating.
column16: In 2009 I worked for the Montana Conservation Corps as a Youth Crew Leader. I spent many weeks out in the field with my crew_COMMA_ which consisted of six teenagers and my co-leader. During the day we build trails and fences_COMMA_ and at night we cooked_COMMA_ ate_COMMA_ played_COMMA_ did lessons_COMMA_ set-up and took down camp. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_What worked? Silliness. Unstructured time to balance out the structured time. Going to bed early so we could be alone in our tents. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This was a particularly interesting communal living experience because of the gap in age and cultural background. One night it was my turn to cook and I made quinoa. None of them had ever heard of it before_COMMA_ much less eaten it. The next day everyone was pooping_COMMA_ a lot_COMMA_ and I became the subject of many jokes about poop-inducing hippie food. I wanted us to eat healthy out there_COMMA_ but in the end I compromised and started making pasta instead. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I had a more traditional communal living experience living at a cooperative house with 32 other people in Madison_COMMA_ WI. We shared food_COMMA_ supplies_COMMA_ cooking_COMMA_ communal spaces and decision-making.
column17: I am drawn – in both body and brain – to the “Between Nature and Culture // Reconstructing Wildness” session. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Last year at my residency in upstate New York I tapped into a community of artists and farmers with strong ties to both country and city. As a native Wisconsinite – and someone who has spent their life canoeing_COMMA_ hiking_COMMA_ and chasing dogs – I feel a similar “pull.” And yet_COMMA_ I am learning to see these urges (to country and city) not as diametrically opposed_COMMA_ but as mutually constituted. They exist together. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I tap into a different kind of creativity when I am in nature. My city self is frenetic and pop-culturey_COMMA_ fueled by a turbulent and productive anxiety. My wild/nature self is . . . more physical. Less scared. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_One thing that sounds exciting about the session is the opportunity to work with artists who work in more physical mediums – especially dancers and musicians. I have a background in both (from way back) and I wanna stretch these muscles.
column19: I definitely want to sing_COMMA_ especially outside_COMMA_ and combine voice with environmental soundscapes. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Also: feminist bookstores. Two years ago I started a documentary film about A Room of One's Own Bookstore_COMMA_ in Madison_COMMA_ WI – a place I used to work and one of the oldest feminist bookstores in the country. They had recently moved locations and doubled in size_COMMA_ at a time when feminist bookstores all over the country were shutting down. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The story of this film is about survival_COMMA_ adaptation_COMMA_ and crafty/shifty ways of changing meaning and connotation through time. I'm interested in our narratives around natural selection – and how we apply this biological model to economics and society. What happens when we equate natural selection with capitalism?
column20: What can chihuahuas teach us about our wild selves? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_People often think that my little dog is wimpy and fragile. He appears that way when he's walking on his leash in his little pink coat. But take of the coat and the leash – and he is a sure-footed little creature. He climbs mountains and trots through snow!

Please note that it was part of a performance project and the video images start at 2:15._NEWLINE_https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-TiT29wr2g1WExNRXE2ZWJETXc/edit?usp=sharing
column13: My work revolves around portraiture_COMMA_ both of people and places_COMMA_ within the realm of community-engaged art. I started out in this work of portraiture 10 years ago_COMMA_ when I left university studies and made a documentary about what it means to be an artist_COMMA_ from the perspective of 4 homeless men in Dallas_COMMA_ TX. In the years since_COMMA_ I lived in Philadelphia and worked for a college prison education program that brings university students and incarcerated students together as peers for intergroup dialogue. I was also teaching art in the Philadelphia jails. I received a grant in 2008 for a portrait project in the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia_COMMA_ using plants growing on the roadsides and lots of the neighborhood to dye silk. I created a series of 10 portraits of neighborhood residents using batik_COMMA_ embroidery_COMMA_ and applique. (Please see the Kensington Portrait Project on my website.) I will be exhibiting this work in Philadelphia summer of 2015_COMMA_ and will be collaborating with residents to design the exhibition. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I moved to Toronto in September 2013 to pursue a graduate degree in Environmental Studies at York University. My program requires that students create and fulfill research towards a self-designed plan of study. My work is currently focused on how to intervene in cycles of social violence using arts-based approaches. A main question of this work is how patterns of thought and action are maintained_COMMA_ and ways of intervention that can allow for new_COMMA_ yet unexplored_COMMA_ avenues to emerge. My focus and realm of inquiry for this work is on group and collective-based approaches to social intervention. My artwork in exploring this topic includes performance_COMMA_ video_COMMA_ textiles_COMMA_ and installation_COMMA_ with a focus on testimony and witness.
column14: In my work in prison education_COMMA_ my role was to facilitate group processes and coordinate collective projects. Influenced by educational practices of facilitation and curriculum development_COMMA_ my approach to research and artistic practice is oriented towards the creative capacity of groups. My practice is community-engaged and oriented towards impact on social issues. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My process begins with conversations_COMMA_ either individual interviews or group conversations_COMMA_ around a particular question or set of questions. (A question I’m currently working with along with others is_COMMA_ “How can we understand social violence as a form of addiction_COMMA_ and what are markers of this historically and culturally?”) From this collective dialogue and input_COMMA_ I work by myself to develop mediums and processes of exploring the topic artistically_COMMA_ and create a body of work in response. Sometimes my individual practice is a form of research for understanding the question more deeply_COMMA_ and sometimes my own work enters back as working material for a larger group process. The original question becomes expanded and deepened_COMMA_ and enters back into collective art production and exhibition or performance. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It is an important way of learning for me to work with other artists_COMMA_ offering feedback or entering collaboratively into their processes. I learn from the methods and mediums that other artists use and I see the process of working in community on individual or collective projects as exponentially enhancing each person’s growth.
column15: My most recent work_COMMA_ completed in December 2013_COMMA_ and to be exhibited at York University in April_COMMA_ is called “Safety Net”. This work explores trust and risk in relationships. In line with my process of working collectively_COMMA_ I designed a series of performance-based workshops exploring personal narratives in ways that asked participants to take risk in revealing and telling their stories in public settings. Participants gave me feedback that the collective process allowed them to make actions and speak in ways that they would never have otherwise done_COMMA_ especially in public. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I documented the group workshops from above in video_COMMA_ as way of gaining visual representation of how people choose to take risks in relation with others. I then projected this video onto a wall and traced the movement of people through space using thread and pins_COMMA_ as a way of creating a more tactile and aesthetic sense of individual choices and collective movement around risk and trust. I made a second video of this pin and thread process as a form of self-portraiture that then became the backdrop for a performance piece. In this 10 minute performance_COMMA_ I kneeled on the floor in a darkened room in front of the projection and read letters about risk and trust in a personal relationship of mine with an incarcerated friend. (Please see the link to the video work.) _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This work was a way for me to explore the potentials and challenges for collective work that depend on the willingness of individuals to trust and make relational risks. “Safety Net” was also a way for me to take risks as a facilitator and artist_COMMA_ because I was choosing an entirely new way of working. This was my first work of self-portraiture.
column16: In summer 2013 I lived for 3 months with 12 other people at the Herb Pharm in southern Oregon. This was an internship on medicinal plants_COMMA_ and involved farming for 8 hours a day_COMMA_ 4 days a week_COMMA_ and intensive evening and weekend classes. As a group_COMMA_ we were responsible for cooking_COMMA_ cleaning_COMMA_ shopping_COMMA_ and organizing our household. We all lived together in a large house with shared rooms. Each person was responsible for cooking breakfast and dinner for the entire group 2-3 days out of the internship. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I also co-facilitated a two week undergraduate study abroad program in La Paz_COMMA_ Bolivia. For this project about 12 students all lived together in a guest home in the city and shared quarters and coordinated creative works amidst a collective living environment.
column17: After working in the context of prisons and jails and in community-engaged art projects looking at how to address and change social problems_COMMA_ I’ve arrived at a line of questioning on how to intervene in dominant notions of reality. I’ve been engaging ideas of systems thinking of late_COMMA_ and through this literature I’ve discovered that the highest levels of intervention in social and environmental problems is in changing consciousness and ways of thinking. So far I've discovered that this requires the letting-go of control and allowing new arrangements of human_COMMA_ plant_COMMA_ and animal relationships. Artistically_COMMA_ it requires a willingness for improvisation_COMMA_ and as “Safety Net” highlighted_COMMA_ a willingness to take risks on the unknown. The Unthinking/Unknowing session seems directly related to my work and line of questioning about the role of art in social intervention. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The residency will aid in my development by allowing me an extended time to enter into these conversations creatively_COMMA_ and allow me the space and time to explore these themes of intervention and consciousness through an embodied and collaborative process. I think it is very important to work with others in exploring the question of how we think and how we take a leap into the unknown_COMMA_ since collective intelligence and creativity allows and provides for new ways of action. I hope that that the residency becomes a space for me to create a project or small body of work that can enter into my work as an artist-facilitator with community groups.
column19: I envision a project that involves the mapping of geographic landscapes in juxtaposition with conceptual maps around a particular topic such as “connection” or “interdependence”. This project would engage collaborators in multiple interpretations of the theme in various mediums_COMMA_ including photo transfer of symbolic or metaphorical images_COMMA_ along with the cutting and rearrangement of geographical or topographical maps. It might also include pictures and diagrams of plants or bodies in relation to each other. Other mediums would include music and choreography exploring connection in time and space. The final work would be an exploration of themes of interdependence that emerge from the group process around questions and challenges of social action. The final exhibit would be an installation and performance venue_COMMA_ with the goal of offering new options and ways of thinking about how to define self in relation to landscapes and other living beings.
column20: What is a map?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A map is a way of understanding the meaning of physical_COMMA_ emotional_COMMA_ and cultural terrains. A map can show the body_COMMA_ the land_COMMA_ social environments_COMMA_ mental landscapes_COMMA_ and cultural representations of perception and reality. Always situated within and exhibiting a social worldview_COMMA_ maps can show how people create and share meaning. Stuart Hall speaks of “shared maps of meaning” or the representations of reality that people understand in relatively synonymous ways within cultural contexts. Mapping can be used as a method of exploring notions of time_COMMA_ space_COMMA_ place_COMMA_ and identity.

column13: I am an academic and creative thinker. My PhD deals with 19th century photography and queer representation. My creative practice_COMMA_ as a curator_COMMA_ looks at queer history through contemporary art practices. As an artist_COMMA_ my creative practice needs nurturing and has been dormant for too long._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My PhD work is isolating_COMMA_ often resulting in working in a kind of vacuum. While in many ways it's part of the process_COMMA_ I am not convinced it makes for the best work. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As a die-hard city dweller_COMMA_ nature is challenging to access. I live near Lake Ontario and spend summers reading_COMMA_ staring into the distance on an urban strand that simultaneously hideous and stunning. I long for the smell of nature_COMMA_ long walks and noticing small things in grass.
column14: I often work collaboratively. I've worked with Kelly McCray for many years as co-curators. We founded The Transmission Commission Collective and have worked on several projects. The collective has a "rolling membership_COMMA_" where artists_COMMA_ writers_COMMA_ curators join forces with us for specific projects. Among them_COMMA_ InTents City-an outdoor installation of pjeg's from around the world dealing with the AIDS crisis (8 members). Rare & Raw-an exhibition at the Leslie Lohman Museum for Gay and Lesbian Art (2 members). And_COMMA_ upcoming in June 2014 Hit Parade-an exhibition examining global cruelity against LGBT communities (3 members)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Further_COMMA_ I was part of a collective Shake-n-Make that took 1970s iconography to look at trauma. (3 members)

column16: I have lived in several communal queer houses. I like sharing food_COMMA_ hanging out_COMMA_ etc._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_While I have had many experiences with communal living_COMMA_ I do need some private_COMMA_ alone space._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The only thing that has ever been in the way of communal heaven is a dirty kitchen.
column17: I think it is the balance between togetherness_COMMA_ separateness. Sitting together talking over dinner and quiet walks. I envision a sense of inspiration garnered through new people_COMMA_ new sights and fresh smells
column19: Vintage photography session with 4 x 5 cameras_COMMA_ brownie cameras from the 1920s_COMMA_ pinholes_COMMA_ tin types and daguerreotypes. Making pictures about the death of analogue in an environment filled with joy. Make shift outdoor_COMMA_ light secured darkrooms where you can still smell flowers through the chemicals. working together and seaparely._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Group project; an massive camera obscura set up in a barn or something. Nothing fancy_COMMA_ just some natural light from the barn slats_COMMA_ time passing_COMMA_ people hanging out and enjoying the magic.
column20: February in Toronto has stolen my imagination. It feels like it will last forever_COMMA_ will it? Why can't I break through this terrible feeling?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It's not your fault. Winter can be cruel. Ride this (frozen) wave and spring_COMMA_ like it does every year without fail_COMMA_ will come. Hold tight.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I'm a Toronto-based artist whose work is informed by personal narratives_COMMA_ fictive memories and the fabled imagination. I've worked in performance_COMMA_ sound_COMMA_ film_COMMA_ and sculpture/installation_COMMA_ and am currently developing a film/installation project that revisions various narrative tropes from pop-cultural fictions and traditional fables_COMMA_ and explores the relationship between humans and mythological animals._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I live in the city’s west-end with my partner/fiancé and our rescue cat_COMMA_ Atari. I’m a vegan. I also have a day job as an office manager of a naturopathic clinic_COMMA_ which enables me to explore my interest in natural and alternative healing. I’m particularly interested in herbalism and metaphysical healing._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I’m currently reading 'Kafka on the Shore' by Haruki Murakami. My favourite albums released last year were Rhye’s Woman and Neko Case’s The Worse Things Get. I am also pro-Beyoncé.
column14: In many of my past performance pieces_COMMA_ I’ve collaborated with other people as direct participants as well as audience members. Those performances often took place in the public sphere_COMMA_ and whether they were more participatory or solitary_COMMA_ relied on others to help activate these moments._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_These days_COMMA_ my work has become less focused on direct interaction and more engaged with the possibilities of traditional media_COMMA_ such as sculpture and film. To that end_COMMA_ my collaboration with others has shifted mainly to that which is peer-based_COMMA_ through conversation where ideas are shared and feedback is provided.
column15: mountains and hillsides enough to climb' (2003) was a performance wherein I ran an ad for four weeks in the classified section of the Montreal Mirror_COMMA_ a free alternative weekly_COMMA_ that read: SEEKING PEOPLE FOR 3-LEGGED WALKS. I arranged to meet interested individuals in public spaces around the city_COMMA_ and upon meeting_COMMA_ we secured our ankles together and walked. The walks lasted anywhere from1 1/2 to 4 hours._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Inspired by the 3-legged races regularly featured in my elementary school activities_COMMA_ 'mountains' sought to emphasize community over competition. While during typical 3-legged races_COMMA_ each ankle-bound pair are cooperating in order to compete_COMMA_ the participants in a 3-legged walk are simply cooperating. Removed from its original competitive structure_COMMA_ these 3-legged walks brought various strangers and myself together_COMMA_ cooperating for the simple sake and pleasure of walking. Along with having to negotiate factors such as touch_COMMA_ stride length_COMMA_ speed_COMMA_ and direction_COMMA_ the insertion of our temporarily conjoined bodies into a familiar locale facilitated a re-imagining of how to aimlessly wander the city._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_'enough to cross_COMMA_ enough to last' (2007) took place in Banff_COMMA_ Alberta_COMMA_ and was an extension of 'mountains'. For this performance_COMMA_ I solicited certified hiking guides to go on private 3-legged hikes with me. The hikes lasted 1 1/2 to 4 hours_COMMA_ and took place on various trails of different levels of elevation gain and intensity. During our hikes_COMMA_ the guides provided a verbal narrative of the trails we were on. Along with the physical challenges of navigating mountainous terrain while bound at the ankle_COMMA_ my intention was to complicate the assumed manner in which official tours of Banff trails were normally experienced_COMMA_ and present a form of new logic with the insertion of two temporarily and purposefully conjoined bodies in the landscape._NEWLINE_http://beckyip.ca/enough-to-cross-enough-to-last
column16: I’ve spent some time volunteering on organic farms through the organization_COMMA_ WWOOF. One summer a few years ago_COMMA_ I volunteered on a few organic farms throughout Ontario with a friend. One of our stops was at an eco education centre in Eastern Ontario called Earthwalk. The centre attracted different people who arrived and left at different times. Some of us slept inside and some of us tented outside. Meals were prepared_COMMA_ eaten_COMMA_ and cleaned up together. Each meal took place at the dining room table. We would begin by choosing someone to select a card from the Angel Oracle deck to read aloud. Then_COMMA_ each of us would state an intention or reflection_COMMA_ and together_COMMA_ we’d give thanks before eating. This centre was also in the early stages of building an eco village about an hour’s drive north of where we were. We travelled to the village together_COMMA_ set up camp_COMMA_ and spent some time volunteering there as well.

I’m also interested in the complex relationship between plants_COMMA_ animals and humans_COMMA_ and in exploring their implications in artistic practice and daily life._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A thematic and technical departure from my previous work_COMMA_ these current investigations are also informed by my own relationship to plants and animals_COMMA_ mythological and real. column13: I’m a female artist from China. My art is all about self-identification_COMMA_ but my artwork is never about me. I utilize my person as a mark to allow others to recognize their own form of life: I become their medium. I am always very clear about that. As the only child in my family_COMMA_ I want to describe my loneliness_COMMA_ and the pressure my generation encounters. We_COMMA_ as twenty first century generation_COMMA_ have no choice – we need to be confidence_COMMA_ and as the fastest speed as we can to catch the new industrial revolution and new technology. We can’t wait creating the mass productions and want everything in the fast roll. Yet what is the result_COMMA_ what’s the intention to live life in this way? The whole country of China seems like so peaceful_COMMA_ but we actually are not as happy as we seem to be. Our natural environment got destroyed; the pure religion got destroyed; we are crashing everything ……_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Personal becomes political. What I am doing_COMMA_ and when I am doing_COMMA_ become a political theme. As the patriarchal society in China_COMMA_ I choose the famous and strange places to take a photo of myself jumping in the air_COMMA_ and do the same pose like the sculpture I discover. I want to make something ironic to question the reality: what is right? Why do I do something just like other people expect me of doing? What is the reality? Is that my sculpture or the person jumping in the air?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My current body of work explores: Chinese culture versus American culture_COMMA_ my female sex versus abstract sculptures_COMMA_ and Chinese Communism politics versus only one child generations. My ironic performances isolate myself as a female in China within extreme natural landscapes_COMMA_ such as the Yinchuan desert and the Qin Shi Huang mausoleum. My practice deals with issues of identity_COMMA_ politics_COMMA_ cross-culturalism_COMMA_ and the surrealistic characteristics of my body in the ever - changing environment.
