column13: I am an artist and thinker whose practice is conceptual_COMMA_ experimental and research based. My work has undergone the process of being purely representational to becoming phenomenological in essence_COMMA_ hence sometimes immaterial in its brief experientiality. I am after embodied research_COMMA_ walking being my prime methodological tool. My practice aims to find ways to communicate my belief that the process of thinking is yet another sense_COMMA_ and not the purely mental activity that rationality is understood as in our culture. It attempts to find ways of reuniting the body and the mind through work that is both experiential and intellectual in nature and reception._NEWLINE_I am interested in hybridity and impure systems as ways of survival and endurance —mainly as sources of sustenance. I find duality and established categories of subjectivity/objectivity to be at the core of Western culture’s inadaptability to the future on earth. I am searching for ways of being in the world that are less dysfunctional_COMMA_ both as an individual and within the social as body. My practice is geared towards building opportunities to nourish one or several of the means of experience a person has available to align_COMMA_ disalign_COMMA_ realign_COMMA_ that person’s patterns_COMMA_ including myself. It aims to find ways to attune to behaviors and find transformative ways to new ones. Lately I am focused on the process of being in nature and spending time with it as a learning possibility to enable behavioral awareness and change. I believe a critical/rational understanding of any given situation needs to be coupled with an experiential and embodied process. The benefits brought about by a durational exchange nature~human_COMMA_ while searching to understand this relationships from a non-hierarchical perspective_COMMA_ will allow a more balanced understanding and mode of being. I hope this therapeutic process will bring reciprocity to the relationship.
column14: I believe in the interrelatedness of all live and inert beings. In this sense existence is a collaboration between a particular space and time and a particular state of being within a dynamic system —all in constant flux. This engenders positive and/or negative_COMMA_ long-term and/or immediate_COMMA_ outcomes. Within this framework_COMMA_ and speaking only of intra-species collaborations_COMMA_ I collaborate daily with my family_COMMA_ friends_COMMA_ peers_COMMA_ colleagues_COMMA_ neighbors and fellow New Yorkers as well as with absolute strangers_COMMA_ aiming to have the scale lean towards the positive —nurturing the life aspect._NEWLINE_On the creative/intellectual side_COMMA_ as a process where 2 or more persons tackle together an idea from different viewpoints_COMMA_ working within a set of similar parameters and the common will to an outcome of sorts in mind —with partial or total effacement of individual authorships— I see my practice as highly collaborative. Formally and phenomenological I have consciously engaged in collaborative work with colleagues in walks_COMMA_ writing poems_COMMA_ and composing music/performances under the framework of indeterminacy and blind collaboration that Cage and Cunningham are well known for. I have also collaborated in a formal curatorial project for the exhibition “Notations_COMMA_ the Cage Effect Today_COMMA_” and informal events involving communal walking_COMMA_ foraging and cooking (“What mushroom? What Leave?”). I am currently researching embodiment as knowledge generator in collaboration with an artist/preacher_COMMA_ engaging in field and theoretical research walks; and participate in a collaborative shifting group (IWT) for specific projects. I consider exchanging feedback about specific work —as in a studio visit— to be a collaboration of sorts._NEWLINE_Also I highly consider the visible/experiential portion of my practice to be collaborative in a dialogical sense_COMMA_ in that participants are invited to take part as conscientious performers where the outcome is dependent on the participant_COMMA_ yet indeterminate and open.
column15: PRESENT_COMMA_ 2008-09; MoMA PS1_COMMA_ NY._NEWLINE_During 9 months I sat for four hours at a time reading to myself (full list of titles here http://bibicalderaro.com/artwork/1426296_Present.html) and writing my instantaneous thoughts in a typewriter. I was searching for the roots of the financial collapse of 2008-09 in our economic system: Greek philosophy_COMMA_ the Enlightenment; reason as pure thought; reason as only possibility for thought and knowledge; ethics and epistemology. The writings were offered to the public as a gift_COMMA_ a copy of all typewritten pages given away was kept aside and later bound together in an artist book_COMMA_ and published in the paperback PRESENT. All typewritten pages are now an expanded poem that resides in the homes of those who attended the performance._NEWLINE_PRESENT is a multidimensional performed essay where I attempted to reduce the exuberance of thought to words; it’s a durational poem that gives thought a chance to communicate; it’s language as membrane and thought as sense; it’s a bridge between the left and right hemispheres_COMMA_ between the rational and the intuitive_COMMA_ between the past and the present_COMMA_ between form as stasis and form as a floating_COMMA_ changing dimension._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_-WALKING AS KNOWLEDGE (text~walking)_COMMA_ 2013_COMMA_ Bs.As. Argentina_NEWLINE_This performance revolved around the reactivation of texts selected from Librioteca Pineal (http://www.ciacentro.org/node/1239). LP houses books about aesthetics_COMMA_ theories of perception_COMMA_ epistemology and environmental ethics._NEWLINE_Fifteen artists were invited to participate in a collaboration that was part chance_COMMA_ part agency_COMMA_ as we walked_COMMA_ read and interacted with the urban environment. The participants chose titles from LP to do loud readings at first sight within the group_COMMA_ in the street._NEWLINE_The weaving of texts juxtaposed with the street landscapes and changing neighborhoods makes walking a way of knowing as performatic process.
column16: My most recent determined isolated act of communal living was participating in the Walking Seminar_COMMA_ during the summer of 2013_COMMA_ in Puerto Rico._NEWLINE_The WS was a pedagogical experiment that invited 12 international artists to participate during 3 weeks of walking in PR. We walked out of San Juan heading East and South_COMMA_ camping at unspecified sites for 3-4 nights at a time._NEWLINE_The exposure to the intimacy and endurance of camping in non-campground places_COMMA_ without running water or bathroom_COMMA_ challenged the group in severe ways —many members had never camped before. As well_COMMA_ exposure to differing cultural patterns and language barriers made this experience an interesting mini-social laboratory._NEWLINE_Individual and group responsibility_COMMA_ ethics and trust are key components that I highlight as important elements in a communal living experience that thrives to engage the creative. The WS lacked the organization and transparency needed to allow or support these. Yet_COMMA_ my own personal synthesis of this experience recovers the incredible potential of camping as restorative and creative process —both at an individual and group level— while understanding the importance of a clear mission statement and the need for determined facilitation of leadership —or_COMMA_ again_COMMA_ the clear disclosure of its absence.
column17: My practice is based on the liminal spaces of the in-between —the gaps left by silence and non-doing— to understand processes of formation and transformation of body_COMMA_ thought and matter. I work on such fluctuating processes understood within the biological construct of the membrane as hinge_COMMA_ bridge_COMMA_ connector_COMMA_ to contextualize the production and categorization of knowledge and of being._NEWLINE_Currently I’m searching to make sense of thinking as another perceptual sense with which humans are equipped to experience and “know” the world. I’m also after understanding how being in nature can develop into a process of reciprocal attunement that facilitates changing old behaviors and/or inventing new ones_COMMA_ including that of thinking. Methods to create new patterns of thought and behavior interest me in particular_COMMA_ in the search for truly innovative ways of being in the world oriented to an ecology based on post-humanist ethics._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Thinking/not thinking and knowing/not knowing are fluid concepts that may happen in solitude yet may be enhanced by dialogic correspondences with people and environment. The process of communicating any such instances require at some point the need of naming; this use of thinking in its making is of utmost importance in my practice._NEWLINE_I would like to be able to further challenge this understanding as a methodology and pedagogy. Also_COMMA_ in practicing this understanding_COMMA_ I would like to help shape its theory._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Participating in this residency would allow me to collaborate with fellow artists and thinkers in this direction_COMMA_ while developing an understanding of differences that will make any theory and practice more robust. To engage in knowing/not knowing_COMMA_ thinking/not thinking_COMMA_ naming/not naming within a durational_COMMA_ immersive experience would immensely help shape the research I am proposing as a practitioner of art and thought.
column20: How does a threshold shift/change?_NEWLINE_Given that the world is a continuum in which we exist_COMMA_ I am only speaking of humans’ understanding(s) of the world._NEWLINE_The durational aspect of this question and its potential answer(s) make it difficult to establish one particular way in which a threshold changes. What interests me is the embodied nature of the dialogical self_COMMA_ how we embody experience from perceptions that become emotions and behaviors_COMMA_ into fabricating “knowledge_COMMA_” sets of paradigms fixed to a given reality._NEWLINE_Walking in nature as method of realigning emotion/behavior/knowledge production into a dynamic understanding of sets may bring answers.

column13: I am a multimedia artist from Rio de Janeiro_COMMA_ Brazil. I think of my work as a construction of processes or encounters that mean to reach a state of questions. Through creating opened games that take participants out of their comfort zones_COMMA_ I experiment different possibilities of interactions with the other_COMMA_ what is around and the idea of intensity. These processes might or might not be documented and can take forms such as video_COMMA_ installation_COMMA_ performance_COMMA_ interactions_COMMA_ happenings and other hybrid ones. I was living in New York for that last 2 years while doing an MFA program in Fine Arts at SVA and just moved back to Rio de Janeiro. I will have my first solo museum show in Rio this month_COMMA_ after winning a grant from Caixa Cultural.

column15: Thoughtfeeling workshops were first developed at SMT in 2012 and I have been reshaping them according to space and people since then. These are long silent interactions for 2 people (preferably strangers) with a specific space exploring the notions of spasms of life_COMMA_ presence_COMMA_ closeness and sleep. The workshops are site specific and the space around is a strong influence on what will happen. Participants have their notebooks to communicate through writing with each other and have to stare at each other’s eyes for the whole experience. Thoughtfeeling workshops are not documented.

column19: I would make an event in which everyone should be sleeping or trying to sleep. For that I would design the most comfortable lying down space. Then both live and recorded sound and image performances would happens as well as delicious massages on their foots and shoulders. The performances would all be very subtle and quiet_COMMA_ in a dreamy mood_COMMA_ mixing simple gestures such as breathing and looking to reading very complex philosophical texts. The viewers could choose (consciously or not) where in the spectrum between sleeping and awake they would be. In the end they should write down any dreams they could remember that would serve for inspiration for the next event. The invitation would be something like - "take some rest from yourself".
column20: How can one experience presence? How is this related to an encounter with the other? How can one experience life without becoming immune? What happens to one's life when openness and un-immunity play fundamental roles? To which extent is it possible not to protect oneself? To what extent is this healthy? - These are the fundamental questions of my art practice_COMMA_ one leading to the other_COMMA_ the answers are not fixed ones and come to me creating contradictions as new experiences happen so I would prefer not to answer.

column13: As a moving image artist_COMMA_ I construct a vocabulary utilizing audio-visual fragments._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Initially_COMMA_ language seemed to be something secret. My father is a first-generation Iranian immigrant to the United States. My mother is American. Language in my household was frequently confused. My father’s first language is Farsi. Often_COMMA_ I heard Farsi spoken but I did not know how to access its meaning; I was not taught the language. Its sounds_COMMA_ unfamiliar and pure_COMMA_ were structured in a rhythm and pace that felt like a secret code. How do you access meaning if you do not know the code? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The entanglement of movement and my creative impulses started to highly develop at age ten when I decided I wanted to be a modern dancer; I dedicated myself to serious study. I played the role of pantomime_COMMA_ reaching out to express while keeping silent. In my late teens_COMMA_ I developed anorexia and bulimia. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Developing my illness and getting help was a realization that I did not know how to speak; I never had a voice of my own. During my undergraduate studies_COMMA_ I delved inward trying to find what was important to me. The answer came back to language and movement_COMMA_ but now embodying images and sounds. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Working with the moving image is a complex process in structure-making and concept-building. I often think of my process as a form of collage. Ultimately_COMMA_ my work questions authority: who or what is visible/heard_COMMA_ and who or what is invisible/unheard. How do these positions create an in/ability of action? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In Fall 2013_COMMA_ as an Iowa Arts Fellow_COMMA_ I initiated my studies at the University of Iowa in the MFA Film and Video Production program. I am exploring the moving image as a language_COMMA_ which communicates voice as a body of image and sound structures.
column14: Collaboration appears throughout my practice in many forms. In one sense_COMMA_ there is the collaboration between my conceptions and the technology I am engaging with to manifest these visions. Experimentation with formatting_COMMA_ software platforms_COMMA_ sound feedback_COMMA_ etc require a lot of trial-and-error and manipulation of various tool sets. Working with equipment_COMMA_ keeping footage organized_COMMA_ and consistently locatable is a constant challenge I face and without digital technology I would not be able to do what I do. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In another sense_COMMA_ when I am constructing a video piece_COMMA_ getting feedback from my peers and professors is an important ongoing conversation I engage with. This allows for an open forum of thought to be presented while also helping me question what I am making_COMMA_ really helping me see what is in front. Work can become difficult to read during the process of its making. Having a few voices you trust to help you sift through the mess of thoughts going on in one’s head is a great help._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Lastly_COMMA_ as far as working with another on a collaborative project_COMMA_ I am currently incorporating more hands-on multi-crew projects. Working in the theatre and designing sound for a stage play was a jump in another medium completely_COMMA_ but engaging with a community of artists who posed many questions to me to were looking for answers I could provide to shape an overall vision. It was taking what I know and applying it to the needs of the play’s text. Essentially_COMMA_ adding an elemental framework within a framework. At this juncture_COMMA_ I am working on a performance piece with my colleague Kasia Plazinska. Both of us have never done a project quite like this before_COMMA_ so we are building it from the ground up together each step of the way.
column15: Human Body Battleground Organ Organism_COMMA_ 2013_COMMA_ 9m 30s_COMMA_ dv_COMMA_ appropriated collage_NEWLINE_https://vimeo.com/77166279_NEWLINE_password: exhausted in this unfolding_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The following moving image work was created in a self-directed production course during my first semester in graduate school_COMMA_ Fall 2013. As the title notes_COMMA_ the body is the subject matter of interest. But not a body we can easily define or depict a corporeal presence. More so_COMMA_ this body is a body of image and sound structures that begin in a state of declaration but reveal the fissures of language structures throughout its duration. The Human Body Battle—work demonstrates how a sense of playfulness_COMMA_ humor_COMMA_ with a heavy dose of biting subversion permeates my work. Here they blend together creating a voice_COMMA_ which instigates a complex set of questions upon the viewer rather than posing closed answers. _NEWLINE_Here is the synopsis: Human Body Battleground Organ Organism is an appropriated moving image collage investigating the penis and vagina as disembodied vessels. By utilizing a digital voice to enact this estrangement_COMMA_ a narration of declaration generates a questioning of definitions_COMMA_ where sound and image structures dismantle and reveal a deconstruction of audio-visual form and subject's signification._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Currently_COMMA_ this work is on tour with The Black Maria Film Festival.
column16: Every summer from the age 12-18_COMMA_ I participated in a “dance lock-in” with my fellow dancers. The lock-in was a mixture of celebration for all the hard work and effort we put into our dance training during the year but it was also an exploratory moment for us to creatively express ourselves by ourselves_COMMA_ to be the authorial voices of our choreographic jams._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Imagine_COMMA_ at any hour of the day for three days_COMMA_ collaborating_COMMA_ choreographing_COMMA_ goofing around_COMMA_ practicing and costuming a production number with your best friends. We were locked in our dance studio with no adult intrusion on our creative project. We were creating a dance production from the ground up. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_At the end of the three days_COMMA_ we had the showcase dance recital. It was a blast. This kind of communal living_COMMA_ even though temporary and for a short period of time each year_COMMA_ it was the event I looked forward to most. Getting to work together_COMMA_ be together_COMMA_ and celebrate our love of dance was very special to me and I understood that it was something not everyone got to do_COMMA_ to bond with those they deeply admired about something they deeply admired and live it together.
column17: I am most interested in participating in Unthinking/Unknowing seminar. For me_COMMA_ my art practice correlates to a type of unthinking/unknowing with each project I start. It is through my art making I explore a conception that I do not know how to decipher. It is only through the process of building_COMMA_ piece by piece_COMMA_ that any answers/resultant bodies of texts reveal themselves to me. Even though I predominately work on the screen_COMMA_ I am interested to further expand my practice to involve multi-media performance where the incorporation of my body_COMMA_ moving images and sounds will affect a space with which I am engaging. This seminar explores the unknowing body_COMMA_ movement_COMMA_ and thinking that is involved in my way thinking and making at the current moment. Participating in this will allow for bother professional and personal growth for me and I look forward to the possibility to engage with this open forum of questioning.

column13: Hi SMT_COMMA_ my name is Alex_COMMA_ which is short for Alexandria. I enjoy being able to use a more androgynous name because it fits my androgynous nature (or nurture). I bring up gender initially_COMMA_ here_COMMA_ because it is/has been shaping my work and life-questioning. Without going too much into social imaginary_COMMA_ I think that identity constructs are deeply rooted and mirrored by nature. Without an external social infrastructure_COMMA_ who would I/we be? a rock (genderless)? or a tree(maybe genderless)? or the heart of the forest itself? I would argue that identity or re-identity is summoned by spiritualization/reawakening/rebirth/revolution and the way I see it_COMMA_ you have to find that inside of the earth_COMMA_ inside of your skin. To sum myself up (right now)_COMMA_ I'm into rediscovery_COMMA_ however applied_COMMA_ but I'm dabbling with ideas of collective re-identity as alternative education. And my favorite color is all shades of green. And I box on the weekends.
column14: The genre that my work is most often categorized in is conceptual or performance art. My aesthetic investigation always involves the human body and its interaction with other bodies_COMMA_ human or not. Most of my projects are collaborative in some way. I’ve produced a few projects that literally involve the aid of another person for the entire process from brainstorming ideas to prepping gallery walls. Though_COMMA_ what I find most interesting about my practice is that most solo pieces become collaborative in the final stages. I think that is a big distinction of performance art from other forms of live art_COMMA_ be it theatre_COMMA_ dance or otherwise. The audience participates_COMMA_ unknowingly or not_COMMA_ in the summation of the project. For example_COMMA_ a street intervention piece can be premeditated and conceptualized up until the point of performance. Then the window that has been left cracked open allows for the viewers/audience to alter the course of the work. A swelling crowd_COMMA_ a snickering adolescent_COMMA_ a snail or a frog’s unexpected interaction can change what is ultimately seen and interpreted through the lens of documentation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A more explicit and relevant example of this happened during a project set in a remote area in the Georgian forest. The intention of the piece benefited from isolation to highlight ideas of reclusivity and fear. However_COMMA_ I was not actually afraid. On the day of the performance_COMMA_ a group of hikers stumbled upon my performance. The shock and/or fear (due to costuming) that became present from both parties had an effect and enhanced_COMMA_ in my opinion_COMMA_ the outcome of the piece. The link to this project can be found here: http://amberry03.wix.com/portfolio#!trickster/cnvv
column15: This first link I've provided below is a project with brief description called Divided Actions. I think it reflects the conceptual nature of my work and examines some core ideas relevant to what can be imagined at "A Summit on a Summit" hike_COMMA_ such as mapping_COMMA_ wandering_COMMA_ and collaboration. The project was originally conceived in a class environment to then be ripped to shreds by Marina Abramovic in a studio visit. So we advanced the original project (following strangers as spectacle) to becoming invisible stalkers_COMMA_ think Sophie Calle or Vito Acconci. I liked how it turned out._NEWLINE_Link 1: Divided Actions_NEWLINE_http://amberry03.wix.com/portfolio#!divided-actions/c16ln_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My second link below is another more recent project called iMapping (implicit mapping) that also involves following and mapping but hyper-focuses on the abandonment of social constructs. Like Divided Actions_COMMA_ I am following strangers but this time in a large metal encasement on wheels (my car). There's something about the protective shield that one's personal car can provide. In this context_COMMA_ it's a safety bubble. It’s an external_COMMA_ literal and metaphorical framework preventing my body/self/ideas from touching yours. I give this project as an example for “A Summit on a Summit” because it is an extension of thoughts formed originally from the nature wandering in the first project I’ve provided_COMMA_ Divided Actions. And I’ve asked myself a number of times whether I consider the unknowing participants of these projects (the persons followed) to be collaborators. Essentially_COMMA_ yes_COMMA_ but it’s something I’m still chewing on._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Link 2: iMapping (implicit mapping)_NEWLINE_http://amberry03.wix.com/portfolio#!imapping-implicit-mapping/c1r6c
column16: I would say that the majority of my adult life (post-undergrad) has been some form of communal living. And because of this_COMMA_ I've found myself often at the doorstep of family and friends that will take me in for short spurts of time. More specifically_COMMA_ during the past few years as a graduate art student_COMMA_ I've lived out of my car_COMMA_ had a run at living in a 2 bedroom city townhouse in Atlanta shared by 6-8 people_COMMA_ and crashed the majority of the time at a sculpture studio at my school (Savannah College of Art and Design). _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_More appropriate to this question though_COMMA_ is my 6-week residency in rural India where a group of international artists shared a space that was an empty library--can you even call a library a library without any books? We were told it was a failed attempt by an ambitious NGO but nonetheless_COMMA_ the 15 to 20 mosquito nets gathered on top of individual decorated mats will paint my memory for years to come. As a supplementary note_COMMA_ chai was absolutely the connecting source for the residency_COMMA_ some would say food_COMMA_ or the art produced_COMMA_ but I say chai.
column17: I am applying for 'A Summit on a Summit" hike for a few reasons. For one_COMMA_ I am interested in Guy Debord's or the Situationist idea of the derive and psychogeography. As an expansion of urban wandering_COMMA_ to wander within and among a sensuous landscape develops this solopsistic platform in the mind. I want to find and develop chaos here. I want to stumble upon and create order here. And more importantly_COMMA_ I would like to bare witness of this development with other thinkers. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My opening-up process for discovering new ideas involves a liminal step-by-step process --which follows van Gennep’s rites of passage: separation_COMMA_ transition/unlearning_COMMA_ reincorporation or reidentity. The process is usually in environments that border nature and civilization_COMMA_ like paths within forests_COMMA_ human-made grooves in trees. The process is often solo_COMMA_ so I question how the shifts in identity and unlearning identity can transfix and become valued as a group. As mentioned before_COMMA_ I consider my work to be collaborative in general but usually that collaboration comes into being at the final stages of production or during the performance itself through audience participation. But it has been atypical for collaboration to occur in the thinking process_COMMA_ the initial stages of conception. I'm curious to change/experiment with the process of conceptualizing prior to a project with other vigorous thinkers/artists. I'm interested to watch and interact with the blank stage in others' minds_COMMA_ and how they begin to fill that stage when actively engaging_COMMA_ moving with our **animate environment. Is it a replication of what is visually seen? Is it possible for us to see/envision/feel the same thing? And aiming towards the social realm of my practice_COMMA_ can our inevitable differences be processed in this way as post- "ist"_COMMA_ e.g._COMMA_ racist_COMMA_ sexist_COMMA_ ageist. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_**Just as a distinction_COMMA_ I don't think I believe in inanimate things.
column18: My mobile workshop deals with fear as an inherent part of our identity and how it aids our understanding of rupture. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Questions that help structure what rupture is and can be:_NEWLINE_1) The physical body goes for days without food_COMMA_ how can you sooth that rupture? What is hunger in the context of this hike?_NEWLINE_2) Light enters the eye through the cornea_COMMA_ what happens when the cornea is ruptured (lights out)? Can you imagine other areas for light to enter?_NEWLINE_3) If a specific group_COMMA_ say the people hiking_COMMA_ is a concrete community _COMMA_what could rupture them/us? Do we fear this separation? What would bring us back together?_NEWLINE_4) To me_COMMA_ the largest rupture of all time occurred as a nick of the skin underneath a mustached man whose prejudice initiated one of the largest atrocities of human history. A metaphorical nick_COMMA_ an irritation that erupted in hate-fever. How do we bring that fever down?_NEWLINE_5)Some symptoms of traumatic rupture are loneliness_COMMA_ anxiety_COMMA_ disorientation. Can we orient each other by disorienting ourselves? How?_NEWLINE_6) Imagine fantasy without nature_COMMA_ what is it?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Potential exercise:_NEWLINE_The act of eating is often a congregational meeting. We nourish each other through conversation and company while eating food. What changes when the act of communal eating is merged with the eating process itself? I feed her_COMMA_ she feeds me; she feeds him. What changes when this process is used for one meal? Two meals? Every meal? What happens when we skip a meal_COMMA_ when rules are ‘enforced’ in one of our basic needs?
column19: N/A
column20: Q: By engaging in alternative learning situations are we approaching freedom?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A: Do we attempt to rid of the institution_COMMA_ with its rigid lines and frameworks_COMMA_ its premeditated system of order? Do we seek to demolish it’s walls to rebuild our own? Or to exist without a social structure at all (is that even possible and if so what does it look like?) Or do we simply seek an equal seat in the house? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_ARE WE SEEKING RELEASE OR ARE WE SIMPLY WANTING AN EQUAL SEAT IN THE HOUSE?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I seek release or I simply want an equal seat in their house.

column13: I am a performance-based artist living in Montreal. Formally_COMMA_ I am trained as a dancer and choreographer_COMMA_ making embodiment the primary application in a practice that has become seamlessly interdisciplinary. My performances negotiate the real with the spectacle and target the psychosomatic using gesture_COMMA_ video_COMMA_ collected objects_COMMA_ slide shows_COMMA_ milk_COMMA_ love letters_COMMA_ tape recordings and most recently microwaves. I superimpose narratives of illness_COMMA_ consumption_COMMA_ the self and the feminine using a cross-referential logic of sign symbols. Either as a mantra or a mode of mechanical reproduction I find it necessary to repeat words_COMMA_ images and gestures over and over. Meaning is never the same but also nothing new is ever created. I enjoy this perplexity._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I value both those things that are understated_COMMA_ and those that are overstated. I search for a real feeling but I also like punch lines and entertainment. I consider performance mostly as a situation made up of signs_COMMA_ which include the people_COMMA_ action and that which we sense (see_COMMA_ hear_COMMA_ smell ect…). I look to create disorientation by subverting those signs. Disorientation allows for re-orientation and this is where we see the politics of performance. Politics are embodied. Lately I am interested in the economy of performance via the potentially assigned values of gesture. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My days are made up of the following activities in any set of combinations:_NEWLINE_Drinking coffee_COMMA_ running up the mountain_COMMA_ going to the studio_COMMA_ performing my "waitress to pay the bills" performance series_COMMA_ eating beautiful food and making love to my lover. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I work alone but also in collaboration with the collective WIVES_COMMA_ performing regularly in various venues including galleries_COMMA_ lofts_COMMA_ theatres and music venues. Currently_COMMA_ I am preparing for 8-hour durational performance titled “digestion/liquidation” which will be performed in Toronto as part of FADO’s emerging artist series “11:45”.
column14: Firstly_COMMA_ for the past year I have been considering the performative situation_COMMA_ as one in which there is a perpetual reversal of power and vulnerability reciprocating between the audience and myself/the performer. I like to create situations where these empowered/vulnerable positions get thrown back and forth like a hot potato. In this way_COMMA_ opposites inform each other while equal meaning and value is ascribed to both. I need my audience and often ask them to participate by singing me songs_COMMA_ or closing their eyes while I make costume changes_COMMA_ reading the letters I give them_COMMA_ and letting me draw them. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Also_COMMA_ I would say that my decision making process often depends on testing things out on peers and friends. I like to know how they respond to visual_COMMA_ textual and gestural ideas because I feel like potential meaning is collaboration. It could never be my doing alone. Meaning is created out of the collective experience of something. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Finally_COMMA_ I work in close collaboration with the members of WIVES collective_COMMA_ to make experimental theatre and live and video performance. When we perform together we are one. It is quite indescribable but I will say that this state it is enabled by a certain quality in me wherein I allow myself to be lost completely into someone else.
column15: https://vimeo.com/63187000_NEWLINE_This video_COMMA_ titled “yes”_COMMA_ features a mirrored image of myself committing the repetitive gesture of slapping my own face. The gesture seems violent at first but through repetition attains a certain ambiguity and meditative or therapeutic quality. This image is accompanied by subtitled dialogue between the identical images. The two selves both ignore each other’s statements and finish each other’s sentences. The “conversation” is rendered into an elucidation of something unspoken. There is no specificity_COMMA_ only sentimentality. I am talking both to myself and to someone not present. For me this work responds very specifically to the School of Making thinking’s summer residency on UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING because for me it occupies a space that I will potentially never understand. I am thinking but it is not yet a thought in a way that the thought may be a thing and furthermore in the way that a thing-thought might be understood. For me linking a gesture or movement disembodies the text. In a sense it disallows the text from attaining any finite or concrete meaning. It this way it proposes something entirely outside our thoughts. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_https://vimeo.com/81539404 _NEWLINE_This is a video documentation of installment 7 of my performance series called “i feel sick”. It was performed outside the AGO in downtown Toronto as part NXNE ART in June of 2013. I’m selecting this work to include in my application because I feel it represents how I offer my gestures to others/the public in a way the gives them lots of space. I am definitely present yet unimposing. This signifies to me moreover_COMMA_ a certain kind of calm reflection I do through action and in dialogue with others.
column16: In 2010 I moved to Guatemala to work with adventure tourism project. During this time the project (made up of myself _COMMA_another leader and 3-5 participants) would spend half the week_COMMA_ for 8 weeks in the highland cloud forests where we would hike up to a camp with all our food and sleep in tree houses. Every morning I would teach yoga to everyone. We cooked all of our meals over that fire and hiked to water spring for our water. The project would then spend the other half of the week in a village where I would coordinate volunteer programs to teach art and English to children._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In 2012 I moved to Joshua Tree_COMMA_ California with my partner who was working on a earth dome building project. There I cooked meals for the 6 builders. My partner and I slept in one of the 3 small ‘pod’ domes on the site. In all we were 7 people living on a 2-acre plot of land_COMMA_ sleeping in a combination of domes trailers and tents. We had electricity for a small part of the day when we turn the generator on.
column17: My keenest interest in the session theme is in the application of philosophy to somatics in a creative structure. One of the goals of my practice is to find a quality or type of movement/gesture that is embodiment of it’s own meaning; movement that does not create meaning through representation. I am interested in creating movement that moves freely through the entirety of the body but is still actively ‘real’ and in so responsible to the situation around it. I imagine a readable pedestrian gesture that gets swallowed by a dance vacuum. My intuition tells me that a way towards this is through creating a unique logic that responds to a specific mind/body inquiry –such as “how can we think what we don’t know how to think?” Likewise_COMMA_ the question could be changed to “how can we act/move/gest what we don’t know how to think?” That being said I think the topic of the residency is absolutely appropriate to help me direct myself towards this particular creative objective of mine._NEWLINE_On another note_COMMA_ I feel my practice would benefit tremendously from the open and communal structures of the residency. When I create a performance it is often for a particular context_COMMA_ with a particular audience in mind. It is very seldom that my creative impulses arise solely out of themselves and have space to develop organically. I often feel like I am making a show and I would like to_COMMA_ during the course of the residency_COMMA_ explore questions instead.
column19: Given UNLIMITED FUNDING_COMMA_ I would build a large glass pyramid in a field. The pyramid would be large enough to house about 10 people. In this rectangle these people would be executing a choreography of independent and partnered gesture_COMMA_ centered on the task of putting thumbtacks in balloons and blowing the balloons up. Culminating into an endurance performance_COMMA_ the performers would fill the balloons until the space is full from floor to ceiling. Some of the movement involved in this performance puts the balloons at risk of popping –especially if they blown up to maximum capacity. There would be a live recording of the space that would be broadcasted to the outside but re-mixed in via programming to play in super slow motion. I would install cameras inside the space (gopro cameras maybe?) and would later edit the performance footage into a video_COMMA_ in such a way that a narrative might be suggested between the performers and the space.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I am fascinated with the body as a site of infinite wisdom and a living archive of experience. Whether in stillness or in movement_COMMA_ the body is the most accessible_COMMA_ intimate and tender medium through which I learn. Lately_COMMA_ I have been learning through a desire to embrace some of the tensions and contradictions (felt most viscerally in the body) between the wild and expansive nature of the imagination and the material realities_COMMA_ histories and political context within which I find myself. I am currently exploring ways of using these tensions as a means for creative resistance and transformation. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In tandem with this curiosity around tension comes my attraction to language as a medium of expression_COMMA_ learning_COMMA_ healing and growth. I love the process of pressing up against the rigidity and limitations of words; the release within a structure. I love investigating_COMMA_ disassembling and unraveling words_COMMA_ and delight in watching them form on a page or tumble out of our mouths as if of their own volition. I love feeling contained by language_COMMA_ and using that container as a catalyst for discovery.
column14: Whether I work alone or in direct collaboration with others_COMMA_ I understand the entire creative process as inherently collaborative. Every element_COMMA_ every image and idea is somehow informed by_COMMA_ and infused with_COMMA_ the infinite sources of inspiration that emerge from everything around me that is alive: the people_COMMA_ insects_COMMA_ trees and sunlight. Beyond inspiration_COMMA_ I am joyfully indebted to the constructive criticisms and feedback from those with whom I share my practice. This is instrumental in keeping my work authentic and alive._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_There is also the magic that I experience during moments of collective presence in performance. I treat my role as a performer as one which cultivates a space of presence_COMMA_ establishing contact and provoking invitation into the realm or reality created in the performance space. So I see the generative process of creation as well as its product as constantly collaborative.
column15: One of the more recent tangible manifestations of things I have been feeling/thinking that relate to the SMT_COMMA_ and especially the “Between Nature & Culture” theme_COMMA_ is the research_COMMA_ writing and exploratory exchange I have undertaken since last Fall. This is centered in learning through a few Indigenous women’s writing of prose and poetry as a means of sensitizing ourselves to the connections between the body and land. This work emerged out of a course I took on Indigenous Traditions_COMMA_ Women & Colonialism_COMMA_ and continues to spiral out in various forms of research_COMMA_ writing_COMMA_ and embodied experience. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This project has served an ongoing process of experimentation with the use of language as a tool of invitation into experiential learning. In this way_COMMA_ I have been exploring and sharing how words can work both to maintain as well as subvert colonial ways of thinking and being. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_So far_COMMA_ this project has taken the form of a paper entitled “Beyond a Fear of the Wild: Reading Indigenous Women’s Writing on Body & Land”_COMMA_ which I will share on a panel on Indigenous Women and Resistance as part of Concordia University’s “Study in Action” conference in March 2014. It has also expressed itself through in a week spent in meditation and observation under a tree in Oaxaca_COMMA_ Mexico_COMMA_ as well as in my poetry practice. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_*In lieu of providing links_COMMA_ here is the abstract of the paper I am referring to_COMMA_ if you are interested:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This paper is an invitation to awareness. It emerges from a framework that considers historically masculinist_COMMA_ colonial worldviews as contributing to an ongoing culture of violence_COMMA_ and understands decolonization as a gradual and ongoing process. In sharing this work I will begin by briefly bringing forth a couple of documented examples of the disconnect between body and land to shine a little light on some of the language used for the purposes of the colonial project. Next_COMMA_ I will show how some Indigenous women are resisting and destabilizing colonial beliefs through teachings centered on the interdependent relationship between the body and the land. As a process and living practice of unlearning colonial worldviews cannot truly manifest through book reading alone_COMMA_ these teachings act as an invitation to an embodied process of un-learning; developing a sensitivity to the dynamic exchange between body and land. Their work asks us to consider how we relate to the land_COMMA_ and the material_COMMA_ psychological and spiritual implications of such a relationship. I aim to show how learning through these writings can contribute to a process of sensitizing ourselves to our environment_COMMA_ facilitating a moving away from colonial worldviews and towards communion with the land through a relationship of reverence and respect.
column16: Communal living has taken several forms at different moments in my life_COMMA_ and right now it is through a shared living space in Montréal with three humans and two furry creatures. We share bulk dry goods and recuperate fruits and veggies_COMMA_ make kombucha and communal meals when we can. We share hand harvested honey_COMMA_ reading materials and plenty of nourishing kitchen floor conversation_COMMA_ and have developed several functional systems for division of labour_COMMA_ as well as financial and material contributions. We have a compost system using vermi-compost in the house and bringing organic waste to the collective garden that some of us work at during the growing season. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Every week we hold a meditation and listening circle where we light a candle and sit in silence_COMMA_ followed by a check-in_COMMA_ and sometimes experimental singing_COMMA_ playing or fort-building. We also have a small stuffed spotted owl who we take turns hiding around the house to develop observation skills and awareness of space.
column17: I have been hungering for the space_COMMA_ time and support to synthesize these seemingly separate practices of yoga asana_COMMA_ meditation_COMMA_ poetry_COMMA_ academic research and writing_COMMA_ and performance. The nature of this course is so closely in line with the work I have been doing that I got this incredible rush all through my spine just reading the description! _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I feel that I will deeply benefit from the exploration of narrative through story telling_COMMA_ as this is central to my work and life_COMMA_ from the body-centric learning that I know can happen through slow play_COMMA_ and the insights and sparks that performed discussion can ignite. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I feel a deep need for the space and collaborative support that this residency has the potential to bring_COMMA_ as well as some time to sit_COMMA_ run and play in the woods/grass/dirt/wind. It is the learning that comes through awakened receptivity to the messages of the body and land_COMMA_ and that exhilarating tension between form and freedom found in intentionally creative_COMMA_ collective space that I seek. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The aspect of “wildness” is of special intrigue to me_COMMA_ particularly with a consciousness of the dominant and colonially constructed division between the body and mind; rational and irrational; masculine and feminine; civilized and savage. I have been finding myself experiencing small flashes of insight in the readings_COMMA_ discussions and thinking I have been doing about this_COMMA_ and see immense potential for deepening_COMMA_ complicating and expanding that learning through this residency session. As my creative practice is a necessary element in all of my learning_COMMA_ I also recognize potential for a more seamless integration between this practice and my more formal academic explorations.
column18: (Only applying to Session A)
column19: Session A: Between Nature & Culture_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would love to create a performance that uses the language and sound of poetry to generate embodied movement. Through this_COMMA_ I wish to bring full_COMMA_ living expression to my poems as living entities occurring always in a particular context with a particular group of people. The process of writing_COMMA_ speaking and sharing poetry has always emerged through my body_COMMA_ yet has not come into full expression in performance; meanwhile_COMMA_ the body-centered work and play I have done has often lacked the tangible synthesis of language. My sense is that I have less a need for money or material resources as much as the intentional space and support to more fully realize this merging of creative practices. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I do not have specifics in mind yet_COMMA_ but envision a series of poems_COMMA_ either new or re-visited_COMMA_ performed in an embodied_COMMA_ gestured manner_COMMA_ and in dialogue with those present. My understanding of such dialogue implies direct contact between “performer” and “spectator”; the holding of space and guiding of a narrative arc that facilitates collective release. What I mean by release involves a connection to the breath and a relaxing of the diaphragm_COMMA_ and happens at the moment in the performance when everyone is together at the same time- often through a shared exhale or laughter.
column20: Q: What can you offer to a collective learning process?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A: Through training and experience as a yoga teacher_COMMA_ educator and workshop facilitator have allowed me to develop a strong capacity to hold space and actively support individuals’ particular experiences. I have come to recognize an ability to facilitate this process while allowing full agency and autonomy of the person I aim to support.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I am an artist_COMMA_ educator_COMMA_ maker and thinker living and working in Brooklyn_COMMA_ NY. Photography is my primary medium but I also work with video_COMMA_ sound and sculpture. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My work is driven by an enthusiasm for small or mundane details in the world around me that are overlooked by others_COMMA_ hence my fascination with dust. Dust is all around us and all things become dust. Some of its largest components are human skin and hair_COMMA_ though it contains other surprising materials like star dust. (For more information on my dust project have a look here at my website here: www.sallybozzuto.com/#!dust/cyuu)_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm also fascinated with things that fit into the following categories: terrifying_COMMA_ gross_COMMA_ amazing. For example: teeth. Teeth are a part of one's skeleton that is seen on the outside of the body (terrifying)_COMMA_ they are covered in bacteria and saliva (gross) but they are also necessary for our survival (amazing.) With the exception of nanomachines picking our bodies apart molecule by molecule (grey goo) or maybe marshmallow fluff I think most of the things I can think of that fit into The Grand Three categories are biological in nature: babies_COMMA_ bacteria_COMMA_ dirt_COMMA_ carniverous plants_COMMA_ etc. Most things about the human body fit into The Grand Three if you think about them for long enough. The human body and its relation to the larger life cycle is one of the key elements of some of my newest work._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am also an excellent conversationalist and have an absurd love of puns. Some of my most recent pun work includes my idea for this year's Halloween costume: a narwhal-mart greeter. Think: smiley face logo with a tusk and fins.
column14: As a photographer and videographer I am always collaborating with others. This takes on many forms: brainstorming sketches and ideas for a project with other artists_COMMA_ interacting with models or subjects_COMMA_ getting feedback on works in progress or working with a crew_COMMA_ especially in the case of video-making. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I think one of the great advantages of working in a residency setting is to get feedback from other artists and thinkers and to have exciting conversation that can spark new ideas. I especially love talking to artists working in different media or people with expertise in other areas such as writing_COMMA_ philosophy_COMMA_ science etc. I think dialogue is one of the most precious and important elements of the art-making process.
column15: http://www.sallybozzuto.com/#!hcybaygos/c1n0f_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_How Can You Be Alive You Growths of Spring? addresses regenerative cycles of life and death using substances such as dust_COMMA_ compost_COMMA_ the human body and plant life. This work stems from a fascination with the complexities of biology and wonder at the improbability of life generating and regenerating itself in endless cycles._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Using photography and video I document real and staged processes such as bodily refuse mixing with decaying vegetation to create compost or plants growing from unlikely sources._NEWLINE_ _NEWLINE_My work toes the line of attraction and repulsion by showing things such as death_COMMA_ decay_COMMA_ and bodily refuse in an aesthetically appealing way. I am also addressing the relation of seemingly contradictory forces. Decay begets new growth_COMMA_ birth begets death and death begets rebirth. The cycle is terrifying_COMMA_ repulsive and amazing all at once. It is my hope that this work fills the viewer with a sense of wonder at the incredible regenerative nature of life and stimulates deeper contemplation of both life and death on a larger scale as part of an endless_COMMA_ cosmic cycle.
column16: I attended SMT for the past two summers and have lived happily with many different roommates. I also have experience living at summer camp and band camp as a young person.
column17: Nature is the primary theme in my newest work_COMMA_ How Can You Be Alive You Growths of Spring?_COMMA_ so the theme "Between Nature and Culture/Reconstructing Wildness" is extremely relevant to my practice._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am very excited to engage in discussions on topics regarding "The Wild_COMMA_" what that means and if there even is such a thing. The aspects of culture surrounding The Wild are of particular interest to me as I think this is something that could be explored much more in my work. I also like the idea of having communal experiences around these themes. Sometimes I can get caught up on being academic with my work_COMMA_ but an emotional component can be equally important.
column19: This might require more time than funds but I would love to grow plants out of dust or ashes (possibly mixed with another growth medium) and document the process using photography and video to create work speaking to the resilience of life.

column11: My artist CV is on my website under "experience."
column13: I grew up in the suburbs of Raleigh_COMMA_ North Carolina in a family of seven_COMMA_ my identical twin sister and I being the eldest. My life has been filled with adversity and isolation_COMMA_ so I consider dreams_COMMA_ fears and anxiety to be extremely valuable parts of human experience. Much of my belief system has developed through a continuous dialogue with a sister who shares my DNA but not all of my experiences. My work and interests are easily traced to the use of this dialogue as a tool for measuring the validity and value of our adverse experiences and emotions in regards to survival within society. I do not believe adverse experiences should be treated as invaluable and often I feel there is an attempt to eradicate them along with a skeptical dialogue of our culture in education. I have a B.A. in Art Education and teaching certification from Meredith College and an M.F.A. from the New York Academy of Art. I have recently completed an experimental animation that is off to compete in film festivals. This work incorporates a life-size_COMMA_ partially animatronic_COMMA_ low-budget_COMMA_ stop-motion puppet as well as other puppets and drawings. Having just finished my most ambitious animation to date_COMMA_ I am currently teaching at a public school in Raleigh_COMMA_ North Carolina and pursuing funding and opportunities to take my animation and kinetic work to the next level. I have a two-month-long gallery show at the end of this year that will incorporate animations_COMMA_ puppets_COMMA_ kinetic sculpture_COMMA_ drawings and music. My work is surreal_COMMA_ psychological and attempts to capture beauty and value in adversity_COMMA_ isolation_COMMA_ and venturing into dark places without remaining trapped in them.
column14: The way in which I have always lived my life and created artwork seems to be therapeutically and spiritually connected to my survival and this can also be said of the people to whom I become close. Because of the isolation that I experienced growing up_COMMA_ it became imperative to think outside of “reality” in order to survive. This has both positive and negative aspects when trying to keep this quality and participate in community and society_COMMA_ but it does require the seeking out of companions who function this way as well and there is some magic in it. I have always created art in intellectual gatherings of friends_COMMA_ and past dialogues and dreams have led to my current work and goals. In my animating_COMMA_ I am literally working with others and must access my relationship resources in order to complete them. My most recent film incorporated live actors who acted in stop-motion with my life-size_COMMA_ Frankenstein influenced_COMMA_ self-portrait. My upcoming show will incorporate the help_COMMA_ art_COMMA_ music_COMMA_ support and input of dozens of people. I find that along with the experiences of my twin sister_COMMA_ I am often trying to pull from the experiences of others to find overarching themes that hopefully lead to modern_COMMA_ visual mythologies and enhance the spiritual value of my life and the lives of others.
column15: Please watch my most recent animation at: https://vimeo.com/81851033 The password is: psycho_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Also_COMMA_ please look at my website._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Recently_COMMA_ I have spent a lot of time reading_COMMA_ researching and thinking about identity_COMMA_ the idea of the individual_COMMA_ epigenetics_COMMA_ nature and nature_COMMA_ the work of Charlie Kaufman_COMMA_ the philosophies of Ludwig Wittgenstein_COMMA_ the problems of technological determinism_COMMA_ and twin symbolism in art.
column16: All but one of my living situations have been communal. I have lived with probably a total of thirty different people_COMMA_ including my grandmother. But my most interesting experience was probably sharing a room with my twin sister until the age of eighteen. Although we have lived apart_COMMA_ we were never separated by more than a few miles until I moved to New York to earn my M.F.A. This was extremely hard and frustrating. My sister and I have been through everything together and most of my immediate family would agree that if it had not been for our relationship_COMMA_ our collective situation might be far more adverse than it is. I struggle always to find something that matches that relationship_COMMA_ but I know I never will.
column17: "How can we think what we do not know how to think?" is a question that creates probably one of my favorite black holes to fall into_COMMA_ and I feel it is a deep thought spiral that is related to all the thoughts in my brain_COMMA_ feeling often outside of myself and separated from reality_COMMA_ not ever knowing when I am thinking like "myself" or how much control I have over what that is. Because of this_COMMA_ I love dreams_COMMA_ all talk of them and looking for synchronicities between my life and the lives of others. I hope to find realities that lie outside of what I expected or thought_COMMA_ but I feel that I have to train myself to be open to this and aware enough to notice what I want to incorporate into my artwork and personal value system.
column19: With the funding and time_COMMA_ I'd love to share my experience putting life into puppets through non-electronic kinetics_COMMA_ stop-motion_COMMA_ and electronic servos. column20: Does technological determinism allow for individual control over the necessities of survival? Wittgenstein: "Just as a man cannot report his own death when it happens_COMMA_ but only foresee it and see an epic description of a whole culture_COMMA_ you will have to look at the works of its greatest figures_COMMA_ hence at works composed when the end of this culture could only be foreseen_COMMA_ because later on there will be nobody left to describe it. So it’s not to be wondered at that it should only be written in the obscure language of prophecy_COMMA_ comprehensive to very few indeed."

column13: I’m a 24-year-old artist-thinker originally from Winnipeg_COMMA_ Canada_COMMA_ and I’ve been based in Montreal for the last two years. At the moment_COMMA_ my work (as well as my life) is informed by the tension I feel as a university dropout who is deeply engaged with critical theory. I have a background in physical theatre and movement work_COMMA_ and I really don't know what I make yet. I read voraciously. I go to conferences and tell everyone I'm finishing my PhD in Lisa Robertson and the feminist poetics of waitressing (lies! But I prefer to call it performance art). I know how to work with my body in impulse-based_COMMA_ strange_COMMA_ raw ways. I've read everything Lauren Berlant's ever written. I can mine my chilly northern Manitoba upbringing for all sorts of inspiration - digging graves in snow as a lonely third-grader at recess_COMMA_ lying on my bookshelf for hours pretending I was Anne Frank_COMMA_ polar bears_COMMA_ my mother's depression_COMMA_ etc. I find psychoanalytic theory delicious_COMMA_ feminisms necessary_COMMA_ Montreal dance parties utterly weird and generative. But ugh! I don't know what I make.
column14: Adrienne Rich: "I wanted to go somewhere the brain had not yet gone. I wanted not to be there so alone". Lisa Robertson: "So what if she is thick and stupid behind her life. It is not private"_COMMA_ and also_COMMA_ "She wanted to tell about it but not necessarily in language". Lauren Berlant: "the emotional time of being-with_COMMA_ time where it is possible to value floundering around with others whose attention-paying to what’s happening is generous and makes liveness possible as a good_COMMA_ not a threat.” _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm a compulsive archivist_COMMA_ I've read fucking everything_COMMA_ and my friends are crazy and brilliant. I don't know how I would survive without the glut of quotes I've sought out to validate my curiosities_COMMA_ tensions_COMMA_ alienations. The theory that fascinates me is fundamentally about relations and subjectivities. I want to know how we survive and how we survive together_COMMA_ I want (always_COMMA_ always) to create work that stands as a testament to the aggressive_COMMA_ sometimes hopeless genius of the friends I’m lucky to know. I write as the daughter of a mentally ill_COMMA_ hyperliterate mother who gave me her copy of The Madwoman in the Attic to read at seventeen. I work as the granddaughter of a Jewish Marxist woman who could spin off Atwood references at the drop of a hat but could not_COMMA_ would not_COMMA_ stick around town long enough to begin to mother her children._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Why are my loved ones in such turmoil? Why are they so articulate and yet so anguished? I hope this doesn't sound too heavy. I come from a mad but hilarious line of folks. My family does the best bleak humour and I mean to carry on the legacy_COMMA_ but at the same time I wonder_COMMA_ with Anne Boyer (the best poet_COMMA_ my favorite poet): "Who will care for the raped but brilliant thinkers?" (Mother_COMMA_ friend_COMMA_ friend_COMMA_ aunt_COMMA_ friend_COMMA_ fucking hell when does this shit end?).
column15: http://hysteriarama.tumblr.com/post/16572083925/self-identify-as-a-hater_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This is a tumblr post that I wrote a couple of years ago. I tend to believe that I generate the best_COMMA_ richest life for myself when I dredge up the space to puke my anxieties into some sort of public sphere. At the same time_COMMA_ I don't really find that terror and abjection livable in an ongoing sort of way_COMMA_ so I'm continually trying to find ways to shape my raw material into questions and frames that others can enter and exit consensually. I'd like to invite participation and collaboration without coercing it_COMMA_ or_COMMA_ as one of my genius friends and I discussed recently: "We've got to translate our trainwreck selves into art and theory or else we're doomed to a lifetime of being well-read_COMMA_ inarticulate girls who cry publicly far too often."
column16: I spent a year in my hometown (the frigid-but-secretly-grand Winnipeg_COMMA_ MB) living in an anarchist collective home with eight other folks. We were the Winnipeg Copwatch Collective_COMMA_ the Winnipeg Radical Cheerleaders_COMMA_ the punk house with the best tickle trunk in town. I learned so much about anti-racism_COMMA_ about the politics of policing_COMMA_ about the soul-sucking dullness of house meetings_COMMA_ about being naked (also literally_COMMA_ we didn't like to wear shirts) with roommates and letting them see the spaces I didn't have theory for_COMMA_ didn't have quotes for_COMMA_ found scary and vulnerable and wanted to hide. In our collective house it was impossible to remain hidden_COMMA_ and though that scared me it also broke me open in the best ways. As an only child who grew up with a single parent_COMMA_ communal living is deeply foreign to me_COMMA_ and therefore both scary and exciting. It's my favorite challenge to undertake. I'm also totally on top of doing dishes.
column17: I began taking theatre classes as a three-year-old_COMMA_ and only recently have I taken a break. I'm sick of this break. Physical theatre also throws me into a tizzy because it inevitably undermines my ability to falsify my practices. Life becomes sincerity or bust. I end relationships_COMMA_ eat better_COMMA_ wash my face early and read on mountains. Physical theatre always reminds me that_COMMA_ though I may be a hyperliterate theorist-in-training_COMMA_ I am also an embodied thing. Affect theory (and Deleuze_COMMA_ ooh baby) goes hand-in-hand with this work. When I am moving_COMMA_ engaged relationally_COMMA_ and theorizing my becoming rather than theorizing what I've already become_COMMA_ I morph into the most human_COMMA_ most productive version of myself. Juliana Spahr: "An attempt to reach the human moment will occur". All I'm ever trying to do. All I really give a shit about. The session theme seems so human-moment-heavy_COMMA_ it makes me feel totally lustful.
column19: I hated university so much_COMMA_ found it so unbelievably dull_COMMA_ and yet inevitably find myself longing for structured educational spaces_COMMA_ albeit ones that don't require so much alienation from oneself. This is the tension I'd like to prod in my dream project. How do you perform your thesis? How do you embody your fragmented poetics? Last year I co-facilitated a lit collective named CWIRL (crazy women writing in real life_COMMA_ we all met on tumblr so we though the irl part was hilarious_COMMA_ and the crazy women part was a seventies feminist throwback). I'd like to remount a miniature version of CWIRL. I dream of facilitating a collective school-process in which we read Adrienne Rich_COMMA_ Lauren Berlant_COMMA_ Lisa Robertson_COMMA_ etc etc etc (and believe me I can fill in the etc) and begin to indulge in our feminisms in a new way. I'd like to theorize the Belantian impasse_COMMA_ the time lived without a genre_COMMA_ in a way that accounts for my being a waitress_COMMA_ a depressive_COMMA_ a girl who has watched every episode ever of Law and Order SVU. (This is vague. This question terrifies me but I know that with a bit of support I could rock it_COMMA_ live it_COMMA_ make it possible).
column20: Q: Hey baby_COMMA_ what are you wearing?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A: Glasses_COMMA_ dangling on one finger. Filled-in eyebrows_COMMA_ aching shoulders_COMMA_ jeggings (which I feel ambivalent about). A body from binge-eating_COMMA_ the other night_COMMA_ when I was talking to my mother for hours about the nature of her life on an icy reserve in northern Manitoba and the nature of mine in cold_COMMA_ throbbing Montreal. My Jewish nose. My bad skin which will just not not not un-bad and which forces me to re-encounter skin theory_COMMA_ rupture_COMMA_ imperfection_COMMA_ I wear this shit on my face and I have to find a way to make that livable. Long hair that I spent years growing out after I chopped out the desexualize and rehumanize myself_COMMA_ post-feminist-fatigue_COMMA_ feeling so sick of being vulnerable in the ways that girls tend to be. No bra. Smartwool socks that my father mailed to me because the one way he consistently cares for me is this super pragmatic_COMMA_ warm foot technology way. It's a limited love but I'll take it. I'm going to put on a dress now and go dancing. Xoxo gossip girl.
column21: No way! If I get the chance to join you this July I am so_COMMA_ so_COMMA_ so there. The only scheduling conflict is that I probably won't ever want to leave.

column12: Hike (A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT)_COMMA_ Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)_COMMA_ Session B (UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING)
column13: My current body of work is a collection of object-based circumstances that incorporate and activate the viewer. The viewer is changed from viewer to participant and even an active plot driver. The object is changed from passive subject of observation to a complex character. In this way the hierarchical barrier between viewer and object falls away_COMMA_ activating both the viewer and the object as characters of equal force. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The narrative happens episodically_COMMA_ with main characters who appear as puppets or dolls. Rather than existing on a stage or inhabiting a fictional plane_COMMA_ the puppets inhabit the real world: getting haircuts_COMMA_ writing notes to human acquaintances_COMMA_ dying and being interred_COMMA_ or inciting a grave digging. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Events unfold organically and genuinely_COMMA_ and I as the artist often take on the role of character rather than master puppeteer. The lack of total control serves to tint the unfolding events with honesty. It reminds us that though what is happening in these pieces is the language of the lunatic or the trickster (a part of the mind may choose to hang back an laugh at the absurdity of accusing a puppet of a crime)_COMMA_ it is at its core as real as the human experience. Fellow human characters participating in these events observe how they feel compelled by the circumstances_COMMA_ and even by the puppet characters_COMMA_ to feel and react in a way that is surprising_COMMA_ unplanned_COMMA_ and genuine. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_These “circumstances” are a part of a larger_COMMA_ perhaps interminable epic. They are an intuitive narrative that asks questions about the agency of objects_COMMA_ the authenticity of intuition_COMMA_ the human condition as character in play_COMMA_ manipulation and perception_COMMA_ and the defining qualities of what is real.
column14: My main practice is at it's core dependent on collaboration. The circumstances defy the separations that traditionally exist between reality and fiction_COMMA_ artist and viewer_COMMA_ art work and real world. Much of what the work becomes is due to its existence in the mind of the participants. They act not as viewers of an object_COMMA_ but actants in a series of events. Thus my work is arguably always a collaboration. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Aside from my core artistic practice_COMMA_ I also participate frequently in collaborative efforts_COMMA_ such as event planning_COMMA_ group exhibition curation_COMMA_ and collaborative art projects. Most recently I completed an artist book_COMMA_ designed_COMMA_ illustrated_COMMA_ and crafted collaboratively with artist Mike Calway-Fagen. I am currently organizing a puppet slam_COMMA_ for which I've invited a number of individuals from various artistic backgrounds_COMMA_ as well as non-artists_COMMA_ including scientists and environmental activists. These creative minds are coming together to both invent and produce an alternative puppet performance that will challenge given power dynamics_COMMA_ starting with expectations about puppetry. In this way_COMMA_ the work will both directly and indirectly challenge far reaching and basic assumptions about the human place in the universe.
column15: The circumstances surrounding Fabro's Funeral represent two separate situations_COMMA_ each of which were a part of an ongoing epic. This work involves a dependency on the voluntary participation of others_COMMA_ a perpetual call and response between the people and objects involved_COMMA_ and the importance of moment to moment involvement. It also embodied a search-based approach to content_COMMA_ and revealed a richness of substance as events unfolded. The piece is not preserved in crisp documentary photographs_COMMA_ but in snapshots_COMMA_ and in the minds of the participants involved. In this way it is both un-preservable and ongoing_COMMA_ embodying the spontaneity of hear-say. The piece involved questions about life and death_COMMA_ reality and spectacle_COMMA_ and humor and sincerity_COMMA_ but
column16: I have lived on an organic farm under a work-trade agreement. During that time I exchanged 15 hours a week of farm labor for living space in the farm house. I became personal friends with the entrepreneurial farmer who initiated the project. I have also lived with 2 or more room-mates while living and working through school. Each living arrangement has focused on community building_COMMA_ including cooperative cooking and meal-sharing. During my time in Bloomington I have had a close association with the Bloomington Cooperative Living community_COMMA_ and have hosted events for the benefit of the living community as well as participating in the meal-share program.
column17: My work has become increasingly interested in challenging accepted power-dynamics and structures. This manifests primarily in the process of work making rather than the content of the work itself. The art-making process begins with impulse and through a self-aware openness (or perhaps relinquishing of self) discovers the subconscious richness of events. This seems to be consistent with the mission statement of the School of Making Thinking_COMMA_ and I am happy to have found an establishment that claims heurism as it's central maxim. It is because of this self-same center that I have applied to all three programs_COMMA_ but with a special interest in Unthinking/Unknowing_COMMA_ which seems to speak to the heart of my work most directly_COMMA_ but also seems to be applicable to a broader practice outside of the residency program.
column18: My work is centrally interested in allowing the spontaneous to unfold_COMMA_ which is one of the integral focuses of the hike. I'm also very interested in non-homocentric perspectives--that is to say_COMMA_ the investigation of the universe that does not place the human at it's center. Ideally I'd like to craft an experience to take place during the hike that allows this perspective to be fully experienced. This may focus on the environmentalist value of "bio-centrism"_COMMA_ but it may also be related to the broader view of "selflessness" in its most deconstructed and broadly applicable form.
column19: I have up to this point enjoyed drawing from an attitude of resourcefulness_COMMA_ relying on the appropriation of cast-off and discarded items. I find that this practice brings charged objects to the work; objects that carry their history and character with them. This is almost stubbornly low-cost at times. Given unlimited funding_COMMA_ I think I may still choose to work in this way_COMMA_ re-using items that are obtained without cost as a rule. Funding_COMMA_ however_COMMA_ could be utilized in this situation for transportation of items typically more difficult to obtain. This might create an interesting opportunity to engage and examine the process of transport in all it's dimensions: its economics_COMMA_ it's environmental impact_COMMA_ and it's effect upon us as objects in a constantly shifting world.
column20: What is the usefulness of a question? Maybe the usefulness of a question is not as a formulaic approach to the acquisition of understanding or a fortification of a belief system. Rather_COMMA_ the value of a question is the experience it offers: a question is an acknowledgment of doubt. To acknowledge doubt with no hurry to resolve it is to embrace uncertainty_COMMA_ even to invite it as an artistic medium.
