column13: People call me Cub. I’d like to sail around the Earth. Up until recently_COMMA_ I thought I was an artist_COMMA_ one that happened to enjoy adventure_COMMA_ map making_COMMA_ self-directed science experiments_COMMA_ and cataloguing curiosities. Once I realized I was not an artist I thought I was an explorer_COMMA_ one who happened to enjoy making videos_COMMA_ writing_COMMA_ drawing_COMMA_ and photography - see where I’m going with this? On the second last day of 2013 I bought a twenty foot sailboat and realized I was both an artist and an explorer. I am currently negotiating what it means to be an artist who expresses through the medium of exploration_COMMA_ and how to create work for presentation via exploration.
column14: I am drawn to The School of Making Thinking because of its approach to collaborative work. As an emerging artist_COMMA_ I find sharing ideas extremely intimidating. I’m easily embarrassed and I often sell myself short because of it. After reading SMT’s ideas on collaboration/individuation_COMMA_ I am convinced that it’s within this community structure I will find my ideal form of collaboration that will allow me to break from being self conscious_COMMA_ and instead learn to embrace the vulnerability that comes with allowing your ideas to move from mind to mind. I am motivated by group discussion_COMMA_ and glean insight for my own projects while observing peers critique each other. When working in a group on one project_COMMA_ I sway more to the side of a follower than a leader if the final product is going to be something that requires interpretation_COMMA_ however_COMMA_ if the project is something literal I feel more comfortable being vocal with my opinions. I believe this is rooted in the insecurity of not believing in myself as an artist_COMMA_ and my struggle of self-identifying as one.
column15: At one point in my life I thought I was going to be the first person I knew personally to go into space. A popular daily paper promised to send someone to space - all you had to do was ask and get the most votes. I thought if I made a video to accompany my request I’d be chosen for sure. I was not. That said_COMMA_ I still plan on being in space at some point in my life. I wouldn’t describe this as the work that represents me best in relation to being fit for the SMT program_COMMA_ but it showcases my enthusiasm and ernest disposition when working on projects that excite me. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bAggD8qoi4I_NEWLINE_A work in forever progress that is more aligned with the SMT program is Rambler_COMMA_ currently a blog with zine ambitions that I post long winded stories and photos from adventures. Rambler as printed matter is my first work that will marries my artist and explorer spirit in a medium that is tangible. http://www.ramblerrambler.tumblr.com
column16: After film school I went to art school in Vancouver for a year. To save on rent_COMMA_ three friends and myself found a 10x30ft windowless studio to call home. We had no cell phone reception or internet_COMMA_ we occupied the space with books and discussions_COMMA_ slept on pullout couches_COMMA_ and ate food from dumpsters near school/meals provided by a nearby temple. There was a public toilet on the floor that we shared with a dentist office and pharmaceutical company who would never find out we lived there. During the day we had to pretend we were working_COMMA_ by night we would take over the halls to make music_COMMA_ art_COMMA_ ride bikes and skateboard. We found the balance in creatively challenging and emotionally supporting each other._NEWLINE_Two years later I lived in close quarters with five other people as we sailed from Halifax to Spain on a 53ft sailboat. Before setting sail_COMMA_ we spent a week on land living together. We made meals_COMMA_ shared our fears_COMMA_ and on the final night we sat in a sauna taking ten deep breaths as a group then jumped into the Atlantic as one. At sea we were all accountable for each other’s life.
column17: I believe that Between Nature and Culture// Reconstructing Wildness is a program that given the opportunity_COMMA_ would remedy my dilemma of the artist vs. explorer struggle. The focus on group work is an element that I know is missing in my current practice_COMMA_ and with the aid and critique of others in a safe zone for sharing_COMMA_ I will be able to let go of many self-doubts that hold me back from currently making the work I conceive. _NEWLINE_The session Unthinking/Unknowing is something that on a basic level I have been trying to achieve since I left school. It’s something that I think everyone should be working on_COMMA_ but it’s difficult to know where to start. For myself_COMMA_ and I believe it’s this way for a lot of people_COMMA_ the idea comes as a feeling_COMMA_ then the unthought-thought comes to the surface_COMMA_ and from there without instruction_COMMA_ it has no where to go and I’m back to thinking what I am told to think. _NEWLINE_Challenging oneself to formulate ideas and concepts through more unfamiliar territories_COMMA_ such as intuition and unconventional learning allows for one to develop new modes of thinking_COMMA_ and expand their creative process within their own work.
column18: During the “Summit on a Summit” hike I would like to lead a workshop in telling time (during sunlight) and direction (at night) by natural indicators. I’d like to explore as a group the dichotomy of a sunrise_COMMA_ vs. a numerical time of day_COMMA_ or the position of the stars vs. a number value or name for a direction. These are both man-made structures that it’s difficult to imagine life without_COMMA_ however the natural world is existing without these things. I want to have a discussion about what this means; to comply with something man invented_COMMA_ in this case time as a number_COMMA_ but to know that it even with this system in place_COMMA_ the phenomenon of a sunset knows no time_COMMA_ and is existing regardless of what time your clock says. Man’s invention of time_COMMA_ vs. the Earths rotation around the Sun happen simultaneously_COMMA_ I think there’s a lot that can come from this observation_COMMA_ especially on a hike_COMMA_ and the romanticisms of losing track of time and direction.
column19: With unlimited funding_COMMA_ I would create a space that would serve as a site-specific Museum of Natural Imagined History. The project’s intention is to challenge fact vs. fiction in nature and promote discussion on what the general public is willing to accept as scientific truths or myths. Often we cite what’s published as truth without question_COMMA_ but sometimes after years of further examination_COMMA_ we find these truths of the past become modern-day myths. I often find the myth is more alluring than the fact_COMMA_ and as an artist I’d like to explore this idea further and ask the participants to immerse themselves in a world that is based less on scientific “theory”_COMMA_ and more on the Ancient Greek word “theoria”_COMMA_ which means “a looking at_COMMA_ viewing_COMMA_ beholding”.
column20: If asked by Mars One to be one of the 24 explorers sent on a one-way mission to colonize Mars_COMMA_ would you go?_NEWLINE_Funny you ask; that question’s been on my mind. I believe that space exploration is exciting and important_COMMA_ and to be one of the first humans on Mars is an incredible opportunity. However_COMMA_ I believe that we owe it to Earth to focus our energy on causes that will protect our natural resources_COMMA_ resources that are essential to our existence and that are not on Mars. So no_COMMA_ on principle I cannot help you colonize Mars.

column18: I would like to work on a project about cooking as intimate experience. column13: My name is Lasha Mowchun and I would position myself as equally thinker and artist. I wanted to be an artist from the time that I was very very young and thought that I would be a painter. After several unsatisfied years as a painter I found myself looking at my paintings and wanting them to move_COMMA_ to speak. I felt frustrated with the silence and stasis of the gallery experience. I felt critical of Fine Art more broadly_COMMA_ because I felt that it was often inaccessible to the broader population and that the institutional galleries reproduced the marginalizations which were in broader society. I wanted art to be something which was not confined to the gallery_COMMA_ which was able to reach out and uplift pieces of society which were not within the art world. My frustrations almost entirely dissuaded me from realizing my childhood dream of being an artist. Instead of giving up I tried to put my criticisms to work in a productive way. I began to theorize relational aesthetics and participatory art as a way of breaking the divide between audience and artist. I became interested in film because it is a media which has permeated deeply into both high and low culture and which is therefore available to a broader audience. I use my camera not only to fuse narrative and aesthetic concerns but to respond to social inequalities and philosophical questions. After many years of making films_COMMA_ I do not believe that I will ever completely answer my questions of institutional power_COMMA_ hierarchy and populism through my media. Instead I do not look for answers but seek to remain sensitive and open. I try to let my questions continually to reformulate themselves which forces me to reformulate my media and aesthetics to respond. Giving up painting was important for me because it taught me that being open to change allows opportunities for unexpected transformation.
column14: I think that people are not the authors of their own thoughts because our sentiments are the furnishings of broader ideological forces. In this manner all thought is collaborative_COMMA_ because meaning is created within a web which extends beyond the individual. In my practice as a filmmaker I see my camera as a relational entity within which this ideology has been inscribed. _NEWLINE_I believe that filmic works whether artistic or commercial exist in a dialogue with the broader ideological forces because film is a mass artform_COMMA_ which serves not only to entertain but also to control_COMMA_ to govern and to design our representations. I am interested in responding to these ideologies_COMMA_ whether they be consumeristic_COMMA_ political or social within the medium of film because I see it as a site specific interrogation. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The practice of making a film is inherently collaborative as it is created by many individuals in a network. As a filmmaker I have had to reach out to many communities I was previously unfamiliar with. In advertising for actors on the internet_COMMA_ meeting crew members who are willing to work for free_COMMA_ or in exchange for my work on their project I have extended beyond myself. The subjectivities of these many collaborators are then integrated into the content of the project itself extending the ideological references beyond those which I have personalized._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_ Particularly through my use of non-actors in dramatic roles I have found that identity is not an expression of self_COMMA_ but a performance of ideology. Someone who is not a trained actor has not learned to unpack their concepts of self and when they play a character they surface. I want to access these surfacings because they are the runoff of glacial beliefs systems which mould the individual. As someone who has acted in my own films_COMMA_ or had my close personal relationships translated into narrative I have been fascinated to watch the strange formations of ideology surface. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Collaboration has been essential to my art practice because I think that my work is more relevant if it is challenged by forces which are beyond my personal sentiments. I have written many of my projects in direct collaboration with other artists and invited strangers into my editing suites. I like collaboration not only because of its philosophical qualities_COMMA_ but also because I like to feel stimulated and challenged by other people.
column15: I am applying for the Unthinking/Unknowing seminar between July 1st and 21st because I am interested in questioning my preconceptions_COMMA_ working in collaboration and ultimately approaching thinking as concept. As an example of my relevant work I will provide my most recent film_COMMA_ entitled the Excruciating Beauty of Melody which considers irrationalism as a form of anti-knowledge through we may gain clearer insight. I would like to provide a link to the film and recommend that because the film is 25 minutes long_COMMA_ if the jury only has a limited time they watch from 18:00 forward. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://vimeo.com/73748392_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Inspired from a real delusion_COMMA_ the film follows the life of a young man who believes that his body is becoming a musical instrument. The score is of the film is his personal soundtrack- a piano which begins to haunt him_COMMA_ at first from the distance and then moving closer_COMMA_ until it is inside of him. This film was loosely based on a story from my family which has been told and retold_COMMA_ detailing a schizophrenic episode which my Uncle Elroy in which he believed that he could play the piano on his teeth. I had been fascinated with this story for years and as I came of age as an artist and feminist particular themes in this story began to interest me. The music which Elroy heard_COMMA_ elicited from his body seemed to be a unique way of knowing the body which is outside of the confines of gender. I believe that sexuality has been narrowed through the binary system of gender_COMMA_ which covers over the hidden meanings of the body and narrows the pluralities of identity. My Uncle Elroy had a girlfriend named Laura during his formative experience with schizophrenia whom he still talks about today_COMMA_ 40 years later. I sought to portray this music as a form of anti-knowledge_COMMA_ which helped both Laura and Elroy efface their gendered knowledge of their bodies and move into a unknown place in which they might allow the hidden meaning of their bodies to surface.
column16: I currently live in communal housing with two other artists. Together we share a house which was built in 1895 around the time which my hometown of Winnipeg_COMMA_ Canada was being settled. I find our home to be a source of personal nourishment and inspiration. Together we form a micro-community which connects to a larger constellation of art_COMMA_ thought and radicalism in the city of Winnipeg. In the past I have had communal living experiences through living on intentional communities in both California and Oregon. Both of these communities were on eco-farms where the community grew and harvested their own food.
column17: I am applying to the Unthinking/Unknowing residency because on a fundamental level my art is fed by theoretical practice and I am interested in exploring this from the standpoint of a critical pedagogy. I am interested in Deleuze’s concept that thinking is an exercise which demands that one create a place of unknowing in which unexpected discourses may arise. It makes sense to me that unknowing itself would be the basis for thinking because I believe that the sentiments of an individual are often the furnishings of a wider ideology. These sentiments themselves do not necessarily constitute thinking. I think that one must become self conscious of this ideology in order to make contact with the realm of thought.. Reading and writing are by big parts of my practice as an artist_COMMA_ but I know that there are different ways to know things which transcends these modes. I feel that art should be more integrated into daily life_COMMA_ including our personal behaviours and daily relationships.This workshop provides an opportunity for participants to reconfigure knowledge into more foundational areas of our lives including our relationships to ourselves and to one another.
column19: In the past I have used the technique of casting to create a form of sculpture which combines figurative sculpture_COMMA_ with burning wax and digital projection. I know that this seems difficult to envision so please consult the following link. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://vimeo.com/46888685_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_To create this sculpture I poured wax into a cast which was taken from my head. I then inserted a wick into the hot wax_COMMA_ giving my head a certain mortality as the burning wick of the candle melts away the wax. I then projected a video of myself onto the candle creating an overlapping of representations. This is a lengthy and expensive process. If I had unlimited funding I would hire studio assistants_COMMA_ buy lots of wax_COMMA_ casting materials and additional video projectors._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_At the School of Making Thinking I would use these materials and labour to make casts from other participants who volunteer themselves. I would cast from different parts of the body on each participant and combine the casts into a singular body_COMMA_ creating a collage of many bodies together. The inspirations for this body would be taken from the somatic techniques of Roberto Freire which seek use group movement in therapy. I would broadcast projections onto this wax sculpture of participants who volunteered to have their reflections on the the somatic therapy filmed. This sculpture would be a body which transcends the individual and embodies knowledge in its collaborative form.
column20: What do you draw your inspiration from?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As a writer and filmmaker my narrative are inspired listening and paying attention to dialogue around me. I am always gathering research from people in my midst and carefully observing. I have been known to tape record my family suppers to glean narratives from convoluted stories and manias.
column21: I currently do not have any schedule conflicts.

column13: I am a film director_COMMA_ screenwriter_COMMA_ and script doctor I am also a teacher with a full schedule - currently I am teaching 20-30 hours a week at the New York Film Academy_COMMA_ where I lecture on narrative theory for film and screenwriting at the college level. I am currently writing a book about my narrative theories_COMMA_ called " The Neurotic's Journey"_COMMA_ which posits_COMMA_ among many other ideas_COMMA_ that late 20th century and early 21st century cinema differs from earlier filmic forms in that it offers both a more fragmented and conflicted inner landscape in a radically intimate character subjectivity_COMMA_ and a more collective and transcendent outer landscape in mythical and mystical catharsis_COMMA_ which transcends human identity_COMMA_ space_COMMA_ and time. In this way for me today’s cinema is at once going in deeper and pushing out farther_COMMA_ at play with Deluze’s notion of cinema as crystal_COMMA_ Tarkovsky’s concepts of time and transcendence_COMMA_ Jodorwsky's Psychomagic_COMMA_ Jung’s collective unconscious_COMMA_ the notions of capitalism and patriarchy as inherently alienating_COMMA_ Kristeva's abject/eruptive female and Ponty’s exploration of the body as experience. In addition to the book_COMMA_ I am working on my screenplay_COMMA_ Hearbeat_COMMA_ a psychological thriller about a girl who gets a heart transplant from her dad's lover. _NEWLINE_I also do psychic journeying and energy work. I am starting an informal energy work collective with my like-minded friends. I did not study this or seek this out_COMMA_ it came to me in series of experiences that opened me into a very healing field of unknowing. Everything I do has come from a 'not knowing'.
column14: I co- produced and co-directed my first film_COMMA_ and I co–wrote the feature screenplay for “Gabi on the Roof in July” with Larry Levine. I am in both a writing and directing group and these have been great experiences. Right now_COMMA_ I’d say biggest collaborative project is my 8+ years of teaching. I have developed my book in collaboration with my students_COMMA_ who are from all over the world_COMMA_ with all kinds of backgrounds. At their best it feels like our classes wire into a spaceship and the group takes off_COMMA_ enjoying an exponential growth in insight that is profoundly healing and productive. I have also collaborated with my students to become a new person. They don’t need to know it – I only tell them if its useful for their development – but they have taught me a self respect and self esteem I never had before My screenwriting work is collaborative in that I do drafts with input from friends_COMMA_ actors_COMMA_ and producers_COMMA_ and in directing I collaborate with actors_COMMA_ crews and the realties of the day to make shoots work. In a larger sense_COMMA_ I think all of us – and the earth – exist in collaboration with each other_COMMA_ and divisions between us are arbitrary and meaningless. In practice_COMMA_ I need time alone_COMMA_ especially since the time I spend with people touches such a deep place in me. So_COMMA_ like many artists I would say I swing between opening and closing – humans and solitude. I’ve been doing a lot of writing and it’s lonely. Its also lonely to do as much teaching as I do since the opening and closing is both intense and needfully boundaried. I would be excited to deal with this opening and closing in the context of the SMT community_COMMA_ and see where it could go in new and creative directions.
column15: http://www.hulu.com/watch/389262_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Hi this below is my latest thing- its the notes for the nuerotic's journey portion of my book. It is a HOT MESS and may look insane to you_COMMA__COMMA_ but it is what I have been working on and it is my current best work. It is what I will be working with if I come to the workshop. PLEASE do not share it with anyone_COMMA_ it is for your eyes only! Thanks._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7OGM6MYi2mtRWNqZmY4N2lsWTQ/edit?usp=sharing_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'd say the most representative is yet to come!
column16: I have lived at the Sivananda yoga ashram_COMMA_ which was lovely. Feature film shoots always turns into hilarious cult like experiences because of stress_COMMA_ enforced intimacy_COMMA_ and long work hours_COMMA_ but once I worked on a movie about a cult where the crew lived in upstate NY in a house next door to set and it became a super cult - in a good way. Everyone bonded and two couples met who got married ! I am respectful_COMMA_ calm_COMMA_ realistic_COMMA_ non dramatic_COMMA_ tidy and cool with 5 minute showers.
column17: Given my experiences writing fictional characters_COMMA_ working with students_COMMA_ and doing energy work with people with somatic_COMMA_ symptomatic_COMMA_ and ‘ neurotic’ states_COMMA_ I am excited to explore sites of tension and freedom in the body and our discourse in the first portion of the workshop. When I read texts_COMMA_ I often feel that I am more experiential or associative in my response_COMMA_ and I would be excited to explore that work in a field where that is foregrounded. This would inform the work in my book about the building blocks of reality that create patterning for neurotic heroes Part of what I am working on with the book is the leaving behind the known into the unknown in the sense of it being a mix of things that have not been synthesized before in a screenwriting book- personal experience_COMMA_ psychology_COMMA_ philosophy_COMMA_ film theory_COMMA_ direct experience. I am liberated by the feminist notion of writing from the body - that the personal is political_COMMA_ which reminds me of Ponty’s radical embrace of the physical as the spiritual. I think this will lead to a more profound investigation of constructing being and not being_COMMA_ both in my book and my films. Being so in love with Deluze’s idea of the rhizome_COMMA_ and cinema space and time which has informed my approach to my book_COMMA_ I am excited to continue work with Ben to investigating embodiment in the Ponty and Zen traditions. I don't know the result. I know it would be profound_COMMA_ Part of it is that I want to not know the result_COMMA_ I spend way too much time knowing. I want to not know what it will do to me and with me . I want to dance with the course and with the group.

column13: I have done a little of a lot_COMMA_ all with the under current of COMMUNICATION. I can't help but think quite a bit about the different ways we have and hold thoughts and information and I'm endlessly fascinated with how we convey what's inside to the outside. The most interesting kind of people to me in my early life were those who wore their stories on weather-worn faces or showed their stripes through their sartorial selections or whose gravelled voices echoed the sounds or the roads they'd tread. I wanted nothing more than to spend time up near people that had been marinating in experience daily until I encountered art theory at university - a whole kind of metaphysical idea world opened up that gave language_COMMA_ crazy_COMMA_ opaque_COMMA_ neologistic art language to the communicative elements of experience. Ideas across time and space and culture and all that. Then science was thrown into the mix. I wanted to do something practical with my working time and my most cultivated practise was conversation_COMMA_ so_COMMA_ naturally_COMMA_ I became a mental health nurse. In job interviews_COMMA_ when a medical or nursing professional asks me why I made the move from art history to nursing_COMMA_ I always give the same response: Both are fundamentally about communication. They love that_COMMA_ and it's true. I've been working as a nurse for three years with a little break to move to London_COMMA_ UK and work at Wellcome Collection_COMMA_ a sensational health/medicine/art museum and to start a thematic talk radio show on NTSlive.co.uk and to write reviews of art shows and art works and to steep in culture and the wacky anomaly of London as a place. _NEWLINE_At the moment_COMMA_ I continue to make radio - show themes of late include Crying_COMMA_ Laughing_COMMA_ Restlessness_COMMA_ and Idle No More - I am also working with a visual artist on a sculpture/installation exploring the concept of the self_COMMA_ and I am writing a zine about loss with a creative witchy woman. I daylight/nightlight as a nurse with an outpatient day program and in inpatient psychiatry at two inner-city Toronto hospitals.
column14: Though communicating with yourself is vital and important and interesting_COMMA_ the complications that arise in communicating to another person is what really gets me excited. I'd wager all my ideas are sparked from human interaction. One reliable feature about a person is they are not like another. It's nuts!_NEWLINE_In the clinical work I do (which is an integral part of my practise)_COMMA_ I collaborate closely with my patients to convey or reinforce their self-reported symptoms and needs and I collaborate with a team of 60 or so nurses_COMMA_ psychiatrists_COMMA_ specialists_COMMA_ social workers_COMMA_ occupational therapists and support staff to make plans for medications_COMMA_ therapies_COMMA_ housing_COMMA_ welfare_COMMA_ community supports like case-managers or addictions services_COMMA_ truly all manner of Real Stuff. It is very complicated work made almost fun by a shared attitude of 'help each other!' and acting upon thought instead of thinking upon thought. It's an activating kind of collaboration and the sort of work that inspires time away from work to think about all the action._NEWLINE_In creative work_COMMA_ I started Lipstick Studios (so named for our brand of courage_COMMA_ lipstick)_COMMA_ a weekly radio talk show_COMMA_ with co-host Angela Shackel. We collaborated to produce every episode until I moved from London to Toronto in October 2013. This was my first creative collaboration and it was ripe with all kinds of material for thinking on communication. We continue to support one another by sharing notes on shows. The experience of collaboration teaches me a great deal about my own work and has changed the way I hear or see the work of others. This collaboration has led to others - the sculpture/installation and the zine. _NEWLINE_Relationships (with the self_COMMA_ those in networks of support_COMMA_ civic and community_COMMA_ all kinds_COMMA_ every kind!) and politics are fundamentally what I think about. In that sense_COMMA_ you are all my collaborators_COMMA_ ever single breathing specimen.
column15: Crying_COMMA_' an episode I produced_COMMA_ wrote and recorded for Lipstick Studios is the best representation of me as a maker/thinker fit for SMT. In this half-hour episode_COMMA_ crying is explored in a particular contexts_COMMA_ tears in a professor's office from the perspective of the crier and the witness_COMMA_ the method actor in tears_COMMA_ and as a stranger in a new city. Hypotheses of why we cry from evolutionary psychology_COMMA_ social history and contemporary theory of affect and emotion were explained as well as the phsyiology of the act. The topic reached to the heart of what I have been thinking about: the translation of emotional knowledge and information_COMMA_ aspects of the interior world_COMMA_ to the exterior. Emotion surfaces with tears_COMMA_ the effectiveness of tears as a form of communication is mitigated by the culture and circumstance of the moment in which they are witnessed._NEWLINE_This project reflects the way I think. I aim to immerse my questions in my interests_COMMA_ the lived experience of others; art and process; biological and social sciences; and critical investigations of phenomena in theory. _NEWLINE_The immersive approach of SMT is tremendously appealing and would be mutually suited to my thinking / making / making thinking.
column16: Victoria_COMMA_ BC_COMMA_ 2006. Five people plus_COMMA_ three jobs_COMMA_ Vancouver Island's snowiest winter_COMMA_ and no heating system. This was the most memorable of all my communal living experiences_COMMA_ which would be all my living experiences_COMMA_ because I've never lived alone for any significant stretch of time. We used the electric oven as our hearth and read in a semi-circle with our feet propped on the open door. We made vegetable stock from skins and peelings and seedlings were watered with a spice shaker. I caught on fire one morning while porridge boiled and I extended my arms over the element to regain sensation. My housemate Dennis noticed before I did and snuffed my sweater out with a dishtowel. We made bread and subletted a room to an American Jazz singer in her fifties.
column17: Would you proof read and exercise this application further?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am very enthusiastic about existence and approach of the SMT. I am greatful to the party planners (my friend Caitlin Carlisle) for sharing this link with me today and that I have had the chance to submit an application. I would_COMMA_ if the budget of time were not a factor_COMMA_ re-read this and adjust for typical typing errors and the thought tightening that comes with a second look. As it's one minute to midnight_COMMA_ I'll send it off and say THANK YOU! I'm pleased to have applied.
column19: BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDERNESS_NEWLINE_The vision: _NEWLINE_Invasive Speakers - A re-interrogation of colonial take-over. _NEWLINE_This project would explore the transplantation of urbanised/European culture to the organised wilderness of Turtle Island through aural interrogations. This would be a two site sound installation. Site 1: SMT Catskills. Speakers would be located through the site_COMMA_ transmitting the soundscape of a re-created British city circa the present. Participants of the SMT residency will collectively replicate a contemporary British urban centre through voice_COMMA_ improvised sound effects and computer assisted city sounds. These recordings will be looped and broadcast through the speakers as a colonial soundscape grab._NEWLINE_Site 2: SMT Brooklyn. Field recordings of the forest surrounding the Yellow house will be made during the Residency. These recordings will be broadcast as wild noise pollution in Brooklyn. A reminiscence_COMMA_ an inversion of the historical narrative of take-over_COMMA_ and an anxious prediction of what could be if the urban economies do not support the concrete to hold the wilds at bay. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING_NEWLINE_to think is to create what we do not know how to think._NEWLINE_The vision:_NEWLINE_Been thinkin' Thinkin_NEWLINE_A performance that explores historical and contemporary postures demonstrating a person's relations to thinking. SMT participants will act out a recognisable thinking pose. The performers will be animate and may say in the voice of their posture "Been thinking about thinging" or they may choose to interact with each other or viewers in improvised dialogue._NEWLINE_Actor Roles: Piece-of-straw-hanging-from-the-side-of-you-mouth country thinker_COMMA_ day-dreamy contemplative school girl_COMMA_ distressed must-solve-problem thinker_COMMA_ holding a book and pacing thinker_COMMA_ mindful walk with hands clasped at the back thinker_COMMA_ and more!

As it's one minute to midnight_COMMA_ I'll send it off and say THANK YOU! I'm pleased to have applied.

Some of my writing is here:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_http://tolovein.blogspot.ca/2014/02/the-interstellar-mission-of-ceaseless.html_NEWLINE_http://tolovein.blogspot.ca/2013/07/bee-ginnings_11.html_NEWLINE_https://vimeo.com/88019972_NEWLINE_http://www.yorku.ca/etopia/docs/intersections2010/Cherney.pdf
column13: I am a Toronto-based thinker_COMMA_ maker_COMMA_ mover and writer. I'm currently a doctoral candidate in the Ryerson-York Joint Program in Communication and Culture and holds an MA in Philosophy from Concordia University. In my work I gather together movement_COMMA_ philosophy and a critical engagement with performance. My doctoral research_COMMA_ seeks to engage phenomenology as practice: as a mode of embodied engagement and research that enables me to describe and articulate the process of learning movement. dance creation can open the body up to noticing new possibilities for movement and sensory engagement. Likewise phenomenology_COMMA_ as a branch of philosophy concerned with describing the structures of human experience and perceptual life_COMMA_ demands that we suspend the expectations and sedimentations of our ordinary ways of engaging with the world in order to see things as they really are._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_It is frustrating to me that academics who write about performance often lack any developed sensitivities to that medium; it is equally tiring that artists who work in performance-based arenas often lack the necessary intellectual rigour to be viewed as innovators within the realm of academic knowledge production. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I do palliative care support work one day a week at a hospital in Toronto. Last week I took my four year old friend_COMMA_ Nella to a dance show and it was the best day I've had so far in 2014. I make things that are true and difficult. Or at least_COMMA_ that's what my mom says.
column14: In my current work_COMMA_ I ask questions about movement_COMMA_ authenticity_COMMA_ memory and habit. I am specifically interested descriptive analysis_COMMA_ based on the work of think in how the work of thinkers such as French philosopher Maurice Merleau-Ponty_COMMA_ can provide insight into the experience of movement habits_COMMA_ space and time_COMMA_ as shaped by our everyday encounters with the world. Further_COMMA_ I am curious as to how the experience of learning dance can shed insight into the ways that we acquire embodied habits through our experiences with other people_COMMA_ which are then reflected or taken up in the ways we move. It is easy to think here of an example such as posture or way of walking as it might relate to experiences and feelings someone has about themselves. My research operates on a “practice as research” model_COMMA_ which consists of a studio practice of learning historical work by artists such as Deborah Hay_COMMA_ Trisha Brown and Yvonne Rainer. In learning these pieces_COMMA_ it is my goal to think carefully about how this era of postmodern dance is understood_COMMA_ historically situated_COMMA_ as undoing past sedimentations and ways of working. Many scholars have studied this era in dance history_COMMA_ yet only a few (including Toronto-based artist Megan Andrews)_COMMA_ have chosen to approach it from the angle of actually dancing. The central question of this research revolves around how movement learning reveals our articulations of the world and how these articulations reveal important relationships between our bodies and the world_COMMA_ between our own body and the perception of the bodies of other people. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I seek to create a third person window into perceptual experience. In my work I aim to set up heightened conditions for seeing_COMMA_ sensing and recording the experiences of other people. I am interested in notions of authenticity in movement_COMMA_ documentation as a performative practice_COMMA_ witnessing_COMMA_ and questions surrounding the possibilities for intimacy in digitally mediated performance spaces. I have a dynamic engagement with philosophical method: I see this as one modality of articulation for choreographic thought_COMMA_ and an atunement of my dance practice. The intersection of my academic and artistic work is a space of jointure_COMMA_ where the articulating joint is dance itself that in turns lends mobility to working in scholarly and studio based forms. I often inhabit each of these fields separately from one another_COMMA_ but conceive of my practice as being distributed between_COMMA_ and informed by_COMMA_ both the academic and artistic realms.
column15: This is a program note I wrote for my friend_COMMA_ Amelia Ehrhardt's piece_COMMA_ "Traditional Dance". I'm just going to copy paste it. It isn't published anywhere yet_COMMA_ just went in the program. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_"Traditional Program Note or borrowed ideas from Bernard Stiegler and Jean-François Lyotard_COMMA_ with vague undertones of all of phenomenology and French post-structuralism_COMMA_ no acknowledgement of North American thinkers"_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_techne = to bring the immaterial into determinate presence or experience through expression in some kind of language_COMMA_ both art and artifice_NEWLINE_ _NEWLINE_Amelia is a technician_COMMA_ though like most of my favourite dance artists_COMMA_ I’ve rarely seen her throw her legs really high on stage. I only know about her technical prowess because we go to ballet class together on Monday nights. With the word ‘technician’ I don’t just mean her skill at executing ballet vocabulary. The quality of being technical_COMMA_ here_COMMA_ also refers to a particular way of spatializing meaning. Technology is objectification in the sense that it makes meaning tangible in the form of language_COMMA_ spoken or choreographic. To say that someone is a technician is to say that they use technology. In other words_COMMA_ a moving body – i.e._COMMA_ Amelia – uses a particular expression built through materializing ideas in the language of movement (technology) to make an inscription in time and memory._NEWLINE_ _NEWLINE_By entering into the realm of language_COMMA_ we enter the domain of shared meaning. Deposits into this arena of shared meaning are freely available to be taken up by or ‘decoded’ because the use of technology has both semantic and material dimensions. In fact_COMMA_ the semantic is often the domain of communication and intelligibility. Dance training_COMMA_ because it is just like every other kind of language learning_COMMA_ moves back and forth between the material and the semantic. There is an important conversation to be had about the acquisition of information through movement training_COMMA_ wherein we sediment the sense data of experiential movement by inscribing it in our bodies. There is value to thinking carefully about the materiality and specificity of dance vocabulary. Another way to think about it: language reveals what there is left unsaid.
column16: When I was 22 I lived in a communal house. It didn't work so well. Everyone ate everyone else's food and nobody did any cleaning. There were cockroaches and everyone was mad all the time. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Since then_COMMA_ I've lived in a number of communal households but never with more than 2-3 people (not counting sleepover significant others who were like 4th roommates that never paid rent). Currently I live by myself with my 15lbs cat. She's not fat_COMMA_ just gigantic. Here are some things I know about communal living:_NEWLINE_- Always speak up about something that bothers you (no matter how big or small) as soon as you can and definitely before it festers and you get angry._NEWLINE_- Decide if you think something is essential or if you can compromise._NEWLINE_- Not everything will be as you like it_COMMA_ but some things will be magically 100x better than you imagined if you let someone surprise you with their way of doing things. _NEWLINE_- Don't write notes_COMMA_ talk to people. _NEWLINE_- Always ask before borrowing things_COMMA_ even if you think you know the person will be ok with it. _NEWLINE_- Listen when people tell you that you screwed up. Try to do better but know that it's ok if you also sort of screw up at that. _NEWLINE_- Be gentle with other people; be gentle with yourself. _NEWLINE_- Maintain your own boundaries and try to be sensitive to other people's.
column17: I'm kind of resistant to the application of Deleuzian concepts_COMMA_ philosophy_COMMA_ etc. when it comes to practice because it seems like in the dance world at least_COMMA_ this largely amounts to abandoning choreographic structure and language in favour of what is viewed as "superior" art making. Largely this kind of work is shit and a lousy excuse for people to do whatever the hell they feel like doing because somebody did a really bad job paraphrasing what it means to think about a body without organs. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I really think it is possible to be practically inspired by thinking along with Deleuze in a way that extends the notion of boundaries beyond the limit of phenomenology. Or maybe a better way to put that is that phenomenology_COMMA_ by being so explicitly a descriptive tool_COMMA_ becomes sometimes prescriptive when it functions as a frame for artistic practice. I'd like to explore the notion of boundaries within a broader philosophical context.
column19: Actually I don't think I need very much money for this. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would like try to understand better what it means to describe the experience of movement. To do this_COMMA_ I would (because I am a broken record) used phenomenological method. I've been thinking a lot about how to make phenomenology interesting to people who maybe don't think doing it is inherently interesting. The thing is_COMMA_ it's all about wonder. How do we look at the world without our preconceived notions and expectations? A lot of this course would consist of somatic work built from a cross section of techniques that I have studies including Skinner Release Technique (http://www.skinnerreleasing.com/) and Feldenkrais (http://www.feldenkrais.com/). I work a lot with improvisation. Also I would like to find a way of doing a descriptive and experiential study of empathy that doesn't include the words "mirror neurons".
column20: Q: Why do people always ask you what you would do if you had a "do over"? You know_COMMA_ like how people are always so curious about your big life regrets..._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I think people ask this question because they are thinking and remembering their own regrets. I read an article recently about how the famous line from that Robert Frost poem_COMMA_ "two roads diverged in a wood..." is widely misinterpreted. There's this widespread obsession with trying to tell a person's character based on choices they have made in the past_COMMA_ as if to draw a linear correlation between who a person appears to be now and who they have been. My friend_COMMA_ Shiloh_COMMA_ threw an "alternate universe party" in 2011. I went as a veterinarian. We all have our histories.
column21: None.
column23: I try not to eat gluten_COMMA_ but that is just because the media told me I shouldn't. I have no allergies except to ragweed.

column13: I am an artist_COMMA_ a mother of a fourth grader_COMMA_ an animal lover_COMMA_ a sensitive_COMMA_ intuitive who lives in the mountains of Colorado. I am driven by the heart and want to contribute in a meaningful collaboration between art_COMMA_ nature and connecting with other people. I volunteer with art and animal concerned organizations. I am community oriented_COMMA_ willing to participate_COMMA_ and am someone who easily loves others. I am someone who sees an intricate pattern of metaphors in everyday life and how these connect or fail to connect us to one another and our world.
column14: My creative/intellectual practice is collaborative in many ways. When I create art through "creative play in the landscape"_COMMA_ I am gently collaborating with the site and the elements I find there. My intellectual process also collaborative. I am always seeking inspiration from others lists_COMMA_ shared books_COMMA_ quotes_COMMA_ conversations_COMMA_ lectures_COMMA_ social media or web searches.
column15: This autumn_COMMA_ I was invited to work with an open ended music program as a guest teacher. For the afternoon_COMMA_ we hiked a hillside_COMMA_ rolled up our pant legs and crossed a stream and found a special spot among yellow aspen leaves. The kids and I shared some spontaneous_COMMA_ creative play in the landscape. We wrapped bleached deer bones with yarn_COMMA_ artfully placed rosehips in the bark of a tree and created fairy house structures in the underbrush. The kids when on to spontaneously play their string instruments and I made a few more pieces outside with yarn tied to aspen trees. Having created something special together in that 'made special' site_COMMA_ we returned down the hillside_COMMA_ across the river and parted ways knowing something more about ourselves and one another. _NEWLINE_I enjoy this spontaneous creation with a site in the land and with others.
column16: In college_COMMA_ I moved to Eugene_COMMA_ OR._COMMA_ not knowing a soul. Though some housing leads_COMMA_ I ended up moving into a three story house with 13 roommates. None of us knew one another to begin. We had to figure out a way to get along in spite of previously unknown differences. We came up with ways to resolve conflict_COMMA_ including a weekly house meeting and a weekly_COMMA_ rotating schedule of chores.
column17: Being included in such a varied group of creatives sharing and exploring while hiking the landscape together will surely be full of conversations and experiences that will feed my creative practice for a long time to come. I look forward to a different landscape to create with and to the spontaneous synchronicities that would come about from walking_COMMA_ talking and purposefully learning together.
column18: I would like to lead a workshop in creative play in the landscape. This workshop would acknowledge the necessary ingredients to this activity as: a willingness to meet the land and feel its particular consciousness_COMMA_ and be gentle_COMMA_ spontaneous and playful. Working in this way_COMMA_ participants would create an authentic and artful collaboration with nature. To become caught up in the moment of focus_COMMA_ listening and unraveling one's own mind within the safety of the land witnessing this personal process.
column19: N/A
column20: What is your artistic work about?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_To evoke a temporary and poetic presence_COMMA_ I place handmade paper-cut outs_COMMA_ yarn and other art materials in the landscape. I document these gentle interactions through photographs. I refer to my process as “creative play in the landscape”. Creating in this spontaneous way forms a deep focus and an in-the-moment dialogue with a particular site. The photographs that result record a private conversation with a specific landscape and the lives found there. A delicate_COMMA_ visual language is formed to describe connections and tenuousness._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My work contributes to new paths for connecting people’s hearts and imaginations with the land.
column21: None

column13: I am a filmmaker originally from Birmingham_COMMA_ Alabama currently calling Atlanta home. I have written and directed three shorts_COMMA_ with another scheduled for production in late April. I am knee-deep in writing my first feature film which I hope to make in late 2014 or early 2015. I am self-taught_COMMA_ continuously looking for new opportunities to learn and collaborate!
column14: I think I am most collaborative in an idea sharing environment. Being around others with a track record of "doing" is fuel like no other. Dedicating your full self to a passion project is the best way to share a piece of your being with the world. Experiencing someone else react to your efforts in a positive way by contributing their own thoughts is what it's all about.
column15: My last short film_COMMA_ Bubble_COMMA_ was a unique experiment for me. It was my first time to use extensive special effects to portray a concept that I've had for many years. The film explores the notion that we may create our own journeys in an attempt to comprehend our most difficult memories. In a lot of ways Bubble was a test to go into a world that was both scary and exciting for me. I want to do more projects that test my boundaries in this way.
column16: I am currently doing a creative residency in Wilmington_COMMA_ NC with the Cucalorus Film Festival and living with two other artists through May 6th. The house is part of a mini commune with a theater on one side and the festival director living on the other. On any given day there are many opportunities for collaboration! I am here with the purpose of writing my first feature film.
column17: I now more than ever in my filmmaking career it is important for me to be exposed to other artists actively pursuing big ideas and dreams. This environment seems ideal since it includes one of my favorite pastimes - exploring nature. Some of my greatest inspirations have come while being outdoors. I thrive in intimate group settings as well_COMMA_ as it gives me the chance to really bond with others.
column18: I have great expertise and insight in using social media as a tool to fundraise and bring exposure to creative projects. I would love to share my experiences from past projects and plans for my upcoming ones.
column20: What is my current favorite food? (Changes often...)_NEWLINE_Pho!

column13: Originally from Rabat_COMMA_ Morocco Yossera Bouchtia is an emerging screenwriter and filmmaker who currently lives in Brooklyn_COMMA_ New York. She’s recently worked as a video journalist for street art magazine ANIMAL New York. In the past_COMMA_ she’s been credited for creating and co-directing the documentary web series on the Miss Arab-USA pageant. Her role as an Arab-American filmmaker has been featured on The Huffington Post_COMMA_ Jezebel_COMMA_ and Morocco World News. As a filmmaker she holds special interest in the role of culture in shaping feminine identity. With her last short film Laila_COMMA_ Bouchtia hopes to continue helping bridge the communication gap between the women of the Muslim and non-Muslim worlds.
column14: My work in filmmaking is purely collaborative. Each project I take on is dependent on cooperation with other artists who lead different departments within the medium of film which includes Art Direction_COMMA_ Lighting_COMMA_ Cinematography_COMMA_ Acting_COMMA_ and more. A film would not be possible without the collaborative effort of a motivated group who believe in the message of a piece of work.
column15: http://vimeo.com/43976976_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Short Narrative Film: Laila_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Screenwriter: Yossera Bouchtia
column16: I grew up in the urban setting of Rabat_COMMA_ Morocco where I shared a large apartment with my two living grandparents_COMMA_ cousins_COMMA_ an aunt_COMMA_ my parents and my older brother. This cross-generational lifestyle cultivated the way I later lived during my 4 years in college in a townhouse with six roommates. During that time our household duties were delegated by assigning specific chores on a weekly basis. Each week we took on a different cleaning task in order to keep balance and remain collectively taking part in the communal responsibility. Although we were all relatively the same age_COMMA_ I valued the connection and community that I learned at a very young age and enjoyed shared experiences.
column17: I am interested in writing character driven screenplays and examining the psychological needs of characters and the motivational thinking behind their actions. Studying Deleuze would inform my philosophy on how characters arrive at actions and how they may rationalize certain unconscious behaviors.
column20: Why do I write? My identity is based on being both American and Moroccan while not being fully one or the other. Amidst the challenges within this fate I have been rewarded with a unique lens with which to view the world according to various dualities: United States and Morocco_COMMA_ the Arab World and the Western World_COMMA_ the Developing World and the Developed. Conflict exists within each of these relationships. Within conflict comes story_COMMA_ and for a story to be truly brought to life it needs a voice. Mine.

Here are some pages that show I'm not lying when I mention teaching experience:_NEWLINE_http://www.debatechamber.com/tutors/_NEWLINE_http://www.oxbridgeprograms.com/academics/faculty.php_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Also also. A link to one of my favourite activities from last summer's teaching:_NEWLINE_https://oxbridgeacademicprograms.wordpress.com/2013/07/11/oxtrad-philosophy-goes-happiness-hunting/

column13: My central project is empathy. By which I mean_COMMA_ the process of gently leaving to one side our own judgements and emotions_COMMA_ and giving our full attention to the felt reality of another human being. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_How do I work with empathy? First_COMMA_ I practice it. Through training in the techniques of ‘Nonviolent Communication’ (an empathy-centred approach to conflict resolution taught world-wide by hundreds of trainers)_COMMA_ I learn (slowly!) how to bring empathy into my personal relationships. And I have begun to share these techniques with others by running weekly workshops in Oxford. Participants typically feedback that they find empathy to be a radically different_COMMA_ and hugely enriching_COMMA_ way of being with other people._NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Second_COMMA_ I think about it. I am writing a PhD at the University of Oxford on the centrality of empathy to morality. My affiliation is to the philosophy department_COMMA_ but my work draws on fields ranging from neuroscience to literary theory. My hunch is that *Western* approaches to Ethics have neglected empathy_COMMA_ failing to see its centrality in the way of understanding others that is foundational to having moral concern for them._NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_What else? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I’ve spent a total of forty days at silent meditation retreats. I yoga_COMMA_ often. Last summer_COMMA_ I walked 800 kilometres across Spain in a pilgrimage that led me to confront overwhelming angers and griefs I didn’t know I carried. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I have 1000+ hours experience leading outdoor education with children. And I have a particular interest in treasure hunts (more on this below). I think a lot about how to utilise innovative pedagogical approaches to create deep learning experiences in the classroom. A course I ran last summer on ‘philosophy of good life’ took students beyond the classical texts to visit a Buddhist temple and an organic farm_COMMA_ and to conduct happiness creation experiments on the streets of Oxford.
column14: A central theme in my work with empathy is creating encounters between people that facilitate independent working. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_One of the gifts of offering empathy to another person_COMMA_ is that you create a space for them to empathise with themselves. That is_COMMA_ when you attentively and lovingly acknowledge their felt reality - their emotions_COMMA_ longings_COMMA_ memories_COMMA_ pains - you give them space and confidence to do it for themselves. And that can be tremendously healing. The healing work is done by themselves_COMMA_ but facilitated and enabled by the collaborative space. I try to create these spaces in my workshops._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In my formal academic work_COMMA_ I enjoy creating a similar kinds of spaces. Typically_COMMA_ this takes the form of exchanging presentations on latest thinking with fellow graduate students. Even if the other person does not say anything_COMMA_ even if I am ‘doing all of the work’_COMMA_ I find their presence tremendously helpful. It imposes a clarity and rigour on my thought. More than that_COMMA_ it makes me honest. In asking another person to attend to my work_COMMA_ I must ask myself ‘is this really worth paying attention to? Do I really care about it?’. If the answer is anything other than an emphatic yes_COMMA_ I look to reconnect with my work and / or redirect it. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This demand for authentic passion is even stronger when I teach. When young people entrust me with their time_COMMA_ I feel moved to provide them with learning that will inspire and empower them (as opposed to boring them or disillusioning them). Thus I must ask: does this material - this theory - really inspire and empower me? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Academic collaboration is also an invaluable source of feedback and advice for future learning.
column15: How do you turn Shakespeare into a treasure hunt suitable for business executives?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Much of my most creative work has occurred in the outdoor education context. To begin with_COMMA_ this involved working as an instructor at a summer camp for children. It then evolved into the notion of running day-long treasure hunts for adults_COMMA_ utilising cars_COMMA_ codes_COMMA_ spying_COMMA_ and buried treasure. Themes ranged from ‘the quest for the Holy Grail’_COMMA_ to ‘Surviving the Credit Crunch’. In summer 2012_COMMA_ this enthusiasm led me on to a month-long commissioned project for a Shakespeare education charity_COMMA_ who asked: how can we find a new way of engaging corporate supporters with our work?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My answer was to come up with a Shakespearean themed murder mystery treasure hunt_COMMA_ utilising a cast of 6 actors_COMMA_ and 3 historic locations in the city of London. After a chilling investigation of a murder scene (think: dark room_COMMA_ only lit by the candles atop the rose-strewn altar; on that altar lies a cold body_COMMA_ clutching a photo and a dictaphone) participants spent two hours solving clues and interviewing suspects and witnesses_COMMA_ before coming to a verdict. The plot contained elements from Romeo and Juliet_COMMA_ Hamlet_COMMA_ and numerous history plays. The challenge was in working out which plot would lead you to the killer (was it romantic suicide? The jealous brother? Or the power-hungry rivals?)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The event was run with their office staff and trustees (see photos in the link below)_COMMA_ and received excellent feedback (one trustee - a former deputy governer of the Bank of England - told me enthusiastically that I could make a lot of money offering this to American tourists. Then again_COMMA_ maybe it was just because he won.)_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I also once made a birthday treasure hunt for a friend that featured glow-in-the dark murals of Platonic dialogues_COMMA_ and a message in a bottle being discovered in Sri Lanka._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_One of my central aspirations for the coming years is to find a way of bringing this creative energy into my academic work on empathy (see below for more thoughts on this)._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Link for photos and clues from Shakespeare event (as above):_NEWLINE_https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B9JMVWWtLRRgU0xmZ1FwbjNQYVE&usp=sharing
column16: In summer 2011_COMMA_ I spent eight weeks as a member of an eleven person team that travelled through the Balkans (Croatia_COMMA_ Bosnia_COMMA_ Kosovo_COMMA_ Serbia) delivering sport and play activities to disadvantaged children. We worked together_COMMA_ lived together_COMMA_ travelled together (in a minibus). The work was exhausting. Divisions arose from love and unrequited love. Frustrations arose around the way that the trip was managed. But we survived. Even when we collided with a herd of sheep on a Bosnian road._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Learnings I took from that experience include: people appreciate having time and space to be alone. It is vital to create a space where people feel able to honestly express tensions and difficulties in a non-threatening way.
column17: I think that the opportunity to collaborate with other passionate thinkers and artists will radically energise and inspire me in ways that I cannot predict. Is that enough?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In particular - I am interested in the theme of wildness. I’m interested in applying to the notion of empathy - that is_COMMA_ to consider the notion of wild empathy. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Wildness captures the sense that in connecting with ourselves_COMMA_ we radically cast of social norms around presenting ourselves. We strip off inherited ways of thinking_COMMA_ to just honestly be. This reality that lies beneath is_COMMA_ in this sense_COMMA_ wild. Empathising with ourselves is to connect with our wildness. Empathy with others is to connect with their wildness._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_But what is down there? What pains and angers do we find? What desires and longings? Is our basic nature really a compassionate one as Buddhists might proclaim?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_And how to we feel when we encounter this wildness in ourselves and others? Terrified? Awe-inspired? Affirmed? Endeared?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am also interested in wildness in a second sense - in the role of wilderness as a facilitating venue for this process of connecting with our humanity; in how being in wild spaces opens us up and transforms our consciousness. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_More generally_COMMA_ I am excited to find new creative methods to bridge the gap between philosophy and this practice that we call living.
column19: DISCOVERING THE WILDERNESS (WITHIN)_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_First_COMMA_ I would seek to utilise the natural setting to work on processes of self-empathy: exploring the day to day reality of how I felt to be at the residency_COMMA_ and linking this felt reality to deeper parts of myself: enthusiasms and passions_COMMA_ but also trenchant anxieties and fears_COMMA_ and mournings for lost friends & family members._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Second_COMMA_ I would seek to create encounters with other participants to start unlocking their experience of the residency_COMMA_ and how those experiences related to their stories_COMMA_ their realities. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Third: From this work_COMMA_ with myself and others_COMMA_ I would seek to piece together ‘empathic media’ that spoke to the collective experience of the residency_COMMA_ and to the deeper stories of the participants: salient photos_COMMA_ drawings_COMMA_ audio snippets_COMMA_ textual explorations. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_And finally_COMMA_ using these media_COMMA_ I would then develop an immersive ‘treasure hunt experience’ to offer other participants at the end of the residency. For a few hours_COMMA_ participants would explore the local wilderness_COMMA_ following clues based around the ‘empathic media’. A gurgling stream might provide the venue for some reflections on the passing (the transitoriness) of the residency. Under the shade of a giant tree_COMMA_ we might find images capturing salient moments of childhood. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This_COMMA_ then_COMMA_ would be an exploration of wilderness of three levels. First_COMMA_ there is the exploring of the wild truth of others. Second_COMMA_ there is the physical exploration of the wild setting. Through these two aspects_COMMA_ participants would be stimulated to experience their own wildness.
column20: Why is your application late?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I discovered your program this morning through a friend facebook posting about your workshops. Recently_COMMA_ I’ve been thinking a lot about the importance to me of collaboration_COMMA_ creativity_COMMA_ and play_COMMA_ and the scarcity of those things within my academic department. When I read your program description_COMMA_ I thought YES PLEASE. When I read the deadline_COMMA_ I thought_COMMA_ OH. But then I thought_COMMA_ WHY NOT TRY. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A few hours later_COMMA_ here we are.

column13: GONE WILD:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Well we've never been quite properly civilized_COMMA_ and it seems the situation is a comin' to a head//But if the only other option is minding our manners_COMMA_ let us tell you somethin mister cause we'd rather be dead. _NEWLINE_Yeah we_COMMA_ we have gone wild. And we ain't comin back._NEWLINE_We found kittens_COMMA_ chicks_COMMA_ bunnies_COMMA_ hens and foxes...We're the babes in the woods and we're anything but quiet//We're tired of grinding all your axes so we're cutting our losses. Mister better SPARE YOUR ROD CAUSE WE'D RATHER THE RIOT_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_**for Pussy Riot**
column14: In our professional lives_COMMA_ we work on film sets and in music studios. In our personal passion projects_COMMA_ we work in our band and art collective. We never make anything alone. Even when inspiration strikes and all the lyrics and melodies come out at once_COMMA_ the song does not exist without its beat and harmonies. Even when a true story comes directly from heart to page_COMMA_ the film does not exist without light and magic made by many more hearts and hands. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_In HIPS_COMMA_ we write equally and run all aesthetic_COMMA_ political_COMMA_ and business decisions through a democratic process.
column15: Just before the 2012 Presidential Election_COMMA_ Drew Denny surprised 450 theater-goers by dressing up like a talking vagina and critiquing Mitt Romney._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_First watch:_NEWLINE_http://vimeo.com/66487228_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Vagina's Voice provided by Sharon Mashihi_NEWLINE_Performance Score produced by Rachel James_NEWLINE_Vagina Costume by Emily Batson_NEWLINE_Projection Animated and Edited by Caitlin Craggs_NEWLINE_Graphic Design by Hazel Hill McCarthy III_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Then read:_NEWLINE_I think adults need more positive surprises in their life. No more "Surprise! You have three weeks to live" or "Surprise! You're fired" but_COMMA_ rather_COMMA_ "Surprise! A talking vagina is going to ask you to put your hands between your legs and find a toy while having an orgasm to 'Hail to the Chief' while fireworks explode on the big screen after making fun of Mitt Romney's homophobia and sexism :) _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_"Remember being a child and running wild in the forest and feeling like the earth was a very big place that had room for us all to be animals_COMMA_ free to be ourselves_COMMA_ to love and be loved and to celebrate the ecstatic turbulence of being. Now everybody make some noise!"_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_******* ******* ********* ********* *******_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_HIPS demos:_NEWLINE_https://soundcloud.com/hipsforlife/sets/hips-demos/s-fuFxb_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Over 6 months in 2013_COMMA_ HIPS recorded 6 demos in our bedrooms. In 2014_COMMA_ a fancy record label offered to release the recordings as an EP. We are preparing for national tour upon the release_COMMA_ thus providing us with a platform to exhibit the work we create at SMT in venues_COMMA_ galleries_COMMA_ museums_COMMA_ and theaters across the US and Canada.
column16: We are currently living in a collective on the Russian River_COMMA_ working together on a farm and making music every day. There are six permanent residents in our place_COMMA_ which is part of a network of many similar places. We participate in Friday night dinners_COMMA_ Sunday drives_COMMA_ Tuesday mushrooming expeditions_COMMA_ lead daily walks through the Redwood forest_COMMA_ and practice "Guerneville triathalons" which involve doing yoga by the river_COMMA_ riding our bikes to the oldest trees we can find (1_COMMA_500 year old Redwoods or 5_COMMA_000 year old Bays) and running up the biggest hills we can handle then riding home. We cook for and clean with one another_COMMA_ and we like it that way.
column17: Wildness is a part of our daily lives. It is tangible odorous sensual *natural* irrational emotional pleasurable and often quite feminine. For us. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_To survive_COMMA_ we work with plants and in the earth. We cultivate wildness - by digging our hands into the dirt and asking something of a seed. We cultivate wildness - by producing medicine for healing in inspiration._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As multi-media producers_COMMA_ we create works that provide participants with a portal to their own wild sides. We make music that wants movement. Movement that celebrates self and togetherness. In dialogue with images that empower feminine bodies and spirits - HIPS wants women to feel good about being women and wants men to feel good about women feeling good about being women.
column19: We would invite every woman in the world to the forest to do nothing but enjoy herself. Free daycare would be provided and no one would be allowed to clean or cook unless she truly desired. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Short of that_COMMA_ we would like to use our recordings as a score for a multi-media performance we would choreograph_COMMA_ shoot_COMMA_ edit and rehearse at SMT. Celebrating philogyny through image_COMMA_ sound_COMMA_ and movement - our piece will combine references to the *natural* world_COMMA_ Wildness_COMMA_ dance_COMMA_ "womens' work_COMMA_" queer theory_COMMA_ ecstasy and blood.
column20: Why HIPS?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Cause tits and ass get all the attention.
column21: If we are offered a national tour that begins before June_COMMA_ we will not be able to attend. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_However_COMMA_ our tour will probably not begin until July or August.
