column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: i grew up in northern california. my parents bought a new tract house in a town transitioning from rural to suburban. a fence surrounded our backyard_COMMA_ which separated us from the golden hills and live oaks beyond. eventually people built houses there too. the irrigation ditch running along our street became a sidewalk. we played in the sprinklers and went to church on sundays. i pushed a tiny pencil through the prayers printed in the program as we recited them. like checking things off a dreaded to do list._NEWLINE_in high school i’d escape to san francisco and the woods and beaches of marin. i searched for wildness in thrift stores_COMMA_ and magazines. there was no way to google it then. i moved to santa barbara and lived amongst the lemon-scented eucalyptus and the stale beer drenched fraternities. different types of wildness. each year i sat with the great monarch migration in a nearby coastal grove. i read recently their population is dwindling. _NEWLINE_i avoided los angeles for years. all i knew were the frightful things one could see from a car window on the 5 fwy during rush hour traffic. eventually it called me and i answered. i live here now_COMMA_ in a neighborhood with staircases that cut through people's yards_COMMA_ leading up or down to the next crooked street. there are still pockets of wildness in los angeles. I find it growing out of cracks in freeway overpasses_COMMA_ and the cemented LA river._NEWLINE_my work is designing costumes for film. i spend many days in warehouses climbing ladders to reach clothing hung three levels high. i love the vintage show girl and clown hat section at Warner Brothers Costume. It’s located at the very top of aisle 15 white. it's a rag tag bunch_COMMA_ all crooked sequins and bent feathers. there's a lot of character amongst the lopsided bows. I imagine they have their own wild stories to tell.
column14: my work is collaborative from start to finish. primarily film is created to be viewed by an audience. they interact with the medium and the story being told. but before that_COMMA_ it is imagined and shared by the writer_COMMA_ director and creative team. as a costume designer i imagine the way the world looks. each project is different. the director must also agree with my vision. with the help of other costumers_COMMA_ tailors and craftspeople we curate and create a selection of clothes that represent each character in the story. my favorite element of this process is when actors arrive for their fittings. we sift through the possibilities i've gathered until they find objects that aid them in becoming their character. it usually starts with a single item. the right pants_COMMA_ jacket or hat. and then it builds into an entire look. a real imagined person. these elements combine with hair_COMMA_ and make-up and finally walk onto the set a production designer has created. ideally at this moment an imagined world becomes unified and complete. the camera records the results. because there are so many ingredients_COMMA_ it takes a lot to create a great film. it's like alchemy. everything must combine in just the right way to become magic.
column15: http://emilybatson.com/the-pretty-one_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_last spring i designed the costumes for a film called The Pretty One. the story follows twin sisters. one beautiful_COMMA_ colorful and living an adventurous life in the city. the other shy_COMMA_ still living at home and wearing the faded old clothes from her dead mother's closet. through a terrible accident_COMMA_ a case of mistaken identity unfolds and the shy twin finds herself mirroring her sister's life_COMMA_ only to discover a new more authentic life for herself. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_one actress played both sisters and it was fun to create two very different characters who begin to bleed into one another as the story unravels. it's a story of self exploration and acceptance. about stretching beyond the places we find comfortable. while i worked on the film_COMMA_ i was simultaneously reading a book written by Marianne Woodman a Jungian psychologist. the books used fairytales to explain the process of balancing the feminine and masculine aspects of our psyche. _NEWLINE_the films seemed to use the same type of allegory. _NEWLINE_and likewise_COMMA_ it seems to somehow fit with the theme of wildness.
column16: after graduating from college_COMMA_ i went on the obligatory backpacking trip to europe. the first friend in my group split off to become engaged to her boyfriend in florence ( they never got married) the other fell in love with a man who owned a bungee jump on the greek island we were visiting. i found myself on a cog rail train climbing up the swiss alps to a chalet hostel. i lived there for 3 weeks and acted as the housekeeper in exchange for room and board. the owner was fastidious. there were notes stuck to every cupboard and above the sink explaining how to wash / use everything correctly. in the mornings i would do my chores. i learned that cleaning things that were already clean was far easier than cleaning things that were dirty. after work i would go for a hike with the other employees_COMMA_ or ride a bike down the mountain_COMMA_ or visit the hot springs or just sit and watch the fog roll in to the valley below. we would make communal meals in the evening_COMMA_ and slept in bunk beds at night.
column17: i was raised in a very structured environment. there were lots of obligatory rituals. the nature of my work is quite goal and deadline oriented. clothes must fit a specific body. alterations need to be completed at a specific time. the shirt must be blue. i would really just love to be in a place that offered a different approach to living and creating. it's an experience i think i would find both challenging and liberating. exploring how to allow myself to be. to create something from what arises. it is often an impulse that get's buried in the process of daily life. this sounds like a great opportunity to relax and explore what unfolds.
column19: one idea is to make a quilt. something tactile. a square for each day or each new discovery. maybe each square is a written story or a painting. maybe the story is in the color and the texture of the fabric. maybe it is pieced together from fabric contributed by and holding stories from each participant in the program. i only just learned about this residency so i haven't had too much time to formulate my ideas. i'm not quite ready to commit to the exact process. but i do always like to work with fabric. and i'm interested in how that interacts with stories and experience.
column20: question: is it too late to apply to this residency?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_answer: i certainly hope not.
column21: i'm committed to making time this year for a project or adventure that exists outside my chosen career field and my familiar landscape. these dates and this program seems like an ideal scenario. my schedule is varied but flexible :)

column12: Hike (A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT)_COMMA_ Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I live in New York_COMMA_ but I’m writing this from Beirut. I came here to work on two plays with a group of Lebanese and Ethiopian theater artists. With the help of a grant I’ll be here two months. I arrived yesterday. It smells like cumin and gasoline. It’s beautiful and noisy. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I mostly write plays_COMMA_ which means I live in a world of making things with other people. It also means I run away to my room to write. I have a big crush on novels_COMMA_ and essays_COMMA_ I think because I love how intimate reading is – language structures pass into one’s brain and talk with thoughts and memories. I’d like my plays to do that too._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I studied humanities at Yale_COMMA_ and then moved to Savannah with friends to start an arts nonprofit. The nonprofit lives on – after-school creative writing classes for middle schoolers – but I peeled off to come to New York because I missed the hurly-burly of a bigger city. I joined a writers’ group called Youngblood_COMMA_ and helped start a theater company called American Centaur. I’ve found collaborators who are kindred spirits. Lately I’ve been working on projects other people initiated: an adaptation of a Yiddish novel_COMMA_ an adaptation of Love’s Labours Lost_COMMA_ a musical about Earth First!_COMMA_ and now an adaptation with music of 20_COMMA_000 Leagues Under the Sea. (I guess it seems like a lot of adaptations_COMMA_ but “adaptation” is a veeeery loose term.) These are all in various stages of happening/just-happened/will-happen-one-day. It’s nice to have people with a certain amount of infrastructure approach me about joining them as a writer. It can be a challenge to take on material I didn’t select. I’ve learned a lot. I love it. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I write essays_COMMA_ too. But super slowly.
column14: For a while I thought I might have been a maker of devised theater_COMMA_ who enters a rehearsal room with a set of questions and prompts_COMMA_ guides a flock of actors_COMMA_ and stitches together the resulting material into a “collaborative” piece. Now I think I am mostly a playwright_COMMA_ which is to say_COMMA_ someone who writes a play and brings it to rehearsal. I like following a thought very far down a road. Also I’m not good at talking about how a thing should be_COMMA_ I’m better at just making the thing itself_COMMA_ based on inarticulate thoughts and sensations – I stew for weeks and then write something askew_COMMA_ just so_COMMA_ aslant from reality in some satisfyingly itchy way. Once the thing is there_COMMA_ on a page_COMMA_ it is a joy to talk about it with collaborators_COMMA_ to test its joints and see what squeaks_COMMA_ to be challenged in the spots where I pulled up short to dive deeper. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I recently made a piece in which I wrote a script for a particular group of actors_COMMA_ some of whom I knew well and others of whom I didn’t. They all played characters who had their actual names. One told me that it was uncanny_COMMA_ how close to home some of the lines I’d written for him hit. (I’m interested in understanding that more: why?) Increasingly_COMMA_ I’m interested in this process of writing for specific performers because real people are strange and lovely and tug my writing in unexpected directions._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A good playwright knows how to strike each element of live theater – objects_COMMA_ actors_COMMA_ space_COMMA_ audience – and let it ring out loud clear and beautiful in its own key. That’s good collaboration_COMMA_ I think.
column15: This is not a project I initiated or wrote but that’s partly my point. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Two summers ago_COMMA_ I played one of the students in a bootleg punk-anarchist Les Mis that I heard about and showed up for. There were fifty-two of us. We lived in a field and rehearsed under a circus tent. I had a few solo lines but mostly I sang in the chorus and carried around a paper-mache gun and looked adoringly at the actor playing Enjolras. I learned to use a sewing machine_COMMA_ I learned how to sing high without hurting my voice_COMMA_ I learned how to dumpster dive_COMMA_ I got terribly sick_COMMA_ I washed naked in the woods_COMMA_ I made dear friends_COMMA_ and I sprained an ankle. All fifty-two of us were putting in sixteen-hour days. I’d come because I wanted to. I liked just about everyone. Still_COMMA_ I found myself retreating into an I sometimes_COMMA_ and the big thing I learned was how not run away from a We. I’s are important and it’s easy to hold fast to an I because your I is what you know. We is no one’s I_COMMA_ We is uncertain_COMMA_ I can’t control We. When We finally performed Les Mis – six times_COMMA_ in four cities – We were performing a schmaltzy Broadway hit but we were also performing the We we’d made in that month in that field. The whole endeavor was ridiculous_COMMA_ and We were performing the strangeness of We’s loyalty to it. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_That gets at something essential to me: Set up something ridiculous_COMMA_ and have the perverse patience to be loyal to it. Step out of what you know_COMMA_ and have the courage to stand on ridiculous ground. When you do that_COMMA_ people gather_COMMA_ however ridiculously_COMMA_ and when people gather and work hard and are silly together… that’s sacred.
column16: That summer in Vermont was one. Fifty people lived in tents and ate together and worked together and took turns emptying the bucket we all pooped in. I worked hard_COMMA_ and occasionally took time to myself – that was how I existed in that space. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Until recently_COMMA_ I lived in a nine-person warehouse space in Brooklyn. There was no unifying project – people generally kept to themselves – but we shared cleaning duties_COMMA_ and had to make a couple of thorny decisions as a group. Those decisions were tricky_COMMA_ and one in particular caused some damage – mostly to one house member in particular_COMMA_ but to everyone else_COMMA_ too_COMMA_ I’d argue. My read on it is this: There were longstanding rules and policies about house membership. Rules are important. But. It’s dangerous to avoid open conversation about conflict in favor of impartial rule-enforcement. Rules are rules_COMMA_ but people are people_COMMA_ and the chance to hear and be heard are what allow us to live together well._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I love cooking with people. I love standing in a kitchen together_COMMA_ with people coming and going. I love cleaning up together. I love huge stacks of mismatched plates.
column17: Last year I fell in love with a few anarchist thinkers_COMMA_ and this year I fell in love with a few Jewish thinkers. I love the anarchists because they love the mess of uncertainty_COMMA_ and because they remind me to walk and encounter people and worlds without the handrails of the familiar. I love the Jewish thinkers because they love the creative power of structure. They have a radical commitment to constructing spaces – however narrow-seeming – of the sacred in this world. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The session on wildness seems like a space where anarchists and Jews might meet._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I’m interested in how that space might inform my creative practice. I’d relish the chance to leave the physical architecture of New York City_COMMA_ and the familiar mental architecture of the writer’s space or rehearsal room. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My instinct is that Jewish law exists in conversation with the world’s wildness. My instinct is that clarifying the ground on which one stands – which is what Jewish law is doing – allows one to relate to wildness without demand_COMMA_ or possessiveness. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Because as much as I love anarchist thought_COMMA_ I worry that an infatuation with a certain aesthetic of anarchy (as opposed to an anarchist way of thinking) risks exploiting the people and the world around us. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My plays are always part prayer; they are a form of research into freedom. I am always trying to catch something alive_COMMA_ delicate_COMMA_ green-smelling_COMMA_ wild in my plays_COMMA_ however carefully constructed and rigorously rehearsed.
column18: I'm interested in forgetting as a creative practice. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm still working out what that means._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm interested in how forgetting -- or at least attending to the spaces around the things we can't remember -- creates space for self-reinvention. I've always felt like I'll never be the old Henry James "writer is someone on whom nothing is lost" thing because I have such a bad memory for things._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm interested in exploring how lapses in memory make us who we are. I'm interested in how our lapses interact with others' rememberings_COMMA_ or vice versa_COMMA_ and how lapses behave when they meet other lapses. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm interested in exploring strong emotional attachments that have been emptied of any content ("I don't remember why I love this place"). Could we fabricate such attachments? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm interested in the fear that attends the possibility of not knowing some key part of one's past. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'd like to investigate ways of reproducing such blank spaces in art_COMMA_ especially embodied art like theater or dance or film.
column19: I am interested in a play as a container_COMMA_ and dramatic structure – however loosely understood – as architecture. So: I would like to build a small room that was also a play. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would use my limited building skills – and perhaps acquire new ones – to construct the room from wood_COMMA_ fabric_COMMA_ plastic_COMMA_ glass… As I build the room_COMMA_ I’d be writing text that corresponds to different parts of the space. A song for this hole_COMMA_ an argument for that roof beam. I’m curious if paying attention to what makes a sturdy room could result in an unexpectedly sturdy but nonlinear play. Depending on how far I get_COMMA_ I might sleep in the room_COMMA_ eat in the room_COMMA_ host other people who want to come visit the room_COMMA_ and see how all that could inform the play. There will of course be chinks in the room for breeze or rain or grass smells and of course the hope is that those things end up in the play_COMMA_ too. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Texts behind this are maybe Woolf_COMMA_ A Room of One’s Own_COMMA_ Baldwin_COMMA_ Giovanni’s Room_COMMA_ Heschel on the architecture of time_COMMA_ and Renee Gladman’s on architectural sentences and imaginary places.
column20: Do you feel good at talking about your art? Do you think it's important to be good at talking about your art? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I don't feel great at talking about my art. I'm getting better. I know it can be super helpful to be able to talk about one's art_COMMA_ but I think I also would like to make that doesn't quite bear talking about.
column21: I might have an obligation (also upstate) that wraps up June 8_COMMA_ but other than that would be available for either the hike or Session A.
column23: I don't eat meat_COMMA_ but other than that anything. I do eat eggs.

column10: http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/New-Kid-in-Town-2623971.php_NEWLINE_(An article in the SF Chronicle when I began my year as a Core Company member at A.C.T.)_NEWLINE_http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2006/07/28/acting_brings_warmth_to_dark_red_light_winter/?camp=pm_NEWLINE_(a review of Red Light Winter...see 5th paragraph)_NEWLINE_http://www.backstage.com/review/ny-theater/off-broadway/the-shaughraun/_NEWLINE_(a review of The Shaughraun..see final sentences)_NEWLINE_http://aseatontheaisle.blogspot.com/2011/05/off-broadway-shaughraun.html_NEWLINE_(another_COMMA_ see final sentence)_NEWLINE_http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/sanfran/s1198.html_NEWLINE_(of Abigail's Party_COMMA_ see second to last paragraph)
column13: I'm a creative spirit who caught the acting bug at age 11 when reciting The Highwayman to her fellow fifth grade classmates. I'm a musician who studied classical piano for 8 years and now is trying her luck as a singer in an alternative rock band. I'm someone who improvises. Who has a quick wit. Who likes puns and isn't afraid to throw you one the moment it occurs to her. I'm someone who understands rhythm. Who wonders if I should try freestyling for reals because any time I give it a go at a party I'm kind of ridiculously awesome at it. I'm a writer with lots of ideas (and scenes) but who has yet to write her first full length play. I am a theater and film goer and music listener with a keen eye and ear for what moves me and captures me and surprises me and what looks forced and pushed and cliche and patronizing. I'm a passionate artist who wants to create that which moves and captures and surprises and transports people. I'm someone who thinks she'd make a great director -- of film or theater -- because she understands what it is to be an actor and what it is to be an audience and because she can communicate and consider and lead and follow. I'm someone who thinks she'd make an excellent DJ because she knows what kind of music drives her to dance and she thinks it's excellent stuff. I am an actress who does really good work. Work her classmates and teachers admire. Work that landed her a full tuition scholarship to ACT_COMMA_ and has landed her some great jobs and gotten her some great reviews. I'm an actress who doesn't work as much as she'd like to. I'm an actress who wants to create something.
column14: I've learned that the best kind of acting is collaborative. When actors are really playing off each other. The circle of collaborators in this case is made wider by the director and the playwright_COMMA_ and in performance the audience - all offering further possibilities for integration and inspiration. My goal as an actor is to do my preparation_COMMA_ to know where I'm coming from_COMMA_ and then to remain open to how these other elements will affect or guide me in the moment. When the channels are open it can feel like these elements are working both with me and through me. It feels sublime_COMMA_ and I daresay spiritual. There's excitement in the unknown and anchoring in the flow of what's happening. I've encountered something similar in music_COMMA_ which is why I'm now in a band._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Collaboration also exists at a far more messy_COMMA_ less polished level. And the creative work I've done with Clown_COMMA_ Improv_COMMA_ Movement based composition_COMMA_ and Sketch Comedy are examples of that. There is usually more chaos_COMMA_ more mess_COMMA_ and perhaps a need for more negotiation_COMMA_ and compromise. Navigating those waters with my co-creators can become an art itself_COMMA_ but things generally just find a way of taking shape and working out. It's very cool to be a part of that. There is often such willingness in the room_COMMA_ such allowance_COMMA_ and such a unique group dynamic_COMMA_ that the work we end up with is something we never could have found without each other or without the mess.
column15: Senior year at Brown I took a class called Solo Performance. 12 students wrote 12 solo shows. My show was called Whitenoise; it was about my family. The divorce_COMMA_ the remarriages_COMMA_ the coming of age_COMMA_ the dark secrets_COMMA_ and perhaps more interesting the stories about my grandmother_COMMA_ her use of LSD_COMMA_ a shady character she dated_COMMA_ and what he might or might not have done to my aunt. It was easy enough to pour out the material. To bring it in and perform it for my peers. But the piece really came together when I decided to incorporate a performance art device I'd developed a year earlier in a class called Advanced Performance. Our professor had given us the assignment "Overheard Conversations;" I eavesdropped at cafes_COMMA_ took notes_COMMA_ and poured over them...how would I perform this_COMMA_ what was the link... I arrived at a conclusion about superficiality -- that sometimes we need the superficial just to converse -- and this led me to the idea of animating one's face with make up in order to communicate. In the practicing of it_COMMA_ I discovered exciting nuanced choices I could make. In the performing of it...success! The class loved it. An exchange took place. And the feedback from that class inspired me to bring it in to the next one_COMMA_ where I found out it could server to anchor my show. I explored the construct further the following year when I performed a shortened version of the show - or you might call it a lengthened version of the performance art - at two different spaces in San Francisco. I use this example so you can get a sense of how I might play with an idea_COMMA_ and how I might work with that idea and bring it to performance. Although the creation was a solo venture_COMMA_ without the classes_COMMA_ without the spaces and the people that inspired risk_COMMA_ accepted flops_COMMA_ offered feedback_COMMA_ and hoped for brilliance_COMMA_ nothing would have happened.
column16: I am my happiest in communal living situations. I currently live in my 6th communal sitch since college. I've found most on Craigslist_COMMA_ including this one. I joined a 7 roommate_COMMA_ 3 story house in Ditmas Park just a couple summers ago. A house with a porch_COMMA_ laundry_COMMA_ the occasional Sunday night dinner_COMMA_ and even some biggish parties. Totally awesome stuff for yours truly. Then our lease holder's girlfriend moved in_COMMA_ and the couple began fighting and calling the cops on each other and throwing computer monitors down the stairs and giving each other black eyes_COMMA_ so I and three girls moved out. We're now in the top 2 floors of another lovely house with laundry and porches in the same hood. We have dinner parties sometimes and are looking forward to using our lovely back garden when the weather gets nice. Oh and there are no big fights or black eyes. We get along really really well.
column17: Sometimes I'm told I think too much. It's true. I do. I can. However I have my brain to thank for some of the biggest blessings I've encountered in my life_COMMA_ and some of the greatest achievements. I like the idea of exploring thinking. Perhaps by not thinking. Knowing by not knowing. I believe that my heart and soul and instincts are perhaps smarter and more keenly equipped to lead my artistic endeavors than my mind_COMMA_ yet my mind is certainly a necessary part of the equation! I'm interested in what I might be separating from or letting go of by unthinking. How this might change my approach to projects or life in general. Or what I might integrate into my process by knowing thinking differently. It seems confusing and therefore rich ground for me to play in. It also parallels a theme I'm pondering in my life right now...letting go versus showing up. When to release. When to follow. When to think. When to know. When to not know. When to not think. Trusting. Leaping. Tuning in to flow._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_As I mentioned before I'm a girl with ideas. Maybe it's the Libra Moon/Rising in me. They say airy people have lots of ideas they don't follow through on. I also have an Aries sun (opposite sign of Libra) so if there is validity to this stuff it may help to explain why I can be a bit of a frustrated artist or individual. Pulled by polarity. One who has fiery instincts to follow_COMMA_ but keen to consider and weigh the possible outcomes. I want a blank canvas. Space. Time. To play. To develop something. To integrate the ideas and the skills. A play. A film. A performance art piece. Webisodes. I'm truly not sure yet. But I'm capable. And I'm talented. And I look forward to discovering the piece would manifest through me at SMT.
column19: There was a time I stood on the subway platform at Broadway/Lafayette_COMMA_ and I stared at the sign that read "Broadway" above this little cutout in the wall that almost looked like a door. I imagined myself sitting there with a pickaxe_COMMA_ slowly chiseling away like a scene in a Matthew Barney film. Eventually I'd find a door behind the concrete and I'd chisel and pull and finally end up crawling out of a hole in a big green field somewhere and I'd look down and see this tiny little rock I crawled out of. And then I'd drop kick it down the field. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I can envision creating and directing a film at SMT that has a bridge between the real and the unreal. I imagine special effects and/or animation would help to most fully realize this_COMMA_ but the goal would be to make the viewer intimate with the main character's mind. How she sees_COMMA_ how she dreams. Perhaps her journey would be about how she uses the unreal to function in the real_COMMA_ and/or vice versa_COMMA_ or where she finally chooses to dwell and why. Something rich in images and dreamlike ideas. Perhaps the film just is fantasy and there would be nothing real about it. Other than the character's journey. A recognizably human one.
column20: What will you want to teach your children when it comes to art? I will encourage play. Lots of play! I will sing to them at night and join in when they sing in the car. Any old nonsense. I will make sure they spend plenty of time outside. I will teach them how to build troll houses by the stream and sing songs around a campfire and I will encourage the building of forts in a variety of locations with a variety of materials. I will encourage time alone for them. To think. To draw. To nurture their imaginations. I will love what they do and encourage them to love what they do too. (For the record_COMMA_ I don't have kids. But I felt inclined to write this. When I think of my inner artist I think about childhood. Mine and my unborn's.) And to close I'd just like to add this quote from Einstein a friend just posted on Facebook: Play is the highest form of research. Thank you!!
column21: None that I know of at this time. (Also I'm sorry this is late. I saw it on Josephine's Facebook feed at the last minute and thought...yeah... yes. Hope it is still acceptable. Cheers.)
column23: I'll eat anything for the most part_COMMA_ but if I eat meat I prefer it be organic. I like organic stuff in general. Also raw milk or raw milk cheeses is nice.

column10: Audio Smut - the audio documentary project that consumes my existence_NEWLINE_http://audiosmut.ca/about/ _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A sound installation we did in collaboration w Wanderlust_NEWLINE_http://audiosmut.ca/experiments/the-wanderlust-illicit-couples-retreat/_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Radio Cabaret - a variety show of audio documentary based performances_NEWLINE_http://radiocabaret.org/_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I've been asked to judge at a relatively prestigious documentary festival_NEWLINE_http://www.inthedarkradio.org/?page_id=5967
column12: Hike (A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT)_COMMA_ Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: 1: I am passionate and driven. I am sensitive and aware._NEWLINE_2: I work with audio. My mission is to present audio in such a way that inspires a listener to feel its magic the way I do. Hence_COMMA_ I make work that strives to touch hearts in all ways that audio might do. In headphones_COMMA_ (radio show format)_COMMA_ in unexpected places (installation format)_COMMA_ as part of performance (incorporating audio into music performances_COMMA_ puppet shows_COMMA_ theater performances etc.)_NEWLINE_3: I am interested in a critical approach to stories about love_COMMA_ sex_COMMA_ bodies and intimacy. I have a sprouting interest in doing non-fiction work investigating class and mental health._NEWLINE_4: I am dedicated to finding innovative ways of building alternative institutions that can support fresh art making. _NEWLINE_5: There is an important letter. Those who have the letter_COMMA_ please forward to everyone else on the panel.
column14: 1: I embed others in my process from beginning to end_COMMA_ in order to get feedback at multiple points in the course of developing a final piece. Also to keep me accountable to my internal deadlines._NEWLINE_2: I deeply enjoy using the mastery of my craft in harmony with the mastery of someone else's craft; to create multi-layered work.
column15: MAGIC SOUND BOOTH: http://audiosmut.ca/experiments/italian-radio-magic/_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I was at a very serious journalism festival in Italy_COMMA_ where I had been invited to present my work. It was already slightly disruptive of us to simply announce our name: Audio Smut_COMMA_ while on panels with serious journalists from the Washington Post and the New Yorker. Fortunately_COMMA_ the head of the audio department (who invited us) has a Finbloom-esque mischeiviousness about him. We had his 100% support._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The festival was comprised of formal seminar style talks_COMMA_ formal screenings_COMMA_ and formal panel discussions. My collaborator and I created a large installation. It had flowing purple fabric_COMMA_ gauzy pink tool_COMMA_ gold sparkles. It was a portable booth_COMMA_ where two people could escape the crowds and stand in privacy_COMMA_ enshrouded by the flowing fabric and sparkling lights. Inside_COMMA_ our subjects were greeted by a lady in a pink jacket. Dangling from the ceiling were 3 cards_COMMA_ with 3 questions. The subject would pick a question_COMMA_ and each would share a story pertaining to the question. All was audio recorded_COMMA_ for use in future documentary work. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_The reception was explosive. We had a line-up of 15-20 going all afternoon. People were asking about it the entire festival: "Are you going to remount the magic sound booth?". It was a sight for sore eyes. This project strikes me as SMT-esque_COMMA_ in that it looked at what was possible in a given setting and went wacky on what was expected.
column16: I live in a big house with 5 other people and I fucking love it. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I'm really good at doing dishes now. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I went to SMT and lived there for 11 days give or take and I was not annoyed or exhausted of being around people. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I love sleepovers and I have them all the time.
column17: Reconstructing Wildness:_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_One of my goals as an artist is to unravel the tight grip that my intellectual mind has on my process. I want access my unbridled spirit. _NEWLINE_I think that my unbridled spirit is tapped into something true and fresh in me. I think analysis should come after_COMMA_ or happen at a different time than creating. I would like to practice making art by trusting my instincts. I think this is the only way you can truly tap in to the collective unconscious_COMMA_ which is where the truths-we-know-but-are-afraid-to-say live. Another of my goals as an artist is to say the truths-we-know-but-are-afraid-to-say (or even better: the truths we aren't' sure about_COMMA_ and are afraid to say)
column18: I would like to lead a secret luxury game. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I think there is always a near-breaking point when on a wilderness adventure. A point where you are tired_COMMA_ and hungry_COMMA_ and damp_COMMA_ and cold. I would like to have everyone write down something they need to feel cared for on a piece of paper. Then distribute the papers at random. It is your job to give the person on the paper what they need_COMMA_ when you think they need it.
column19: I would collaboratively write_COMMA_ mix and master an album of non-fiction audio infused music. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_OR_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would bring Bekky O'Neill (qualityslippersproductions.com) to SMT as my partner in crime. We would create a toy theater puppet show_COMMA_ which I would create a score and sound design for. The toy theater puppet show features O'Neill's gorgeous hand drawn_COMMA_ hand made puppets and set design. The story features voices from intimate interviews_COMMA_ on a topic derived from the-truth-that-we-aren't-sure-about-and-are-afraid-to-say. There will be explicit sexual content that is true to life. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_OR_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I would like to create a sound designed performance_COMMA_ where someone's movements are designed as in the first scene of Daisies.
column20: Why is going to SMT important to you?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Going to SMT is important to me because I am thoroughly and completely and obsessively engrossed in my radio work_COMMA_ and I want to break the fuck out and shake up my process. Think new thoughts. Answer to new rules.

column13: I was born in Chicago. I started in TV to create a network run entirely by children. that was 1993-ish. I have - to an extent - done that successfully in small pieces_COMMA_ but the $$ has been a little challenging. For the past ten years I have mostly made my living covering fashion (fun). Lately I've been doing some shooting for THE DOCTORS_COMMA_ a daytime talk show_COMMA_ shooting vagina-related material. children's tv. fashion. vaginas. I'm on a roll... and I am loving shooting for other people instead of just for my own projects. I want to build my well spring muscle_COMMA_ the thoughtful and grounded joy that gushes tactfully out of oneself - that is based on one's love for life and experiences and both makes sense and is mysteriously ethereal and not-able-to-be-planned. I want this because I have spent alot of my life creating within others' boundaries and I'm ready to be. in. charge. this is why I would like to be educated in and with SMT.
column14: I love working with people_COMMA_ creating space for others to do their best work. and I am ETERNALLY GRATEFUL to the few people who have done that for me. I like to pull a team together based on what each person does well_COMMA_ and create from there. that said_COMMA_ I can be an anxiety monster and that is probably my greatest professional and creative obstacle. I know the way to make my projects be finished well and on time and there is not always the time to give everyone to their creative processes. this is the greatest challenge working with children - the perfect storm of process and product. a brilliant video editor has been MY key to driving the project into excellence.
column15: I wrote poems and Short Short Stories in my early twenties to overcome writers block. Most of them are in a box somewhere_COMMA_ but are still relevant. The dancing of words that would be fun to tap into again in a raw way...._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am commercial_COMMA_ for lack of a better word_COMMA_ meaning I mostly always work for money since I NEED money and also don't seem to have the discipline to get anything finished without a deadline / air date. double necessity. that said_COMMA_ I always bring an authentic perspective to the work and I think that's what my clients appreciate about me._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_TR/DR (a piece about blended consonants) made by kids for The Electric Company (Sesame Workshop)_NEWLINE_https://vimeo.com/55393073_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_ARMANI (what does New York think of Armani) made for Armani_NEWLINE_https://vimeo.com/77386066
column16: In San Francisco I lived in two apartments with two bunches of people and we all worked together in various ways. In my first apartment_COMMA_ my roommates and I were the first stop for our friends moving to SF from the east coast. They stayed with us until they found an apartment_COMMA_ usually with other friends of ours or theirs - all blended together. My second 'communal' apartment was great too. We all cooked meals together_COMMA_ had a 'house' grocery list that we all shared in $ and collecting (bulk and farmers market). One of my roommates was founding the Wise Fool Puppet Company so even though I was working ridiculous hours (overnight work shifts and school all day)_COMMA_ I could still come home and help make puppets for a while_COMMA_ share a meal that we all cooked_COMMA_ and take a bath which was my then-version of eight hours of sleep. I also had the added benefit of participating in all the Wise Fool events - parades_COMMA_ plays. I could pop my stilts on and go... able to keep my own packed schedule and still participate in and support my friends amazing company. I have also lived communally shorter term on vacations and often fantasize about living in a more collective environment...with children and families or fun adventuresome adults. or both.
column17: A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT:_NEWLINE_This session will aid my open-minded development by dropping me into the deep end of SMT_COMMA_ really playing with other people who are involved in the school and/or who are attracted to the school – a nice sampling of people ready to dive in and explore together. I look forward to being in a state of mind that is receptive to spontaneous communal creation_COMMA_ support_COMMA_ and loving challenge._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING_NEWLINE_The length of time that this session is in and of itself has the possibility of opening me up to manifest creation that is out of my own unique box. I like that it seems a little loose but still has required reading_COMMA_ as well as challenges for the mind/body/spirit.
column18: off the top of my head:_NEWLINE_1) everyone offers one word. each person must make a poem out of everyone's words and then do a poetry reading_NEWLINE_2) each person must make one adornment out of the natural environment and this adornment is the core of their character during one whole meal with the others_NEWLINE_3) in a river_COMMA_ each participant makes a sculpture in the moving water out of stones. one (self) selected gallery guide takes the group for a tour of each sculpture as each artist tells how his/her work is like their grandmother - or any older ancestor they choose
column19: I have shot a couple of interviews and would like to shoot MANY of people talking about the first time they had sex. This is a wide open question that can get into first orgasm_COMMA_ first (extreme feeling) sexual experience at ANY age.... the first sex with the boyfriend/girlfriend from a great relationship in which they WAITED_COMMA_ tainted childhood experiences_COMMA_ same-sex titillation that felt wrong/great/confusing (and WHY). if I were to start NOW_COMMA_ I'd need full cooperation of people at SMT to interview them (since I only have two so far) and maybe it would start out with the raw_COMMA_ first person_COMMA_ first remembrance and then I could edit that and then add group discussions of sex - explore with a wider group in a more general fashion. so much to talk about sex... we could go on and on..._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I also have shot a MILLION hours of my nieces and nephews growing up and it would be cool to really sit down and hack away at that... load it all up and organize_COMMA_ make a plan...
column20: Which way does infinity go?_NEWLINE_because of our thinking_COMMA_ infinity goes deep - inside and out. infinity is the on and on of our love for someone_COMMA_ the anguish that comes with it_COMMA_ the piled on thoughts that make us feel about something and then also release the feelings to just. be. LOVE. (which is all we are anyway). because of our thinking_COMMA_ we can either allow ourselves to just BE_COMMA_ a state in which love_COMMA_ spirit_COMMA_ light flows through us... or we can COMPLICATE things INFINITESSIMALY with second guesses and layers of speculation. this_COMMA_ to me_COMMA_ is infinity going IN..._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Infinity going OUT may be more than 100 words...not so sure about counting now... it's ALL the possibility... the COUNTRIES where we have not been_COMMA_ the culture that we cannot grasp - from the Maharaja to sex trafficking to outer space.... where we CAN go is all still in our thinking because if we could think differently_COMMA_ then we could all think the same and have no wars and drink coconut milk on the beach......so THINKING is infinity because it's ever evolving and ever driving the choices we make OUTWARDLY. and Worldy...

column12: Hike (A SUMMIT ON A SUMMIT)_COMMA_ Session B (UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING)
column13: My first word was "no". My virtue is the questions that I can't let go of; the why_COMMA_ the so what_COMMA_ the what for_COMMA_ and the what does it mean. As tiring and difficult as they are_COMMA_ I am committed to them. My work deals more with the "how" of fear. Fear as a given element in a social life_COMMA_ and how to acknowledge_COMMA_ allow_COMMA_ and circumvent fear of other people that keeps me moving and can push me to isolation. Through my work_COMMA_ individual or collaborative_COMMA_ my goal is to create situations and systems that bring people toward each other. I draw on tactics from relational aesthetics and social practice_COMMA_ engineering spaces for interaction and producing relationships as the work of art. For example_COMMA_ I have worked with Craigslist offering my sponsorship- or advice_COMMA_ presence_COMMA_ friendship_COMMA_ mentorship- to strangers on the internet. The relationships and conversations that were born of that offer are what I consider my art. I value making myself as vulnerable as I am asking participants in my work to become. I consider my work a process or tool with which myself and those involved can grow.
column14: My practice is often physically collaborative. I work with another person to make the piece of art. Sometimes this means building with another person_COMMA_ hashing out every measurement and angle aloud. Sometimes it means that conversation is an integral part of the project_COMMA_ and people volunteer to talk to me. Sometimes it is collaborative in that I ran my design/writing/idea by ten people in my community before I got to the final piece. I always look at my work with other people and they help me to figure out what the piece is_COMMA_ what it does_COMMA_ what it means_COMMA_ and why it exists. Or at least bring me closer to understanding.
column15: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B16HTlj0PVuUZ2ZnekhTelF3bW8/edit?usp=sharing_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_This project is ongoing. I meet with people (anyone who signs up)_COMMA_ and we talk about what isn't working in their lives_COMMA_ the things that are running them around_COMMA_ or the feeling they can't seem to describe. This conversation usually lasts 45 minutes to an hour._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Afterwards_COMMA_ I sit with what I've heard_COMMA_ and try to distill a theme or trend. From this I write a prescription_COMMA_ which is a string of words and a course of sugar pills. I design the packaging and literature of the prescription from scratch for each "patient".
column16: I've lived in communal houses when I was younger in Santa Cruz_COMMA_ CA. Sometimes it was lovely_COMMA_ and sometimes it was oppressive. It was lovely when we communicated effectively_COMMA_ and had systems of organization we all agreed upon. With these things in place_COMMA_ I lived joyfully with seven other people in a house by the beach. We met weekly for check-ins about our house and our lives. I've lived in communal houses in which the communication was lacking_COMMA_ or the co-habitators had no interest in maintaining a comfortable environment for everyone in the house.
column17: I am so excited about this session that I am filling out this whole application 4 days after the deadline_COMMA_ with no idea if it will even submit when I hit the button. Thinking as a muscle_COMMA_ as an excursive regimen_COMMA_ as an occupation_COMMA_ as a sport is critical to my work_COMMA_ my life_COMMA_ and my faith. I want help in entering a liminal thinking space I've never visited_COMMA_ to think what I do not know how to think. My understanding of art is informed by phenomenology and objects and people defining themselves over and over again by their relationships. To be worked by this session I think would allow me to approach my work with a much more delicate approach to the spaces of ambiguity in my work.
column18: A guided meditation fraught with assumptions.
column19: With unlimited funding I'd build a ropes course. 50 feet above the ground in the trees. It would take 2 or more hours to traverse the entirety. And then I would build_COMMA_ with the help of everyone there_COMMA_ houses in the trees while we stand on the wires and platforms of the ropes course. We would wear harnesses and carabiners_COMMA_ so it'd be safe and possible. I'm not immediately certain what this has to do with the course I'd love to take_COMMA_ but given unlimited funding in any scenario I want to do this.
column20: What was the most pressing question on your mind two years ago_COMMA_ a year ago and what is it now?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Two years ago I wanted to know HOW TO GET UP AND NOT FALL DOWN. How to get up on time_COMMA_ check all the things off the list_COMMA_ be nice to fellows_COMMA_ eat_COMMA_ and all these exhausting things (or rather things that were exhausting then) without lapsing into NOT GETTING UP._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A year ago I wanted to know HOW TO BE GOOD_COMMA_ how to satisfy moral criteria of everyone at once. How to never be bad. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Now I want to know HOW TO MAINTAIN EMPATHY THROUGH CHAOS. I am busy every moment_COMMA_ and I have failed to schedule time to be available to people around me. Do I need to schedule empathy in a weekly planner?

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: Firstly_COMMA_ I'm aware that I've missed the deadline and I'd like to apologize. I came across the program in December_COMMA_ but hadn't checked back for a deadline. I thought I should try for a spot anyway. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I am a passionate_COMMA_ curious artist_COMMA_ who likes to occupy and agitate the background. I graduate from York University in 2012 with a BFA in Visual Art and Psychology. I'm currently working on my MA in Art History at York University. I work in performance_COMMA_ sound_COMMA_ video and multiples to explore magic and queerness. I volunteer at an LGBTQ youth service in the city and regularly attend community education sessions. I try to find creative and nurturing ways to build my community_COMMA_ without falling adhering to dogmas and (sometimes limiting) tropes. I try to be aware of my energy_COMMA_ the space I find myself in and those around me (or not).
column14: I would describe my creative/intellectual practice as mischievous. I like to slip around things and circle them. I think that humour is an important part of my practice_COMMA_ which is inherently social. Apart from it's communicative nature_COMMA_ humour is the unexpected tipping point between the ludacris and the grotesque. Play with affective poles is central to my work. My sense of humour is used to side-eye rational and/or hegemonic processes. I hope that my work creates moments of confusion and discomfort_COMMA_ which I feel are fertile spaces for growth and understanding.
column15: I was a part of a group show in 2011 called Ululology. The show was a quasi-response to the Occupy Movement_COMMA_ which was quite active at that time. Myself and five other sound artists worked independently on projects and periodically shared our progress with one another. At the end of a few weeks_COMMA_ our work was placed in the same gallery space. None of the works were made for headphones_COMMA_ so the possibility of being heard was constantly negotiated. The volumes were altered daily to create different relationships and reconstruct the space. My project was an extremely loud_COMMA_ deep bass piece which vibrated the only seating in the room_COMMA_ and a sound track of shaking tea sets.
column16: I aspire to live in a communal home in the future but have not been able to as of yet. I've stayed in hostels on a number of occasions for majority of my travelling_COMMA_ the longest being a 14 day stay in Vancouver. I feel that I can successfully read the room and respect the needs of those around me. I prefer to share space with others and have never had any issues with listening and communication or sharing responsibilities. I am a very clean and hardworking housemate.
column17: The poles of nature and culture are present in both my art practice and my research. My explorations of the supernatural always return to the laws of nature_COMMA_ religious institutions_COMMA_ essence and the body. How can something exist outside of nature if nature is all encompassing? What does it mean for something to be alive or not? In what ways is History_COMMA_ that is to say the forward facing path of civilization_COMMA_ distinct from muscle memory and memory in general? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_For my MA research_COMMA_ I analyze the dissemination of an urban_COMMA_ self-identified "half-breed" indigenous filmmaker named Ariel Smith. Her videos question naivety and gender performances. I am using the trickster figure as a framework for her artistic practice and the sneaky_COMMA_ somewhat non-human characters in her work. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Also_COMMA_ I feel that the living experience itself will be a part of processing the theme. I am very excited to have the opportunity to express myself and learn from others in a communal environment.
column19: I would love to see underwater_COMMA_ underground or avian series of performances. The performances could be in fox-like dens_COMMA_ large bird nests or a windowless_COMMA_ flying_COMMA_ brick room.
column20: What is your favourite word? _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_A friend of mine_COMMA_ who is a writer_COMMA_ once used the word mezzochist to describe me. The word is meant to describe someone or something which experiences pleasure from occupying a middle ground. It is closely followed by the word misty.

column10: I don't have a website. I am in the midst of creating one. This is part of why I am applying to this residency... to elaborate my ideas about beginning a project/consortium.
column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)
column13: I have been grieving the loss of my inner wilderness ever since I was a child_COMMA_ and have circled around between the study of depth psychology_COMMA_ Zen Buddhism_COMMA_ and wilderness Rites of Passage for the past two decades. I want to bring these together_COMMA_ to explore Edge Habitat_COMMA_ using wilderness as a metaphor for what we have lost as a civilization_COMMA_ and what we grieve as individuals.
column14: I am beginning to conceive of a consortium of people_COMMA_ living and working around the world_COMMA_ who in their own ways_COMMA_ are working to bridge the gap between civilization (and all the domestications that come with that) and wildness. This gap exists between ourselves and our darkest parts_COMMA_ between ourselves and others_COMMA_ between past and future (in the absence of presence)_COMMA_ and between domesticated and wild_COMMA_ so anyone who is engaged in exploring this gap is necessarily a part of the movement towards healing.
column15: I don't have any examples of art work. I only have a fledgling website. None of my work has been documented_COMMA_ it is in the realm of group work_COMMA_ council facilitation_COMMA_ rites of passage_COMMA_ vision fasts_COMMA_ dream circles. I will include a paper I wrote for my Psych masters_COMMA_ as a way of offering a sampling of thought processes._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_rCbOoDDrUeU3pETGRjdlBZbEU/edit?usp=sharing
column16: I have lived in community for years now_COMMA_ Buddhist temples and monasteries to council-based Earth-wisdom based communities_COMMA_ and I love it. It is the only way to live! During our intensive training_NEWLINE_periods at Zen Mountain Monastery_COMMA_ we engage in body practice_COMMA_ which is... Ultimate Frisbee! When I arrived at ZMM_COMMA_ I had never played frisbee_COMMA_ and had never played it in a group_COMMA_ on a team_COMMA_ in silence! Unfortunately_COMMA_ I think it is the truth that before this game_COMMA_ I have never done an activity simply because it is fun_COMMA_ and_COMMA_ even as I worked hard to stay in silence_COMMA_ I found myself laughing wildly throughout the hour each week. We are all competitive to varying degrees_COMMA_ and we all work hard to score goals_COMMA_ but no points are tallied. We practice letting it go the moment it is over. It feels clean_COMMA_ and full of joy. It is a phenomenal manifestation of Indra's net_COMMA_ an active form of communal engagement_COMMA_ a wildly dynamic illustration of live interconnectedness_COMMA_ of causal relations_COMMA_ of loving inclusion and the healthy channeling of aggression_COMMA_ of multiplicity_COMMA_ and active quick attentiveness.
column17: The project I am tip-toeing towards will be based in the effort to close the gap between civilization and wildness_COMMA_ between solar consciousness and lunar consciousness. I want to offer_COMMA_ along with others who are doing similarly-oriented work around the world_COMMA_ wilderness rites of passage_COMMA_ wherein those of us who feel like we've lost our way_COMMA_ can begin to find our way back. The theme of the session_COMMA_ between culture and wildness_COMMA_ is well-suited to the work that I am beginning to step into_COMMA_ though the word 'culture' definitely throws a different light on to what I am calling civilization. However_COMMA_ this dissonance has the potential for much juicy exploration_COMMA_ which I would love to engage with the support and challenge of others.
column19: I would facilitate a dream council_COMMA_ or a visionary council_COMMA_ or a 24hr solo fast_COMMA_ with mirroring and a communal setting of intentions. _NEWLINE_Dream councils involve the setting of sacred space_COMMA_ and the creation of a communal matrix using dream time._NEWLINE_Visioning councils are circles_COMMA_ facilitated with a theme in mind_COMMA_ allowing the community to enter into shared shikantaza_COMMA_ which is a zen term for open awareness. We will form a container which is strong enough to hold all voices_COMMA_ as the sky is vast enough to allow all forms of weather to move through._NEWLINE_The solo is an opportunity to go out into the wilderness with just water and a simple shelter. No journal. No food. Bare bones. Just you and the mirror of the wild. There is council before_COMMA_ to clarify intentions_COMMA_ and council after_COMMA_ to mirror and listen to stories. And in the middle_COMMA_ during the Threshold_COMMA_ we are all invisible_COMMA_ and in the spirit world_COMMA_ wandering until we each find our own unique power spots. There we stay_COMMA_ sitting vigil overnight_COMMA_ watching for what the mind_COMMA_ both internal and external_COMMA_ has to offer.
column20: What is your life question?_NEWLINE_I am in the middle. I struggle with the gaps. A deep part of me wants only to retreat_COMMA_ to fall into silence_COMMA_ to cease the movement_COMMA_ and to listen_COMMA_ watch. And a powerful part of me wants to run_COMMA_ to involve myself_COMMA_ to create. I feel I am on the edge of a process of constant breaking down/building up_COMMA_ and I can commit to neither one nor the other. I ache for the wilderness. How do I end up in the cities?
column21: If I commit to it_COMMA_ I'll be there.

column12: Session A (BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE // RECONSTRUCTING WILDNESS)_COMMA_ Session B (UNTHINKING/UNKNOWING)
column13: I am a 22 year old half asian half american finishing up my last semester at the Columbus College of Art and Design in the AICAD residency program in Dumbo. I'm from Knoxville_COMMA_ TN but I see myself as a man of the world. I have always loved and welcomed change and new challenges_COMMA_ which definietely plays apart of my artistic practice. I have traveled to China 7 times now_COMMA_ traveling over there took a large part of my life as a child. Growing up understanding two completely different cultures and walks of life has given me a drive and intense will to work and produce art that challenges and awakens us to this existence.
column14: My process is very open. I work with whatever is around me I have always been very flexible_COMMA_ I don't see divisions between different art practices and or social practice. One of my biggest interests has been film/video which it in itslef is very collaborative. Most of my work or practice is about asking questions_COMMA_ in this sense asking is also a collaborative process.
column15: I collaborated with the band Yung Life by choreographing and performing a dance/performance in lieu of their music. We toured across the east coast for three weeks performing in public spaces. As the tour continued my choreography transformed because of our newfound experiences and interactions. My work is reactionary and very open to the environment around me.
column16: Lived with 5 people in a van in July across East Coast. I am currently living with 21 people in a apartment in Midtown turned illegal bunk bed scenario. Backpacked across China for 2 months living with people I met paying dues by helping around and through art gifts.
column17: I thoroughly enjoyed Deleuze and Guattari's "Precept_COMMA_ Affect_COMMA_ and Concept" I'm very interested in how Deleuze's concept's can be implemented in an actual practice._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I love how explorative the program seems. Creating a residency that challenges what a regular residency is very interesting to me. After my stay in New York I have realized that I must shut myself in or at least be in a place more secluded. Where I can reconnect to the actual world. This line from The Tao Te Ching has been stuck in my head._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_"You don't have to leave your room_NEWLINE_to understand what's happening in the world._NEWLINE_You don't have to look out the window_NEWLINE_to appreciate the beauty of heaven._NEWLINE_The farther you go _NEWLINE_the less you know. _NEWLINE_Using this: Sages don't go anywhere and yet know what to do. _NEWLINE_Don't see and yet name things. _NEWLINE_Don't deem-act and yet accomplish.
column19: The beginning of my series of sculptures around the country creating objects of ritual or importance for the American landscape. Sculptures that are extremely permanent_COMMA_ and with time become culturally relevant. Stupa like sculptures that people have to trek on foot to experience. Or an interactive performance that utilizes parts of the forest that one has to travel to one part play/open conversation and surreal performance. Putting viewers into a state of acute awareness of the world around them.
column20: why do we always try to find answers? Why do we think our answers divulge some kind of truth? Answers only lead to more questions. Hopefully one realizes that truth isn't within the answer_COMMA_ it is in asking the better question. For truth exists in the human act_COMMA_ the process of finding. The journey.
column22: from a nice guy at a party who gave me your card.

column13: I'm an artist and a critical thinker. In college_COMMA_ I studied philosophy at the University of Chicago – a school I wanted to go to because of their core curriculum (with classes like 'Self_COMMA_ Culture_COMMA_ & Society') and their “UNcommon Application”. I said in my uncommon application that I thought a liberal arts education would make me a better thinker and therefore a better artist. That was when I was 18. Now I'm 30. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I moved to NYC after college to pursue acting. I worked with an experimental theater company called the Bats at the acclaimed Flea Theater and in the NYC Fringe Festival. I learned a lot about working on new plays. Eventually_COMMA_ I realized that training was essential to my craft_COMMA_ and in 2012_COMMA_ I got my MFA in acting at Rutgers. Since Rutgers_COMMA_ I've been honing my skills working in off-Broadway and regional theater_COMMA_ film_COMMA_ and national commercials. I am always dedicated to taking my work to the next level. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I find inspiration in a diversity of interests. Currently_COMMA_ I'm working on a line of recycled denim clothing and accessories called SilkDenim_COMMA_ a screenplay_COMMA_ and I'm learning how to make films with a DSLR. I'm also engaged in feminist art. For example_COMMA_ last year I was a guest speaker in a high school girls' health class to discuss body image and feminist issues for which I created a questionnaire and inspirational handout. I love using art to explore the world_COMMA_ and I don't feel the need to limit that to one medium. All types of art inform my ability to be engaged with my surroundings and question assumptions I have about myself and the world. For I believe “the unexamined life is not worth living.”
column14: Finding a balance between individual and collaborative work is an essential part of my creative path. Luckily_COMMA_ acting has taught me a lot about it. Despite being fundamentally collaborative_COMMA_ acting has a very solid basis of independent work that makes me aware of the difference between them and the necessity of both. When I walk into rehearsal or show up to perform_COMMA_ hours of personal preparation and body conditioning are involved. But all that preparation is really just that_COMMA_ because it is through collaboration that magic happens. Collaborating in the theater happens on many levels with many different people - the director_COMMA_ castmates_COMMA_ audiences_COMMA_ designers...on big and small levels_COMMA_ from creating the mood of the piece to deciding where to place a chair. My collaboration with the costume designer is different from my collaboration with an audience. I feel sometimes my collaboration with the audience is the most beautiful_COMMA_ but then I remember that it wouldn’t be possible without many other collaborations. Each play I do_COMMA_ I rediscover the awe of just how collaborative the theater is. Everyone has their own job_COMMA_ but all the jobs have to come together into a nightly experience for a short time. It's a challenge_COMMA_ but when it works_COMMA_ a true sense of community is created_COMMA_ and it feels awesome. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_My orientation to the world as an artist is by its very nature collaborative. I'm currently collaborating with my Mom on SilkDenim_COMMA_ I'm writing that screenplay with a friend_COMMA_ and I'm working on auditions in classes. I always find ways to engage others in projects. I find that collaborating with others keeps me motivated_COMMA_ structured_COMMA_ and challenged. In a sense_COMMA_ everything I do is collaborative. I love collaborating with friends and family_COMMA_ but I also love collaborating with a whole new group of people.
column15: The last play I did was Parlour Song by Jez Butterworth_COMMA_ a British contemporary dark comedy about 3 people trapped in a suburban mundane existence. I played Joy_COMMA_ a depressed and desperate housewife who begins stealing her husband's things to get his attention. Joy is a seemingly 'unlikeable' character; she steals_COMMA_ lies_COMMA_ and cheats to get what she wants. And Parlour Song is a highly poetic and at times absurd play. The combination proved to be a deeply fulfilling challenge for me_COMMA_ requiring me to be a more nuanced and patient performer. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Everyone involved in this production was a truly committed_COMMA_ talented_COMMA_ and giving artist. The play itself was brilliant material. Audiences were open and engaged. As a result of all these wonderful collaborations mixed with my hard individual work_COMMA_ I learned to embrace a part of me that really brought Joy to life. And this process of learning to bring Joy to life got deeper and deeper each and every night_COMMA_ with every show_COMMA_ every talkback_COMMA_ and every kitchen table conversation._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Through hard work and collaboration_COMMA_ I saw and felt the underlying humanity in Joy and the true depth of Parlour Song. This best represents me as an artist fit for your program because it not only shows me as a successful working professional_COMMA_ but as one who_COMMA_ when put into an engaged and critical community_COMMA_ excels and thrives. It can't exactly be shown to you because you would have had to see the play_COMMA_ but it helps that we received good press. Parlour Song proved to me that I'm a skilled artist who never stops learning_COMMA_ who puts her entire self into her work_COMMA_ and who works well with others. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Parlour Song reviews: _NEWLINE_http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yksRx98QR3s_NEWLINE_http://thetartan.org/2013/11/4/pillbox/parloursong_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Pgh Post Gazette named me one of the best actresses of the year for my performance: _NEWLINE_http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2014/01/05/Daina-Michelle-Griffith-2013-Performer-of-the-Year/stories/201401050053
column16: Once a year_COMMA_ a group of friends get together at my friend's Dad's house on Long Island. I call it my heaven. We make all our food together_COMMA_ we hang out on the rocky beach_COMMA_ we have long discussions about our lives and the future_COMMA_ we go for swims_COMMA_ walks_COMMA_ trips to buy food or pick people up_COMMA_ we collect and play with rocks. We clean up together. We spend time on everyone. We also respect when people want to be on their own and read or just be alone_COMMA_ take an outdoor shower. We build fires on the beach_COMMA_ and I always insist we roast marshmallows. We swim to the neighbor's floating trampoline and try to bounce each other off. This is heaven to me._NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I've lived in a lot of different set-ups_COMMA_ but most recently it's either been alone or with my boyfriend. I love living alone_COMMA_ but I often wonder if I had more time in a large communal house setting_COMMA_ would I be more inspired to think outside the box when it comes to my art.
column17: The question 'how can we think what we do not know how to think?' intrigues me because it reflects a kind of questioning I have about my creativity and life. I guess you could say I'm always thinking about how I think about things in the hopes that I'll teach myself how to better think about things. When you define thinking as “a questioning and investigating of the basic assumptions that define our selves_COMMA_ culture and world_COMMA_” I get very exited. I have a little fire within me that is never satisfied with the first idea_COMMA_ or with things as they are. I find that to be a natural state for me as an artist and a thinker_COMMA_ but also one that needs attention and effort_COMMA_ because it is in this state that I begin to truly create new ideas. _NEWLINE__NEWLINE_I think your program would encourage me take my creative investigation to the next level_COMMA_ and I'm looking to do so. What your school offers sounds particularly well-suited for me_COMMA_ because we have a mutual appreciation for the connection between the intellectual and the creative and for exploring innovative forms of learning. I like to talk but I also like to move_COMMA_ use my body_COMMA_ and try new things. For example_COMMA_ the extremely physical portion of the Unthinking/Unknowing session sounds really cool to me. I believe your approach may help me at this stage of my life and career_COMMA_ where I have a good foundation of skill and experience_COMMA_ but I've got something new I'm broaching that I need to get out.
column19: I would mount a 1-woman show based on the themes discussed in school in relation to themes I am working on as a feminist artist. I would come to the program already prepared with 5 female characters I want to explore. They would be a range of women in age and race_COMMA_ and I would use my time to create a show with these characters. I think with an unlimited budget_COMMA_ I would also bring in video and sound to make it a multi-media piece. I would start writing monologues and performing them for feedback the first week. The second week I would form the story_COMMA_ and the final days would be used to mount the show. I would want to bring in themes of beauty and body-mage_COMMA_ but mostly I would want to explore the ways in which different women grapple with their own self-worth.
column20: What is a theme you explore in your art?_NEWLINE__NEWLINE_Like with Parlour Song_COMMA_ I explore making the despicable relatable. It's not only necessary for acting_COMMA_ but also for communicating with others_COMMA_ and it requires admitting your own faults and trying to see the good in others' faults. More than empathy_COMMA_ it's about better understanding human behavior_COMMA_ or 'bad' behavior. It's easy to designate things good or bad_COMMA_ but when I look from an artistic point of view_COMMA_ I'm forced to see new perspectives. I'm forced to re-imagine and personalize a negative stereotype in hopes of getting others to see that stereotype in themselves or in ways they hadn’t before.

column23: I only eat humanely treated/farm meat_COMMA_ but other than that I eat everything.
